[[ru:Энергия#История термина «энергия»]]

{{hatnote|For other uses, see [[Holy water (disambiguation)]]. "Lustral water" redirects here, see also [[Water of lustration]].}} [[File:Angelo acquasantiera at Santa Maria degli Angeli - front.jpg|thumb|240px|A holy water container ([[stoup]]) at the church of [[Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri|Santa Maria degli Angeli]], [[Rome]]]] '''Holy water''' is water that has been [[Blessing|blessed]] by a member of the [[clergy]] or a religious figure. The use for cleansing prior to a baptism and spiritual cleansing is common in several religions, from [[Christianity]] to [[Sikhism]]. The use of holy water as a [[sacramentals|sacramental]] for protection against evil is common among [[Anglican]]s, [[Roman Catholics]],{{cite web|url=http://anglicanhistory.org/usa/ignatius/principles3.html|title=Tracts on Principles of Divine Worship: No. 3. The Sprinkling of Holy Water|publisher=Men's Guild, St. Ignatius' Church|accessdate=13 January 2013|location=New York|quote=Holy water has no power to beautify the soul here in time and the body in eternity, as Penance and the Eucharist have; but for those who reverently use it, having the right dispositions of faith and contrition, it has power to banish demons, dispel their deceits and vexations, cleanse the soul from stain of venial sins, avert earthly ills (other than those which God allows for our good), and to promote our temporal welfare.}}Henry Theiler, 2003 ''Holy Water and Its Significance for Catholics'' {{ISBN|0-7661-7553-7}} pp 13–15 and [[Holy water in Eastern Christianity|Eastern Christians]]. == In Christianity == {{see also|Water of lustration}} In [[Catholicism]], [[Anglicanism]], [[Eastern Orthodoxy]], [[Oriental Orthodoxy]] and some other [[Christian Church|churches]], holy water is water that has been sanctified by a [[priest]] for the purpose of [[baptism]], the [[Blessing (Christianity)|blessing]] of persons, places, and objects, or as a means of repelling evil.Chambers's encyclopædia, page 394, Published by Lippincott & Co (1870)Nathaniel Altman, 2002 ''Sacred water: the spiritual source of life'' {{ISBN|1-58768-013-0}} pp 130–133 === History === [[File:Holy water St Teresa's church Clarendon Street Dublin 2006.jpg|thumb|right|Take-home holy water at St Teresa's church, [[Dublin]]]] The use of holy water used by various sects of Christianity is a practice only attested to in Catholic documents. The [[Apostolic Constitutions]], which goes back to about the year 400, attribute the precept of using holy water to the [[Apostle Matthew]]. It is plausible that in earliest Christian times water was used for [[expiation|expiatory]] and [[ritual purification|purificatory]] purposes in a way analogous to [[Mikveh|its employment in Jewish Law]]. Yet, in many cases, the water used for the [[Sacrament]] of [[Baptism]] was flowing water, sea or river water, and it could not receive the same blessing as that contained in the baptisteries in the view of the Roman Catholic church.[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07432a.htm Catholic encyclopedia on Holy water] However, Eastern Orthodox do perform the same blessing, whether in a baptistry or an outdoor body of water. === Use and storage === Sprinkling with holy water is used as a [[Sacramentals|sacramental]] that recalls baptism.Catechism of the Catholic Church, Sacramentals, [http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P58.HTM ss. 1667, 1668] Holy water is kept in the [[holy water font]], which is typically located at the entrance to the church (or sometimes in a separate room or building called a [[baptistery]]). Smaller vessels, called [[stoups]], are usually placed at the entrances of the church, to enable people to sprinkle themselves with it on entering. In recent years, with the concerns over influenza, new holy water machines that work like an [[automatic soap dispenser]] have become popular.{{cite news|title=Hi-tech holy water calms flu fear|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8356019.stm|accessdate=17 May 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=11 November 2009}} In the Middle Ages the power of holy water was considered so great that in some places fonts had locked covers to prevent the theft of holy water for unauthorized [[Magic (paranormal)|magic practices]]. The Constitutions of [[Edmund Rich|Archbishop Edmund Rich]] (1236) prescribe that "Fonts are to be kept under lock and key, because of witchcraft (''sortilegia''). Similarly the [[chrism]] and sacred oil are kept locked up."''Fontes sub serura clausi teneantur, propter saortilegia. Chrisma similiter et oleum sacrum sub clave custodiantur" (Wilkinson, ''Consilia'', 1:636, quoted in [[George C. Homans]], ''English Villagers in the Thirteenth Century'', 2nd ed. 1991:384 and note 2). === Proper disposal === In Catholicism, holy water, as well as water used during the washing of the priest's hands at mass, is not allowed to be disposed of in regular plumbing. Roman Catholic churches will usually have a special basin (a ''[[Sacrarium]]'') that leads directly into the ground for the purpose of proper disposal. A hinged lid is kept over the holy water basin to distinguish it from a regular sink basin, which is often just beside it. Items that contained holy water are separated, drained of the holy water, and then washed in a regular manner in the adjacent sink.Henry Theiler, 2003 Holy Water and Its Significance for Catholics {{ISBN|0-7661-7553-7}} p 48 === Hygiene === Holy water fonts have been identified as a potential source of bacterial and viral infection. In the late 19th century, [[bacteriologist]]s found [[staphylococci]], [[streptococci]], [[escherichia coli|coli bacilli]], [[corynebacterium diphtheriae|Loeffler's bacillus]], and other bacteria in samples of holy water taken from a church in [[Sassari, Italy]].Dietetic and Hygienic Gazette, Volume 14, page 578. The Gazette Publishing Company, 1898. In a study performed in 1995, 13 samples were taken when a burn patient acquired a bacterial infection after exposure to holy water. The samples in that study were shown to have a "wide range of bacterial species", some of which could cause infection in humans.J.C. Rees and K.D. Allen, 1996 "Holy water—a risk factor for hospital-acquired infection". ''Journal of Hospital Infection'' 32(1), pages 51–55. During the [[swine flu]] epidemic of 2009, [[John Thomas Steinbock|Bishop John Steinbock]] of [[Fresno, California]] recommended that "holy water should not be in the fonts" due to fear of spreading infections.California Catholic Daily. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20120226133520/http://www.calcatholic.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?id=4646a566-ae6a-456c-8f28-0d47cb14d3ac Holy water should not be in fonts during this epidemic ]". 4 May 2009. Also in response to the swine flu, an automatic, motion-detecting holy water dispenser was invented and installed in an Italian church in 2009.NPR Morning Edition. "[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120340662 In Italy, An Automatic Holy-Water Dispenser ]". 12 November 2009. === Christian traditions === ==== Roman Catholics ==== ===== Sanctification ===== As a reminder of baptism, Catholic Christians dip their fingers in the holy water and make the [[sign of the cross]] when entering the church. The liturgy may begin on Sundays with the [[Rite]] of Blessing and Sprinkling Holy Water, in which holy water is sprinkled upon the congregation; this is called ''aspersion'', from the Latin, ''[[asperges|aspergere]]'', to sprinkle. This ceremony dates back to the ninth century. An ''aspergill'' or ''[[aspergillum]]'' is a brush or branch used to sprinkle the water. An ''aspersorium'' is the vessel which holds the holy water and into which the aspergillum is dipped, though elaborate [[Ottonian art|Ottonian]] examples are known as ''[[Situla (vessel)|situlae]]''. [[Blessed salt in Christianity|Blessed salt]] may be added to the water "where it is customary." This use of holy water and making a sign of the cross when entering a church reflects a renewal of baptism, a cleansing of [[venial sin]], as well as providing protection against evil.Philip Bold, 2008 ''Catholic Doctrine and Discipline Simply Explained'' {{ISBN|1-4097-8610-2}} page 283 It is sometimes accompanied by the following prayer:Jacquelyn Lindsey, 2001 ''Catholic Family Prayer Book'' OSV Press {{ISBN|0-87973-999-1}} p.65 {{quote|"By this Holy water and by your Precious Blood, wash away all my sins O Lord".}} Although not actually holy water since it has not been blessed by a [[priest]], some Catholics believe that water from specific shrines, such as [[Lourdes]], can bring healing.Richard Clarke, 2008 ''Lourdes, Its Inhabitants, Its Pilgrims, And Its Miracles'' {{ISBN|1-4086-8541-8}} page 38 ===== Formula ===== The traditional Latin formula for blessing the water is as follows:
Exorcizo te, creatura aquæ, in nomine Dei Patris omnipotentis, et in nomine Jesu Christi, Filii ejus Domini nostri, et in virtute Spiritus Sancti: ut fias aqua exorcizata ad effugandam omnem potestatem inimici, et ipsum inimicum eradicare et explantare valeas cum angelis suis apostaticis, per virtutem ejusdem Domini nostri Jesu Christ: qui venturus est judicare vivos et mortuos et sæculum per ignem. Deus, qui ad salutem humani generis maxima quæque sacramenta in aquarum substantia condidisti: adesto propitius invocationibus nostris, et elemento huic, multimodis purificationibus præparato, virtutem tuæ benedictionis infunde; ut creatura tua, mysteriis tuis serviens, ad abigendos dæmones morbosque pellendos divinæ gratiæ sumat effectum; ut quidquid in domibus vel in locis fidelium hæc unda resperserit careat omni immunditia, liberetur a noxa. Non illic resideat spiritus pestilens, non aura corrumpens: discedant omnes insidiæ latentis inimici; et si quid est quod aut incolumitati habitantium invidet aut quieti, aspersione hujus aquæ effugiat: ut salubritas, per invocationem sancti tui nominis expetita, ab omnibus sit impugnationibus defensa. Per Dominum, amen.
'''English translation:'''
I exorcise thee, creature of water, in the name of God the Father almighty, in the name of Jesus Christ, his Son, our Lord, and in the power of the Holy Spirit, that you may put to flight all the power of the enemy, and that enemy and to root out and, along with his fallen angels through the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, who shall come to judge the living and the dead and the world by fire. O God, who for the salvation of the human race has built Thy greatest mysteries in the substance, in your kindness hear our prayers, and with the element to this, for many kinds of purifications of his well-prepared, the power of Thy blessing, Serve it; the creation of Thy mysteries, serving as an agent of divine grace; is sprinkled with this water in their houses or in the buildings of the faithful, that whatever might be free from all uncleanness, he is freed from every harm. It is not no pestilent spirit, no taint of corruption; let all the wiles of the lurking enemy; or to provide for the safety and peace of the inhabitants of that which is, and if there be any, by the sprinkling of this water, so that health, through the invocation of Thy holy name, made secure against all attacks. Through the end.
===== Protection against evil ===== [[File:Teresa of Avila dsc01644.jpg|thumb|left|[[Saint Teresa of Avila]], by [[Rubens]], 1615]] Catholic saints have written about the power of holy water as a force that repels evil. Saint [[Teresa of Avila]], a [[Doctor of the Church]] who reported [[visions of Jesus and Mary]], was a strong believer in the power of holy water and wrote that she used it with success to repel evil and temptations.Tessa Bielecki, Mirabai Starr, 2008 ''Teresa of Avila: The Book of My Life'' {{ISBN|1-59030-573-6}} pp 238–241 She wrote: {{quote|"I know by frequent experience that there is nothing which puts the devils to flight like Holy water."Teresa of Avila, 2008 ''Life of St. Teresa of Jesus'' {{ISBN|1-60680-041-8}} page 246}} In ''Holy Water and Its Significance for Catholics'' Henry Theiler states that in addition to being a strong force in repelling evil, holy water has the twofold benefit of providing [[grace (Christianity)|grace]] for both body and soul.Henry Theiler, 2003 ''Holy Water and Its Significance for Catholics'' {{ISBN|0-7661-7553-7}} pp 24–31 The new ''[[Rituale Romanum]]'' excludes the [[exorcism]] prayer on the water. Exorcized salt used to be added to the holy Water as well. Priests can now use the older form if they wish according to ''[[Summorum Pontificum]]'', an apostolic letter by Pope Benedict XVI.{{cite web|title=Extraordinary Form; Book of Blessings|author=Legionary of Christ Father Edward McNamara|url=http://www.ewtn.com/library/liturgy/zlitur336.htm|publisher=ZENIT}} ==== Eastern Christians ==== {{Main|Holy water in Eastern Christianity}} [[File:The consecration of water on the Theophany. Kustodiev.jpg|thumb|right|''Great Blessing of Waters'' by [[Boris Kustodiev]]]] [[File:Esphigmenou.procession for Little Blessing of Waters.jpeg|thumb|right|Procession for the Lesser Blessing of Waters]] Among the [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] and the [[Byzantine Rite]] [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Catholics]] holy water is used frequently in rites of [[blessing]] and [[exorcism]], and the water for baptism is always sanctified with a special blessing. There are two rites for blessing holy water: the "Great Blessing of Waters" which is held on the [[Great Feasts|Feast]] of [[Theophany]] and at baptisms, and the "Lesser Blessing of Waters" which is conducted according to need and local custom during the rest of the year, certain feast days calling for the Lesser Blessing of Waters as part of their liturgical observance. Both forms are based upon the Rite of Baptism. After the blessing of holy water the faithful are sprinkled with it and each drinks some of it. Holy water is drunk by the faithful after it is blessed and it is a common custom for the pious to drink holy water every morning. In the monasteries of [[Mount Athos]] holy water is always drunk in conjunction with consuming [[antidoron]]. Eastern Orthodox do not typically bless themselves with holy water upon entering a church as Western Catholics do, but a quantity of holy water is often kept in a [[baptismal font|font]] placed in the [[narthex]] (entrance) of the church, available for anyone who would like to partake of it or to take some of it home. After the annual Great Blessing of Waters at [[Theophany]] (also known as [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]), the priest goes to the homes of the faithful within his parish and, in predominantly Orthodox lands, to the buildings throughout town, and blesses them with holy water. When blessing objects such as the palms on [[Palm Sunday]], [[Easter eggs|Paschal eggs]] and other foods for [[Easter]], candles, or liturgical instruments and sacred vessels ([[icon]]s and crosses are not blessed, however, as they are considered intrinsically holy and redeemed). The blessing is completed by a triple sprinkling with holy water using the words, "This (''name of item'') is blessed by the sprinkling of this holy water, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit." Throughout the centuries, there have been many springs of water that have been believed by members of the Orthodox Church to be miraculous. Some still flow, such as the one at [[Pochaev Lavra]] in [[Ukraine]], and the Life-Giving Spring of the [[Theotokos]] in [[Constantinople]] (commemorated on [[Easter Friday|Bright Friday]]). ==== {{anchor|Sanctified water}} Anglicans ==== ''Holy water'' is not a term used in [[Church of England]] rites, although font water is sanctified in the Church of England baptism rite.[http://www.cofe.anglican.org/worship/liturgy/commonworship/texts/initiation/baptism.html Church of England Rite of Holy Baptism, The Archbishops' Council of the Church of England, 2000–2006] In contrast, the [[Episcopal Church (United States)]] does expressly mention the optional use of holy water in some recent liturgies of blessing.Enriching Our Worship 5: Liturgies and Prayers Related to Childbearing, Childbirth, and Loss; Church Publishing; 2009; p. 20. More generally, the use of water within [[High Church]] Anglicanism or [[Anglo-Catholicism]] adheres closely to Roman Catholic practice. In many such Anglican churches baptismal water is used for the [[asperges]].[http://justus.anglican.org/resources/bcp/Anglican_Service_Book/vidi.html Anglican Service Book] Stoups with sanctified water are sometimes found near the doors of High Church Anglican churches for the faithful to use in making the [[sign of the cross]] upon entering the [[Church (building)|church]]. ==== Lutherans ==== The use of holy water in some synods of [[Lutheranism]] is for the [[baptism]] of infants and new members of the church. The water is believed to be blessed by God, as it is used in a [[sacrament]]. The water is applied to the forehead of the laity being baptised and the minister performs the [[sign of the cross]]. Lutherans tend to have holy water fonts at the entrance of the church.{{cite news|url=http://www.stjamessumter.org/Newsletters/Newsletter0213.pdf|title=Where is the Baptismal Font?|last=Getz|first=Keith|date=February 2013|publisher=Evangelical Lutheran Church in America|accessdate=5 May 2014|quote=By having the font at the entrance of the church, and using the font every Sunday, we are intentionally and dramatically revealing the importance of Holy Baptism and highlighting it as foundational to our life in Christ. It symbolically reminds us that we enter into the life of the church, into the life of Christ’s body, through the birthing waters of the baptismal font, where we are born again from above. Dipping our fingers in the holy water of the font and making the sign of the cross, reinforces who and whose we are. We are reminded that we have been baptized; daily we die to sin and rise to new life in the Spirit. The font is also positioned so that from the font there is a direct and central path leading to the altar, highlighting how these two Holy Sacraments are intimately connected. As we leave the church, we see the baptismal font, reminding us that we have been baptized, named and claimed, to serve others in proclamation and service to others.}} Other synods do not use holy water, however they do typically treat the water used for baptisms in a more respectful manner. ==== Methodists ==== In the Methodist tradition, Holy Baptism is often administered by sprinkling or pouring holy water over the candidate.{{cite web|title=Baptism|last=Hannon|first=Dan|year=2014|work=Life Events|publisher=The United Methodist Church|accessdate=5 May 2014|quote=Holy Baptism is a Covenant between an individual and God. It is God’s word to us, proclaiming our adoption by grace and our word to God, promising our response of faith and love. Persons of all ages can be baptized at Christ Church. We baptize by sprinkling Holy Water. The United Methodist Church recognizes baptisms from other denominations and churches and therefore does not “re-baptize”.}} The official Baptismal Liturgy, as well as the liturgy for Reaffirmation of Baptism commonly done through asperges, has a prayer for the blessing of this water:{{cite web|title=This is your Baptismal Liturgy: A Resource for Understanding The United Methodist Ritual of Holy Baptism|year=2001|publisher=The United Methodist Church|accessdate=5 May 2014|quote=Holy Spirit is invoked to bless and use the water, in anticipation that God will act again, even now.}} {{quotation|Pour out your Holy Spirit, to bless this gift of water and those who receive it, to wash away their sin and clothe them in righteousness throughout their lives, that, dying and being raised with Christ, they may share in his final victory. All praise to you, Eternal Father, through your Son Jesus Christ, who with you and the Holy Spirit lives and reigns for ever. Amen.{{cite web|title=This is your Baptismal Liturgy: A Resource for Understanding The United Methodist Ritual of Holy Baptism|year=2001|publisher=The United Methodist Church|accessdate=5 May 2014}}}} == Other religions == {{Expand section|date=March 2013}} [[File:Hindu public prayer in Haridwar.jpg|thumb|A [[Hindu]] public prayer in the [[River Ganges]]]] In [[Ancient Greek religion]], holy water called ''chernips'' ({{Lang-el|χέρνιψ}}) was created when a torch from a religious shrine was extinguished in it. In Greek religion, purifying people and locations with water was part of the process of distinguishing the [[Sacred–profane dichotomy|sacred from the profane]].''Greek religion: archaic and classical'', by Walter Burkert, John Raffan 1991 {{ISBN|0-631-15624-0}} page 77 The [[Book of Numbers]] mentions using water in a test for the purity of a wife accused of marital infidelity.{{bibleref2|Numbers|5:12–31}} Known as [[Ordeal of the bitter water|the Ordeal of the Bitter Water]], the accused woman ([[Sotah (Talmud)|sotah]]) would first be asked to confess to her crime before the court. If she refused to confess, she would then undergo the ritual. She would be stripped naked and then drink a mixture of water and dust. If she was guilty, she would be supposedly cursed to miscarry any pregnancy, though the text is unclear on the exact punishment. If she was innocent, there would be no effect.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UYHNaY1oXQQC&pg=PA186 |page=186 |title=Women and Jewish Law: The Essential Texts, Their History, and Their Relevance for Today |last=Biale |first=Rachel |publisher=Random House Digital |year=1995 |isbn=0805210490}} [[Sikh]]s use the [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] term ''amrita'' (ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ) for the holy water used in the [[baptism]] ceremony known as ''[[Amrit Sanskar]]'' or ''Amrit Chhakhna''.''Sikhism'', 2004, by Geoff Teece {{ISBN|1-58340-469-4}} page 7 In Hinduism, water represents God in a spiritual sense which is the central theme in [[Mantra Pushpam]] from Taithreeya Aranyakam of [[Yajur Veda]]. Bathing in holy water is, thus, a key element in [[Hinduism]], and the [[Ganges]] is considered the holiest Hindu river.''Hinduism'', 2004, by Geoff Teece {{ISBN|1-58340-466-X}} page 22 The idea of "blessed water" is used in virtually all [[Buddhist]] traditions. In the [[Theravada]] tradition, water is put into a new pot and kept near a ''Paritrana'' ceremony, a blessing for protection. This "lustral water" can be created in a ceremony in which the burning and extinction of a candle above the water represents the [[Classical element|element]]s of earth, fire, and air.{{cite web|url=http://www.thailandlife.com/lustralwater.htm|title=Buddhism in Thailand: Lustral Water}} This water is later given to the people to be kept in their home. Not only water but also oil and strings are blessed in this ceremony. Most [[Mahayana]] Buddhists typically recite sutras or various mantras (typically that of the bodhisattva [[Avalokitesvara]] for example) numerous times over the water, which is then either consumed or is used to bless homes afterwards. In Vajrayana Buddhism, a ''[[Bumpa]]'', a ritual object, is one of the ''[[Ashtamangala]]'', used for storing sacred water sometimes, symbolizing wisdom and long life.{{cite web | last =Smithsonian Institution | first = | title =Buddhist ritual sprinkler (kundika) | url =http://www.asia.si.edu/collections/singleObject.cfm?ObjectId=4442 | accessdate =16 July 2007 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070621094614/http://www.asia.si.edu/collections/singleObject.cfm?ObjectId=4442 | archivedate =21 June 2007 | df = }}{{cite web|last=The British Museum |first= |title=Stoneware kundika (water sprinkler) |url=http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/asia/s/stoneware_kundika_water_sprin.aspx |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927194709/http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/asia/s/stoneware_kundika_water_sprin.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 September 2007 |accessdate=16 July 2007 }} The [[Sunni Islam|Sunni Muslim]] variety of holy water is the [[Zamzam Well|Zamzam]] water that comes from a spring by The [[Kaaba]]. The drinking of "healing water" (''āb-i shifā'') is a practice in various denominations of [[Shia Islam]].Virani, Shafique. The Ismailis in the Middle Ages: A History of Survival, A Search for Salvation (New York: Oxford University Press), 2007, pp. 107–108. In the tradition of the [[Ithna Ashari|Twelver Shi’a]], many dissolve the dust of sacred locations such as [[Karbala]] (''khāk-i shifa'') and [[Najaf]] and drink the water (''āb-i shifā'') as a cure for illness, both spiritual and physical. The [[Ismaili]] tradition involves the practice of drinking water blessed by the [[Imam]] of the time. This water is taken in the name of the Imam and has a deep spiritual significance. This is evident from the names used to designate the water, including light (''nūr'') and [[ambrosia]] (''amṛt, amī, amīras, amījal''). This practice is recorded from the 13th and 14th centuries and continues to the present day. The ceremony is known as ''ghat-pat'' in South Asia. In [[Wicca]] and other [[ceremonial magic]] traditions, a bowl of [[salt]] is blessed and a small amount is stirred into a bowl of water that has been ritually purified. In some traditions of Wicca, this mixture of water and salt symbolizes the brine of the sea, which is regarded as the womb of the Goddess, and the source of all life on Earth. The mixture is consecrated and used in many religious ceremonies and magical [[rituals]].''Wicca for Life: The Way of the Craft -- From Birth to Summerland'', 2003, by Raymond Buckland {{ISBN|0-8065-2455-3}} page 85 == Unofficial uses == Holy water has also been believed to ward off or act as a weapon against mythical evil creatures, such as [[vampire]]s. In eastern Europe, one might sprinkle holy water onto the corpse of a suspected vampire in order to destroy it or render it inert.Bonnerjea, Biren. A Dictionary of Superstitions and Mythology, Folk Press Limited, 1927, p. 242. [https://www.scribd.com/doc/29531529/A-DICTIONARY-OF-SUPERSTITIONS-mythologıes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314220256/http://www.scribd.com/doc/29531529/A-DICTIONARY-OF-SUPERSTITIONS-mytholog%C4%B1es |date=2014-03-14 }}Library of universal knowledge: A reprint of the last (1880) Edinburgh and London edition of Chambers' encyclopaedia, with copious additions by American editors, Volume 14. American Book Exchange (Original from Harvard University), 1881, p. 804. [https://books.google.com/books?id=OOIOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA804&dq=%22holy+water%22+AND+(vampire+OR+undead+OR+monster)&hl=en&ei=qscfTMqAM4LGlQferOGKDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22holy%20water%22&f=false] Thereafter, the concept proliferated into fiction about such creatures. == Gallery == ;Stoups File:ND de Fourvière Intérieur 250709 03.jpg|[[Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière]], [[Lyon]], France File:Smf, acquasantiera inizio Xv sec 02.JPG|[[Florence Cathedral]] File:Chiesa di Santa Maria a Cintoia (Florence) - Facade - Stoup.jpg|{{ill|Church of Santa Maria a Cintoia|it|Chiesa di Santa Maria a Cintoia (Firenze)|vertical-align=sup}}, Florence, Italy. File:Salzburg Kajetanerkirche Weihwasserbecken.jpg|Church of Saints Saint Cajetan and Maximillian, [[Salzburg]], Austria == See also == * [[Anglican devotions]] * [[Catholic devotions]] * [[Holy anointing oil]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * (Mother) Mary; Ware, (Archimandrite) Kallistos (Tr.)(1998). ''The Festal Menaion'' (reprint), pp 348–359. South Canaan: St. Tikhon's Seminary Press. {{ISBN|1-878997-00-9}}. * [[Isabel Florence Hapgood]] (Tr., Ed.)(1983). ''Service Book of the Holy Orthodox-Catholic Apostolic Church'' (6th ed.), pp 189–197. Englewood: Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese. * ''Collectio Rituum ad instar appendicis Ritualis Romani pro dioecesibus Statuum Foederatorum Americae Septentrionalis''. Milwaukee, Bruce (1954) == External links == * [http://www.orthodoxphotos.com/readings/john/2/ On Holy Water blessed at Theophany] by St. John of Shanghai and San Francisco (Eastern Orthodox) * [http://www.getholywater.com/churches/ Holy Water from various Churches] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070812030447/http://en.liturgy.ru/photo/fop.htm Photo of Great Blessing of Waters] at Theophany (Russian Orthodox) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070722100424/http://en.liturgy.ru/photo/fop6.htm Photo of Lesser Blessing of Waters] (Russian Orthodox) * [http://kildare.ie/Heritage/historic-sites/st-bridgets-well.asp St Brigid's Well, County Kildare] {{Catholic protection}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holy Water}} [[Category:Anglican liturgy]] [[Category:Baptism|Water]] [[Category:Catholic liturgy]] [[Category:Lutheran sacraments and rites]] [[Category:Eastern Christian liturgical objects]] [[Category:Religious behaviour and experience]] [[Category:Religious objects]] [[Category:Sacramentals|Water]] [[Category:Water and religion]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Objects believed to protect from evil]]

page.title: Indirect land use change impacts of biofuels

revision.text:
[[Image:Grande Sertao Veredas 3.jpg|right|thumb|[[Brazil]]ian [[cerrado]].]] [[Image:Amazonie.jpg|right|thumb|[[Amazon rainforest]].]]
The '''indirect land use change impacts of [[biofuels]]''', also known as '''ILUC''', relates to the unintended consequence of releasing more [[carbon emissions]] due to [[Land use, land-use change and forestry|land-use changes]] around the world induced by the expansion of croplands for [[ethanol fuel|ethanol]] or [[biodiesel]] production in response to the increased global demand for biofuels.<ref name=Searchinger0208/><ref name=WangLetScie/>
As farmers worldwide respond to higher crop prices in order to maintain the global food supply-and-demand balance, pristine lands are cleared to replace the food crops that were diverted elsewhere to [[biofuels' production]]. Because natural lands, such as [[rainforest]]s and [[grassland]]s, store carbon in their soil and [[biomass]] as plants grow each year, clearance of wilderness for new farms translates to a net increase in [[greenhouse gas emissions]]. Due to this change in the [[carbon stock]] of the soil and the biomass, indirect land use change has consequences in the [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) balance of a biofuel.<ref name=Searchinger0208/><ref name=WangLetScie/><ref name=Lausanne>{{cite web|url=http://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/121496/files/ |format=PDF|title=Accounting for indirect land-use changes in GHG balances of biofuels: Review of current approaches|author=Gnansounou|publisher=[[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]] |date=March 2008|accessdate=2009-06-07|display-authors=etal}} Working Paper REF. 437.101</ref><ref name=OpedFarrel/>
Other authors have also argued that indirect land use changes produce other significant social and environmental impacts, affecting biodiversity, water quality, [[food vs. fuel|food prices and supply]], [[land tenure]], worker migration, and community and cultural stability.<ref name=Lausanne/><ref name=Sawyer08>{{cite journal|title=Climate change, biofuels and eco-social impacts in the Brazilian Amazon and Cerrado. |author=Donald Sawyer |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]] | volume=363 |issue=1498 |pages=1747–1752 |date=2008-05-27 |language=|doi= 10.1098/rstb.2007.0030|pmid=18267903|pmc=2373893}} Published on line 2008-02-11.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.environmentmagazine.org/Archives/Back%20Issues/November%202007/Naylor-Nov07-full.html |title=The Ripple Effect: Biofuels, Food Security, and the Environment |work=[[Environment (magazine)|Environment]] |author=Naylor|date=November 2007|accessdate=2009-06-07|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Righelato07>{{cite journal|url= |title=Carbon Mitigation by Biofuels or by Saving and Restoring Forests? |author1=Renton Righelato |author2=Dominick V. Spracklen |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=317 |issue=5840 |pages=902 |date=2007-08-17 |doi=10.1126/science.1141361|pmid= 17702929}}<!--|accessdate=2009-06-07--></ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
==History== The estimates of [[carbon intensity]] for a given biofuel depend on the assumptions regarding several variables. As of 2008, multiple [[Life cycle assessment|full life cycle]] studies had found that [[Ethanol fuel in the United States|corn ethanol]], [[cellulosic ethanol]] and [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|Brazilian sugarcane ethanol]] produce lower greenhouse gas emissions than [[gasoline]].<ref name=Farrel2006/><ref name=TwoBillion/><ref name=USEthanol/><ref name=Wang2005/><ref name=Wang205ppt/><ref name=MLA04/><ref name=UKRTFO/> None of these studies, however, considered the effects of indirect land-use changes, and though land use impacts were acknowledged, estimation was considered too complex and difficult to model.<ref name=WangLetScie/><ref name=TwoBillion/> A controversial paper published in February 2008 in [[Science (journal)|Sciencexpress]] by a team led by Searchinger from [[Princeton University]] concluded that such effects offset the (positive) direct effects of both corn and cellulosic ethanol and that Brazilian sugarcane performed better, but still resulted in a small carbon debt.<ref name=Searchinger0208>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1151861|title=Use of U.S. Croplands for Biofuels Increases Greenhouse Gases Through Emissions from Land-Use Change|author=Timothy Searchinger|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=319 |issue=5867 |pages=1238–1240 | doi=10.1126/science.1151861 |date=2008-02-29|accessdate=2008-05-09|pmid=18258860|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2008Sci...319.1238S}} ''Originally published online in Science Express on 7 February 2008 available [http://www.princeton.edu/~tsearchi/writings/Searchinger_et_al-ScienceExpress.pdf here]''</ref> [[File:Cloud forest mount kinabalu.jpg|thumb|right|[[Malaysia]]n [[cloud forest]]]] After the Searchinger team paper, estimation of [[carbon emissions]] from ILUC, together with the [[food vs. fuel]] debate, became one of the most contentious [[issues relating to biofuels]], debated in the [[mass media|popular media]],<ref name=Time0208>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1713431,00.html?iid=sphere-inline-sidebar |title=The Trouble With Biofuels |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]] |author=Bryan Walsh |date=2008-02-14|accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=Time0308>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1725975,00.html |title=The Clean Energy Scam |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]] |author=Michael Grunwald |date=2008-03-27|accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''This article was the [[Article (publishing)|cover story]] of the [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/0,9263,7601080407,00.html April 7, 2008, print edition entitled "The Clean Energy Myth"].''</ref><ref name=DebateTime>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1729709,00.html |title=The Debate on Clean Energy |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]] |author=Joe Jobe |date=2008-04-10|accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''Reply letter by Joe Jobe, CEO of the National Biodiesel Board published in the "Inbox" section in Time's April 21 issue''.</ref><ref name=NYT1108>{{cite news |url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/11/03/the-biofuel-debate-good-bad-or-too-soon-to-tell/?scp=10&sq=Clean%20energy%20scam%20Time%202008&st=cse |title=The Biofuel Debate: Good, Bad or Too Soon to Tell? |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author=Tom Zeller Jr. |date=2008-11-03|accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=RFA1108>{{cite news |url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/blogs/greeninc/summary.pdf|format=PDF |title=Executive Summary: Understanding Land Use Change and U.S. Ethanol Expansion |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |author=Renewable Fuels Association |date=2008-11-08 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=GCC1008>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2008/10/biofuel-compani.html |title=Biofuel Companies Question ARB's Inclusion of Indirect Effects in Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=2008-10-24 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=WSJ1108>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122636711059015989 |title=If a Tree Falls in the Forest, Are Biofuels To Blame? It's Not Easy Being Green |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |author=Stephen Power |date=2008-11-11 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=SFC042209>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/04/21/MN81175SHB.DTL |title=State readies stringent fuel standards |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=David R. Baker |date=2009-04-22|accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displayStory.cfm?story_id=14205727 | title=Maized and confused, Does ethanol in Iowa cause deforestation in Brazil? | work=[[The Economist]] |date=2009-08-10| accessdate=2009-08-12}}</ref> [[scientific journal]]s,<ref name=Searchinger0208/><ref name=WangLetScie>{{cite web |url=http://www.transportation.anl.gov/pdfs/letter_to_science_anldoe_03_14_08.pdf|format=pdf |title=Letter to Science about Searchinger et al. article |publisher=[[Argonne National Laboratory]] |author1=Michael Wang |author2=Zia Haq |date=2008-03-14 |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''The published version on Science Letters is included in Searchinger E-Letter responses 2008-08-12''</ref><ref name=Righelato07/><ref name=ScienceBiofuel>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/climate/2008/0801/full/climate.2007.71.html |title=The backlash against biofuels |author=Kurt Kleiner |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume= |issue= 0801|pages= 9|date=2007-12-12 |accessdate=2009-06-07|language=|doi= 10.1038/climate.2007.71}} ''Focus Feature published online''.</ref><ref name=SearchingResponse>{{cite journal|url=http://sciencepubs.com/content/319/5867/1238/reply |title=E-Letter response to M. Wang and Z. Haq's E-Letter: Ethanol's Effects on Greenhouse Gas Emissions |author=Timothy Searchinger |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=319 |issue= 5867 |pages= |date=2008-08-12 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=ORNLletter/> [[op-ed]]s and public letters from the [[scientific community]],<ref name=OpedFarrel>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/02/13/EDGEV10VF.DTL |title=Better biofuels before more biofuels |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=Alexander E. Farrell |date=2008-02-13 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=letter27scient>{{cite web |url=http://www.bioenergywiki.net/images/7/7b/DOE_letter.pdf |format=PDF |title= Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board|publisher=[[BioenergyWiki]] |date=2008-06-24 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=letter170scient>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/clean_vehicles/call_to_action_biofuels_and_land_use_change.pdf|format=PDF |title=Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name=GCC0408>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/04/usc-lcfs-20090421.html|title=Group of Scientists and Economists Urge Inclusion of Indirect Land Use Change Effects for Biofuels and All Transportation Fuels in California LCFS |publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref> and the ethanol industry, both American and Brazilian.<ref name=Economist0809>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displayStory.cfm?story_id=14205727|title=Maized and confused|work=[[The Economist]]|date=2009-08-10|accessdate=2009-08-10}}</ref><ref name=LetterCARB>{{cite web |url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/lists/lcfs09/67-nfa_arb_luc_final.pdf |title=Letter to Mary D. Nichols, CARB Chairman |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] |author=New Fuels Alliance |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref name= "UNICA03">{{cite web |url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/lists/lcfs09/129-unica_comments_to_carb_on_sugarcane_ethanol.pdf|format=PDF|title=UNICA's Comments to CARB on Sugarcane Ethanol |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]]|date=2009-04-16 |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref> This controversy intensified in April 2009 when the [[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) set rules that included ILUC impacts to establish the [[Low-carbon fuel standard#California Low-Carbon Fuel Standard|California Low-Carbon Fuel Standard]] that entered into force in 2011.
In May 2009 [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) released a [[notice of proposed rulemaking]] for implementation of the 2007 modification of the [[Renewable Fuel Standard]] (RFS).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/otaq/renewablefuels/#regulations |title=Renewable Fuel Standard Program (RFS2): Notice of Proposed Rulemaking |publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref> EPA's proposed regulations also included ILUC, causing additional controversy among ethanol producers.<ref name="LAT0609">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-corn-ethanol6-2009may06,0,2321568.story |title=New standards could cut tax breaks for corn-based ethanol |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |author= Jim Tankersley}}</ref><ref name="Guardian0609">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/may/06/obama-ethanol-green-biofuel|title=Barack Obama's $1.8bn vision of greener biofuel|author= Suzanne Goldenberg |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="WP0506"/><ref name="Jennifer Kho">{{cite web |url=http://earth2tech.com/2009/05/05/corn-ethanol-crew-cries-foul-over-epa-emissions-ruling/ |title=Corn Ethanol Crew Cries Foul Over EPA Emissions Ruling |publisher=earth2tech.com |author= Jennifer Kho |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref><ref name="UNICA Press Release">{{cite web |url=http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/prnewswire/press_releases/national/California/2009/05/05/SPTU003 |title=Sugarcane Ethanol Industry Eager to Implement U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard |publisher=National Press Release |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]] Press Release|date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref> EPA's February 3, 2010 final rule incorporated ILUC based on modelling that was significantly improved over the initial estimates.<ref name=EPARuling/><ref name=EPA2010/>
The [[UK]] [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]] program requires the [[Renewable Fuels Agency]] (RFA) to report potential indirect impacts of biofuel production, including indirect land use change or changes to food and other commodity prices.<ref name="UKRTFO"/> A July 2008 RFA study, known as the Gallager Review, found several risks and uncertainties, and that the "quantification of GHG emissions from indirect land-use change requires subjective assumptions and contains considerable uncertainty", and required further examination to properly incorporate indirect effects into calculation methodologies.<ref name=Gallagher0708>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewablefuelsagency.org/_db/_documents/Report_of_the_Gallagher_review.pdf |title=The Gallagher Review of the indirect effects of biofuels production |publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Agency]] |author=Ed Gallagher |date=July 2008 |accessdate=2009-06-09}} ''See Chapter 2: The effect of land-use change on GHG savings from biofuels''.</ref> A similarly cautious approach was followed by the [[European Union]]. In December 2008 the [[European Parliament]] adopted more stringent sustainability criteria for biofuels and directed the [[European Commission]] to develop a methodology to factor in GHG emissions from indirect land use change.<ref name=EU08/>
==Studies and controversy== {{relevance inline|date=December 2017}} [[Image:BioethanolsCountryOfOrigin.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1.30|UK figures for the [[carbon intensity]] of bioethanol and [[fossil fuels]]. Graph assumes all bioethanols are burnt in country of origin and prior cropland was used to grow feedstock. No ILUC effects were included.<ref name=UKRTFO>{{cite web| url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/govrecrfa.pdf|format=PDF|title= Carbon and Sustainability Reporting Within the Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation|publisher=Department of Transport, United Kingdom |date=January 2008 |accessdate=2009-04-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080625044948/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/govrecrfa.pdf |archivedate = June 25, 2008}}</ref>]] Before 2008, several [[Life cycle assessment|full life cycle]] ("Well to Wheels" or WTW) studies had found that [[Ethanol fuel in the United States|corn ethanol]] reduced transport-related greenhouse gas emissions. In 2007 a [[University of California, Berkeley]] team led by Farrel evaluated six previous studies, concluding that corn ethanol reduced GHG emissions by only 13 percent.<ref name=Farrel2006>{{cite journal|url= http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/311/5760/506|title=Ethanol Can Contribute to Energy and Environmental Goals|author=Farrel |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=311 |issue=5760 |pages=506–508 |date=2006-01-27 |accessdate=2009-06-01|language=|doi= 10.1126/science.1121416|pmid= 16439656|last2= Plevin|first2= RJ|last3= Turner|first3= BT|last4= Jones|first4= AD|last5= O'Hare|first5= M|last6= Kammen|first6= DM|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2006Sci...311..506F}}.</ref><ref name=TwoBillion/><ref name=Wang205ppt/> However, 20 to 30 percent reduction for corn ethanol, and 85 to 85 percent for [[cellulosic ethanol]],<ref name=TwoBillion/><ref name=USEthanol>{{Cite journal |author1=Goettemoeller, Jeffrey |author2=Adrian Goettemoeller | title = Sustainable Ethanol: Biofuels, Biorefineries, Cellulosic Biomass, Flex-Fuel Vehicles, and Sustainable Farming for Energy Independence | year = 2007| publisher = Prairie Oak Publishing, Maryville, Missouri |pages=40–41 |language=| isbn = 978-0-9786293-0-4 }}</ref> both figures estimated by Wang from [[Argonne National Laboratory]], are more commonly cited. Wang reviewed 22 studies conducted between 1979 and 2005, and ran simulations with Argonne's [[GREET model]]. These studies accounted for direct land use changes.<ref name=Wang2005>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportation.anl.gov/pdfs/TA/375.pdf|format=PDF|title=Updated Energy and Greenhouse Gas Emission Results of Fuel Ethanol |author=Michael Wang|publisher=Center for Transportation Research, [[Argonne National Laboratory]]|date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''Presented at the 15th [[International Symposium on Alcohol Fuels]], San Diego, California''.</ref><ref name=Wang205ppt>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportation.anl.gov/pdfs/TA/354.pdf |format=PDF|title=Updated Energy and Greenhouse Gas Emission Results of Fuel Ethanol |author=Michael Wang|publisher=Center for Transportation Research, [[Argonne National Laboratory]]|date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''This is a public presentation of Michael Wang 2005 paper summarizing the results of the ANL study''.</ref> Several studies of Brazilian sugarcane ethanol showed that sugarcane as feedstock reduces GHG by 86 to 90 percent given no significant land use change.<ref name=TwoBillion/><ref name=MLA04>{{cite web|url=http://www.eners.ch/plateforme/medias/macedo_2004.pdf |author= Macedo Isaias, M. Lima Verde Leal and J. Azevedo Ramos da Silva|title=Assessment of greenhouse gas emissions in the production and use of fuel ethanol in Brazil|publisher=Secretariat of the Environment, Government of the State of São Paulo|year=2004|accessdate=2008-05-09|language=|format=PDF |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528051443/http://www.eners.ch/plateforme/medias/macedo_2004.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-05-28}}</ref><ref name=UKRTFO/> Estimates of [[carbon intensity]] depend on [[crop productivity]], agricultural practices, power sources for ethanol distilleries and the energy efficiency of the distillery. None of these studies considered ILUC, due to estimation difficulties.<ref name=WangLetScie/><ref name=TwoBillion>{{Cite journal |author1=Sperling, Daniel |author2=Deborah Gordon | title = Two billion cars: driving toward sustainability | year = 2009 | pages= 98–99 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]], New York| isbn = 978-0-19-537664-7}} ''For more detail, see also the Notes 27 and 28 for Chapter 4, pp. 272''.</ref> Preliminary estimates by Delucchi from the [[University of California, Davis]], suggested that carbon released by new lands converted to agricultural use was a large percentage of life-cycle emissions.<ref name=TwoBillion/><ref name="Delucchi2006">{{cite web|url= http://www.its.ucdavis.edu/publications/2006/UCD-ITS-RR-06-08.pdf|format=pdf|title=Lifecycle Analyses of Biofuels (Draft Report)|author=Mark A. Delucchi |publisher=[[University of California, Davis]] |date=May 2006 |accessdate=2009-06-11}} [[Institute of Transportation Studies]] UCD-ITS-RR-06-08. ''See pp. 13–14.''</ref>
===Searchinger and Fargione studies=== In 2008 Timothy Searchinger, a [[lawyer]] from [[Environmental Defense Fund]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.princeton.edu/~tsearchi/ | title=Timothy D. Searchinger | accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> concluded that ILUC affects the [[life cycle assessment]] and that instead of saving, both corn and cellulosic ethanol increased carbon emissions as compared to gasoline by 93 and 50 percent respectively. Ethanol from Brazilian sugarcane performed better, recovering initial carbon emissions in 4 years, while U.S. corn ethanol required 167 years and cellulosic ethanol required a 52 years payback period.<ref name=Searchinger0208/> The study limited the analysis a 30-year period, assuming that [[land conversion]] emits 25 percent of the carbon stored in soils and all carbon in plants cleared for cultivation. Brazil, [[China]], and [[India]] were considered among the overseas locations where land use change would occur as a result of diverting U.S. corn cropland, and it was assumed that new cropland in each of these regions correspond to different types of [[forest]], [[savanna]] or [[grassland]] based on the historical proportion of each converted to cultivation in these countries during the 1990s.<ref name=Searchinger0208/>
{| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px" ! colspan="5" align=center style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | Summary of Searchinger et al. <br>comparison of corn ethanol and gasoline [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] emissions<br>with and without land use change <br> ([[Gram]]s of [[carbon dioxide equivalent|CO<sub>2</sub>]] released per [[megajoule]] of energy in fuel)<ref name=Searchinger0208/><ref name=SearchingerSM/> |- | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | <center>'''Fuel type<br>(U.S.)'''</center> || style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | <center>'''Carbon<br> intensity'''</center> || style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | <center>'''Reduction<br>GHG'''</center> || style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | <center>'''Carbon<br>intensity<br> + ILUC'''</center> || style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | <center>'''Reduction<br>GHG '''</center> |- | '''Gasoline''' || bgcolor="#ffffcc" |<center>'''92'''</center> || <center>-</center> ||bgcolor="#ffffcc" |<center>'''92'''</center> ||<center>-</center> |- | Corn ethanol || <center>74</center> || <center>-20%</center> ||<center>177</center> ||<center>+93%</center> |- | Cellulosic ethanol || <center>28</center> || <center>-70%</center> ||<center>138</center> ||<center>+50%</center> |- | colspan="5" align=left |<small>Notes: Calculated using default assumptions for 2015 scenario for ethanol in [[Common ethanol fuel mixtures#E85|E85]].<br>Gasoline is a combination of conventional and [[reformulated gasoline]].<ref name=SearchingerSM>{{cite web|url=http://www.princeton.edu/~tsearchi/writings/SupportingMaterials.pdf |title=Supporting Materials for Use of U.S. Croplands for Biofuels Increases Greenhouse Gases Through Emissions from Land Use Change |author=Searchinger |publisher=[[Princeton University]] |accessdate=2009-06-11 |year=2008 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010140245/http://www.princeton.edu/~tsearchi/writings/SupportingMaterials.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-10 |df= }} ''Data taken from Table 1B, pp. 21''.</ref></small> |}
Fargione and his team published a separate paper in the same issue of Sciencexpress claiming that clearing lands to produce biofuel feedstock created a carbon deficit. This deficit applies to both direct and indirect land use changes. The study examined six conversion scenarios: [[Brazil]]ian [[Amazon rainforest|Amazon]] to [[soybean]] [[biodiesel]], Brazilian [[Cerrado]] to soybean biodiesel, Brazilian Cerrado to sugarcane ethanol, [[Indonesia]]n or [[Malaysia]]n lowland [[tropical rainforest]] to [[oil palm|palm]] biodiesel, Indonesian or Malaysian [[peatland]] tropical rainforest to palm biodiesel, and U.S. Central [[grassland]] to corn ethanol.<ref name=Fargione08>{{cite journal|url= http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1152747 |title=Land Clearing and the Biofuel Carbon Debt |author=Fargione |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=319 |issue=5867 |pages=1235–1238 |date=2008-02-29 |accessdate=2009-06-09|language=|doi= 10.1126/science.1152747|pmid= 18258862|last2= Hill|first2= J|last3= Tilman|first3= D|last4= Polasky|first4= S|last5= Hawthorne|first5= P|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2008Sci...319.1235F}} ''Originally published online in Science Express on 7 February 2008, available [http://www.nature.org/initiatives/climatechange/files/land_clearing_and_the_biofuel_carbon_debt.pdf here]''.</ref> The carbon debt was defined as the amount of {{CO2}} released during the first 50 years of this process of land conversion. For the two most common ethanol feedstocks, the study found that sugarcane ethanol produced on natural cerrado lands would take about 17 years to repay its carbon debt, while corn ethanol produced on U.S. central grasslands would result in a repayment time of about 93 years. The worst-case scenario is converting Indonesian or Malaysian tropical peatland rainforest to palm biodiesel production, which would require about 420 years to repay.<ref name=Fargione08/>
====Criticism and controversy==== The Searchinger and Fargione studies created controversy in both the [[mass media|popular media]]<ref name=OpedFarrel/><ref name=Time0208/><ref name=Time0308/><ref name=DebateTime/><ref name=NYT1108/><ref name=RFA1108/><ref name=WSJ1108/> and in [[scientific journal]]s. [[Robert Zubrin]] observed that Searchinger's "indirect analysis" approach is [[pseudo-science|pseudo-scientific]] and can be used to "prove anything".<ref>''"For example, using Searchinger’s “indirect analysis” approach you can “prove” that increasing the mileage standards for vehicles contributes to global warming. Consider: Every gallon of gasoline not used by a motorist saves him $3.50 at today’s prices. He can use that money to buy other things. For example, at current prices (about $80 per ton), $3.50 could buy him about 90 pounds of coal. Burning that coal would obviously produce far more carbon dioxide emissions than burning the 6 pounds of carbon in one gallon of gas. So higher mileage standards for cars cause global warming. Q.E.D."'', in: {{cite book | title=Merchants of Despair: Radical Environmentalists, Criminal Pseudo-Scientists, and the Fatal Cult of Antihumanism | publisher=New Atlantis Books | author=Zubrin, Robert | year=2012 | isbn=978-1594034763}}</ref>
Wang and Haq from Argonne National Laboratory claiming: the assumptions were outdated; they ignored the potential of increased efficiency; and no evidence showed that "U.S. corn ethanol production has so far caused indirect land use in other countries." They concluded that Searchinger demonstrated that ILUC "is much more difficult to model than direct land use changes".<ref name=WangLetScie/> In his response Searchinger rebutted each technical objection and asserted that "... any calculation that ignores these emissions, however challenging it is to predict them with certainty, is too incomplete to provide a basis for policy decisions."<ref name=SearchingResponse/><ref name=SearchingNFAResponse/>
Another criticism, by Kline and Dale from [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]], held that Searchinger et al. and Fargione et al. "... do not provide adequate support for their claim that bioufuels cause high emissions due to land-use change", as their conclusions depends on a misleading assumption because more comprehensive field research found that these land use changes "... are driven by interactions among cultural, technological, biophysical, economic, and demographic forces within a spatial and temporal context rather than by a single crop market".<ref name=ORNLletter>{{cite web|url=http://www.ornl.gov/info/ornlreview/v41_3_08/ScienceMag_Kline_Dale_a06_080711.pdf|format=PDF|title=Biofuels: Effects on Land and Fire|publisher=[[Science (journal)|Letters to Science]]|date=2008-07-11|accessdate=2009-06-11|author1=Keith L. Kline |author2=Virginia H. Dale }} This reference also includes Timothy Searching and Joseph Fargione responses to Kline and Dale (''Science Vol 321'').</ref> Fargione et al. responded in part that although many factors contributed to land clearing, this "observation does not diminish the fact that biofuels also contribute to land clearing if they are produced on existing cropland or on newly cleared lands". Searching disagreed with all of Kline and Dale arguments.<ref name=ORNLletter/>
The U.S. biofuel industry also reacted, claiming that the "Searchinger study is clearly a 'worst case scenario' analysis ..." and that this study "relies on a long series of highly subjective assumptions ..."<ref name=NFAResponse>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/1522/response_to_science_articles_on_biofuels_-_new_fuels_alliance.pdf |format=pdf |title=Statement in Response to Science Articles on Biofuels |author=New Fuels Alliance |publisher=Renewable Fuels Association |accessdate=2009-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727023157/http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/1522/response_to_science_articles_on_biofuels_-_new_fuels_alliance.pdf |archivedate=July 27, 2008 }}</ref> Searchinger rebutted each claim, concluding that NFA's criticisms were invalid. He noted that even if some of his assumptions are high estimates, the study also made many conservative assumptions.<ref name=SearchingNFAResponse>{{cite web|url=http://www.bioenergywiki.net/images/3/31/Searchinger_Response.pdf |title=Response to New Fuels Alliance and DOE Analysts Criticisms of Science Studies of Greenhouse Gases and Biofuels|author=Timothy Searchinger|publisher=[[BioenergyWiki]]|date=2008-02-26 |accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
[[Image:SlashandburninBrazil.jpg|right|thumb|Slash and burn forest removal in Brazil.]] [[Image:Nelore cattle.jpg|right|thumb|[[Cattle ranching]] in Brazil.]]
===Brazil=== In February 2010, Lapola estimated that planned expansion of Brazilian sugarcane and soybean biofuel plantations through 2020 would replace [[rangeland]], with small direct land-use impact on carbon emissions.<ref name=Lapola2010/><ref name=Mongabay>{{cite web|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2010/0208-amazon_biofuels.html|title=Amazon rainforest will bear cost of biofuel policies in Brazil|publisher=Mongabay.com|author=Rhett A. Butler|date=2010-02-08|accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref> However, the expansion of the rangeland frontier into Amazonian forests, driven by cattle ranching, would indirectly offset the savings.<ref name=Mongabay/> "Sugarcane ethanol and soybean biodiesel each contribute to nearly half of the projected indirect deforestation of 121,970 km<sup>2</sup> by 2020, creating a carbon debt that would take about 250 years to be repaid...."<ref name=Lapola2010/>
The research also found that [[oil palm]] would cause the least land-use changes and associated carbon debt. The analysis also modeled livestock density increases and found that "a higher increase of 0.13 head per hectare in the average livestock density throughout the country could avoid the indirect land-use changes caused by biofuels (even with soybean as the biodiesel feedstock), while still fulfilling all food and bioenergy demands."<ref name=Lapola2010/><ref name=Mongabay/> The authors conclude that intensification of cattle ranching and concentration on oil palm are required to achieve effective carbon savings, recommending closer collaboration between the biofuel and cattle-ranching sectors.<ref name=Lapola2010>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2010/02/02/0907318107.abstract|title=Indirect land-use changes can overcome carbon savings from biofuels in Brazil|author=Lapola |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] | volume= 107|issue= 8|pages= 3388–93|date=2010-02-08|accessdate=2010-02-09|language=|doi= 10.1073/pnas.0907318107|pmid=20142492|last2=Schaldach|first2=R|last3=Alcamo|first3=J|last4=Bondeau|first4=A|last5=Koch|first5=J|last6=Koelking|first6=C|last7=Priess|first7=JA|pmc=2840431|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2010PNAS..107.3388L}}. Published online before print.</ref><ref name=Mongabay/>
The main [[UNICA, Brazil|Brazilian ethanol industry organization]] (UNICA) commented that such studies missed the continuing intensification of cattle production already underway.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.desmoinesregister.com/dmr/index.php/2010/02/08/do-brazils-biofuels-have-land-use-issue/ |title=Brazil biofuels' land-use issue |author=Philip Brasher |newspaper=[[Des Moines Register]] |date=2010-02-08- |accessdate=2010-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160516085121/http://blogs.desmoinesregister.com/dmr/index.php/2010/02/08/do-brazils-biofuels-have-land-use-issue/ |archivedate=2016-05-16 |df= }}</ref>
A study by Arima ''et al.'' published in May 2011 used spatial regression modeling to provide the first statistical assessment of ILUC for the Brazilian Amazon due to [[soy]] production. Previously, the indirect impacts of soy crops were only anecdotal or analyzed through demand models at a global scale, while the study took a regional approach. The analysis showed a strong signal linking the expansion of soybean fields in settled agricultural areas at the southern and eastern rims of the Amazon basin to pasture encroachments for cattle production on the forest frontier. The results demonstrate the need to include ILUC in measuring the [[carbon footprint]] of soy crops, whether produced for biofuels or other end-uses.<ref name=Arima>{{cite journal|title=Statistical Confirmation of Indirect Land Use Change in the Brazilian Amazon|author=Arima, E., Richards, P., Walker, R. and Caldas, M. M.|journal=[[Environmental Research Letters]]|volume=6 |issue=1498 |pages=1747–1752 |date=2011-05-24|language=|doi= 10.1088/1748-9326/6/2/024010|bibcode=2011ERL.....6b4010A}}<!--|accessdate=2011-11-27--></ref>
The Arima study is based on 761 municipalities located in the [[Amazônia Legal|Legal Amazon of Brazil]], and found that between 2003 and 2008, soybean areas expanded by 39,100 km² in the basin's agricultural areas, mainly in [[Mato Grosso]]. The model showed that a 10% (3,910 km²) reduction of soy in old pasture areas would have led to a reduction in deforestation of up to 40% (26,039 km²) in heavily forested municipalities of the Brazilian Amazon. The analysis showed that the displacement of cattle production due to [[agricultural expansion]] drives land use change in municipalities located hundreds of kilometers away, and that the Amazonian ILUC is not only measurable but its impact is significant.<ref name=Arima/>
==Implementation== {{see also|Low-carbon fuel standard}}
===United States===
====California LCFS==== {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px" ! colspan="4" align=center style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | California carbon intensity values <br>for
