others evaluated are available <br>at [http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs.htm CARB's website (see Lifecycle Analysis]). (1) Preliminary values of fuels not included <br>in the 2009 LCFS ruling and subject to refining.</small> |}
On April 23, 2009, [[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) approved the specific rules and carbon intensity reference values for the [[Low-carbon fuel standard#California Low-Carbon Fuel Standard|California Low-Carbon Fuel Standard]] (LCFS) that take effect January 1, 2011.<ref name=SFG042409>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/04/23/BABA1782HB.DTL&type=green&tsp=1 |title=Air Resources Board moves to cut carbon use |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=Wyatt Buchanan |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref><ref name=NYT042409>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9805E6DB113CF937A15757C0A96F9C8B63 |title=California: Low-Carbon-Fuels Mandate |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |agency=[[The Associated Press]]|date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-05-21}}</ref> CARB's rulemaking included ILUC. For some biofuels, CARB identified land use changes as a significant source of additional GHG emissions.<ref name="ARBproposal">{{cite web |url= http://www.arb.ca.gov/regact/2009/lcfs09/lcfsisor1.pdf |format=PDF|title=Proposed Regulation to Implement the Low Carbon Fuel Standard. Volume I: Staff Report: Initial Statement of Reasons|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|date=2009-03-05|accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref><ref name =CARBres0931>{{ cite web |url= http://www.arb.ca.gov/regact/2009/lcfs09/res0931.pdf|format=PDF|title= Air Resources Board: Resolution 09-31, April 23, 2009|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|date=2009-04-23|accessdate=2009-05-31}} Final resolution, pp 8.</ref> It established one standard for gasoline and alternative fuels, and a second for diesel fuel and its replacements.<ref name =CARBruleB>{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs_att_b_mod.pdf |format=pdf|title=Draft Attachment B: Public Hearing to Consider Adoption of a Proposed Regulation to Implement the Low Carbon Fuel Standard - Staff's Suggested Modifications to the Original Proposal|date=2003-04-23|publisher=CARB|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref>
=====Controversy===== The public consultation process before the ruling, and the ruling itself were controversial, yielding 229 comments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/lispub/comm/bccommlog.php?listname=lcfs09|title=Comment Log for Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS09) |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] |accessdate=2009-04-28}} ''All letters and attachments are posted for public view of this site''.</ref> ILUC was one of the most contentious issues. On June 24, 2008, 27 scientists and researchers submitted a letter saying, "As researchers and scientists in the field of biomass to biofuel conversion, we are convinced that there simply is not enough hard empirical data to base any sound policy regulation in regards to the indirect impacts of renewable biofuels production. The field is relative new, especially when compared to the vast knowledge base present in fossil fuel production, and the limited analyses are driven by assumptions that sometimes lack robust empirical validation."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bioenergywiki.net/images/7/7b/DOE_letter.pdf |format=PDF |title= Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board|publisher=BioenergyWiki |date=2008-06-24 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref><ref name="GCC08"/> The New Fuels Alliance, representing more than two-dozen biofuel companies, researchers and investors, questioned the Board intention to include indirect land use change effects into account, wrote "While it is likely true that zero is not the right number for the indirect effects of any product in the real world, enforcing indirect effects in a piecemeal way could have very serious consequences for the LCFS.... The argument that zero is not the right number does not justify enforcing a different wrong number, or penalizing one fuel for one category of indirect effects while giving another fuel pathway a free pass."<ref name="GCC08">{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2008/10/biofuel-compani.html |title=Biofuel Companies Question ARB's Inclusion of Indirect Effects in Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2008-10-24 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newfuelsalliance.org/NFA%20ARB%20ILUC%20Press%20Release%20Final.pdf |format=PDF |title=Leading Advanced Biofuel Companies, Researchers, Investors Call on Air Resources Board to Reconsider Draft Low Carbon Fuel Regulations |publisher=New Fuels Alliance |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref>
On the other side, more than 170 scientists and economists urged that CARB, "include indirect land use change in the lifecycle analyses of heat-trapping emissions from biofuels and other transportation fuels. This policy will encourage development of sustainable, low-carbon fuels that avoid conflict with food and minimize harmful environmental impacts.... There are uncertainties inherent in estimating the magnitude of indirect land use emissions from biofuels, but assigning a value of zero is clearly not supported by the science."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/clean_vehicles/call_to_action_biofuels_and_land_use_change.pdf |format=PDF |title=Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/04/usc-lcfs-20090421.html|title=Group of Scientists and Economists Urge Inclusion of Indirect Land Use Change Effects for Biofuels and All Transportation Fuels in California LCFS |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref>
Industry representatives complained that the final rule overstated the environmental effects of corn ethanol, and also criticized the inclusion of ILUC as an unfair penalty to domestic corn ethanol because deforestation in the developing world was being tied to U.S. ethanol production.<ref name="SFC042209"/><ref name="NYT042409"/><ref name="SciAm">{{cite journal| url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=california-adopts-low-carF|title= California Adopts Low-Carbon Fuel Standar|author=Debra Kahn |journal=[[Scientific American]] |date=2009-04-24|accessdate=2009-05-04}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="NYT042409_2">{{cite news |url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/tag/low-carbon-fuel-standard/?scp=1-b&sq=Calif.+approves+nation%27s+1st+low+carbon+fuel+standard&st=nyt |title=California Fuel Move Angers Ethanol Makers |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |author= Kate Galbraith|date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-29}}</ref><ref name="BDigest">{{cite web|title=CARB votes 9-1 for California Low Carbon Fuel Standard; moves up indirect land use review to Jan 2011 in response to outcry on ILUC |url=http://www.biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2009/04/24/carb-votes-9-1-for-california-low-carbon-fuel-standard-moves-up-indirect-land-use-review-to-jan-2011-in-response-to-outcry-on-iluc/ |publisher=BiofuelsDigest |author=Jim Lane |date=2009-02-24 |accessdate=2009-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911202522/http://www.biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2009/04/24/carb-votes-9-1-for-california-low-carbon-fuel-standard-moves-up-indirect-land-use-review-to-jan-2011-in-response-to-outcry-on-iluc |archivedate=2009-09-11 |df= }}</ref><ref name="GreenM"/> The 2011 limit for LCFS means that Mid-west corn ethanol failed, unless current carbon intensity was reduced.<ref name="SFG042409"/><ref name=BDigest/><ref name="CNN0409"/><ref name=SACBee/> Oil industry representatives complained that the standard left oil refiners with few options, such as Brazilian sugarcane ethanol, with its accompanying tariff.<ref name=GreenM>{{cite web|url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/california-adopts-low-carbon-fuel-standard-6083.html|title=California Adopts Low Carbon Fuel Standard|publisher=GreenMedia|author=Jeff St. John |date=2009-04-23|accessdate=2009-05-04}}</ref><ref name=SACBee>{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/capitolandcalifornia/story/1808713.html |title=California's low-carbon fuel standard has oil companies anxious |newspaper=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |author=Dale Kasler |date=2009-04-25 |accessdate=2009-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430120657/http://www.sacbee.com/capitolandcalifornia/story/1808713.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |df= }}</ref> CARB officials and environmentalists counter that time and economic incentives will allow produces to adapt.<ref name="GreenM"/><ref name="SACBee"/>
UNICA welcomed the ruling,<ref name="UNICA01">{{cite news|url=http://world-wire.com/news/0904230003.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426072816/http://world-wire.com/news/0904230003.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-04-26 |title=Sugarcane Ethanol Passes Critical Test in California |publisher=World-Wire |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]] Press release |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-25 }}</ref> while urging CARB to better reflect Brazilian practices, lowering their estimates of Brazilian emissions.<ref name= UNICA03/><ref name= UNICA01/><ref name= "UNICA02">{{cite journal |url=http://www.biofuelsjournal.com/articles/unica__sugarcane_ethanol_meets_carb_low_carbon_fuel_standard-74330.html |title=UNICA: Sugarcane Ethanol Meets CARB Low Carbon Fuel Standard |journal=Biofuels Journal |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]]|date=2009-04-17 |accessdate=2009-04-29}}</ref>
The only Board member who voted against the ruling explained that he had a "hard time accepting the fact that we're going to ignore the comments of 125 scientists", referring to the letter submitted by a group of scientists questioning the ILUC penalty. "They said the model was not good enough ... to use at this time as a component part of such an historic new standard."<ref name="BDigest"/><ref name=CNN0409>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/23/news/economy/california.reut/index.htm |title=California adopts first-ever low-carbon fuel rule |publisher=[[CNN News]] |date=2009-04-23 |accessdate=2009-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427132230/http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/23/news/economy/california.reut/index.htm |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref> CARB advanced the expected date for an expert working group to report on ILUC with refined estimates from January 2012 to January 2011.<ref name="SciAm"/><ref name="BDigest"/><ref name="CNN0409"/>
On December 2009 the [[Renewable Fuels Association]] (RFA) and [[Growth Energy]], two U.S. ethanol lobbying groups, filed a lawsuit challenging LCFS' [[constitutionality]]. The two organizations argued that LCFS violated both the [[Supremacy Clause]] and the [[Commerce Clause]], jeopardizing the nationwide ethanol market.<ref name=WSJ1209>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126169282611304857|title=Ethanol Groups Sue California Over Low-Carbon Rule|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=2009-12-24|accessdate=2009-12-29 | first=Stephen | last=Power}}</ref><ref name=GCC1209>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/12/rfa-lcfs-20091225.html#more|title=Ethanol Groups File Suit Challenging Constitutionality of California Low Carbon Fuel Standard|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2009-12-25|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/9E510C2CBC9CF893/968C17640481D3A09A8E73400EDACAB4|title=Ethanol Groups Challenge Constitutionality of California LCFS|publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2009-12-24|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref>
====EPA Renewable Fuel Standard==== {{see also|Energy Policy Act of 2005|Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007}} {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px" ! colspan="3" align=center style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" | [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]<br>Draft [[life cycle assessment|life cycle]] [[GHG emissions]] reduction results<br> for different [[time horizon]] and discount rate approaches<ref name=EPAdraft>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/otaq/renewablefuels/420f09024.pdf|format=PDF |title=EPA Lifecycle Analysis of Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Renewable Fuels - Technical Highlights |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''See Table 1''.</ref><br>(includes indirect land use change effects) |- ! style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" | Fuel Pathway || style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" | 100 years +<br> 2% discount<br>rate || style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" | 30 years +<br> 0% discount <br> rate |- |[[Ethanol fuel in the United States|Corn ethanol]] ([[natural gas]] dry mill)<sup>(1)</sup>||<center>-16%</center>||<center>+5%</center> |- |Corn ethanol (Best case NG DM)<sup>(2)</sup> ||<center>-39%</center>|| <center>-18%</center> |- |Corn ethanol ([[coal]] dry mill) ||<center>+13%</center>|| <center>+34%</center> |- | Corn ethanol ([[biomass]] dry mill)|| <center>-39%</center> ||<center>-18%</center> |- | Corn ethanol (biomass dry mill with <br>combined heat and power) ||<center>-47%</center>|| <center>-26%</center> |- | [[Soybean]]-based [[biodiesel]] ||<center>-22%</center>|| <center>+4%</center> |- | Waste grease biodiesel || <center>-80%</center> ||<center>-80%</center> |- | [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|Sugarcane ethanol]]||<center>-44%</center>|| <center>-26%</center> |- | [[Cellulosic ethanol]] from [[switchgrass]] || <center>-128%</center> ||<center>-124%</center> |- | Cellulosic ethanol from [[corn stover]] || <center>-115%</center> ||<center>-116%</center> |- | colspan="3" |<small>Notes: (1) Dry mill (DM) plants grind the entire kernel and generally produce<br> only one primary co-product: [[distillers grains]] with solubles (DGS).<br> (2) Best case plants produce wet distillers grains co-product.</small> |}
The [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]] (EISA) established new renewable fuel categories and eligibility requirements, setting mandatory [[life cycle assessment|lifecycle]] emissions limits.<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/> EISA explicitly mandated EPA to include "direct emissions and significant indirect emissions such as significant emissions from land use changes."<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=GCC0509>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/05/epa-nprm-20090505.html|title=EPA Proposes New Regulations for Renewable Fuel Standard to Implement Requirements of EISA; GHG Reduction and Indirect Land Use Change Effects Included|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref>
EISA required a 20% reduction in lifecycle GHG emissions for any fuel produced at facilities that commenced construction after December 19, 2007 to be classified as a "renewable fuel"; a 50% reduction for fuels to be classified as "biomass-based diesel" or "advanced biofuel", and a 60% reduction to be classified as "cellulosic biofuel". EISA provided limited flexibility to adjust these thresholds downward by up to 10 percent, and EPA proposed this adjustment for the advanced biofuels category. Existing plants were [[Grandfather clause|grandfathered]] in.<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=GCC0509/>
On May 5, 2009, EPA released a [[notice of proposed rulemaking]] for implementation of the 2007 modification of the [[Renewable Fuel Standard]], known as RFS2.<ref name=GCC0509/><ref name=EPAproposal>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/otaq/renewablefuels/#regulations |title=Renewable Fuel Standard Program (RFS2): Notice of Proposed Rulemaking |publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] |date=May 2009|accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref> The draft of the regulations was released for public comment during a 60-day period, a public hearing was held on 9 June 2009, and also a workshop was conducted on 10–11 June 2009.<ref name=EPA0509>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/420f09023.htm|title=EPA Proposes New Regulations for the National Renewable Fuel Standard Program for 2010 and Beyond|publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref><ref name=GCC0509/>
EPA's draft analysis stated that ILUC can produce significant near-term GHG emissions due to land conversion, but that biofuels can pay these back over subsequent years. EPA highlighted two scenarios, varying the time horizon and the [[discounted cash flow|discount rate]] for valuing emissions. The first assumed a 30-year time period uses a 0 percent discount rate (valuing emissions equally regardless of timing). The second scenario used a 100-year time period and a 2% discount rate.<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=GCC0509/>
On the same day that EPA published its notice of proposed rulemaking, President Obama signed a [[Presidential Directive]] seeking to advance biofuels research and commercialization. The Directive established the Biofuels Interagency Working Group, to develop policy ideas for increasing investment in next-generation fuels and for reducing their environmental footprint.<ref name="LAT0609"/><ref name="WH0509">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/President-Obama-Announces-Steps-to-Support-Sustainable-Energy-Options/|publisher=[[The White House]]|title=President Obama Announces Steps to Support Sustainable Energy Options, Departments of Agriculture and Energy, Environmental Protection Agency to Lead Efforts|date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref><ref name="NYT0509">{{cite news|url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/white-house-steps-up-support-for-biofuels/ |title=White House Steps Up Support for Biofuels |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-05 |author= Matthew L. Wald}}</ref><ref name="Sciam0509">{{cite news|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=obama-administration-pushes-biofuels |title=Obama Administration Prepares to Push Biofuels |work=[[Scientific American]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-05 |author= Ben Geman}}</ref>
[[Image:Combine-harvesting-corn.jpg|left|thumb|[[Maize]] is the main [[feedstock]] for the production of [[Ethanol fuel in the United States|ethanol fuel in the U.S.]].]]
[[Image:Sugarcane harvest Piracicaba 05 2009 5783.JPG|left|thumb|[[Sugarcane]] is the main feedstock for the production of [[ethanol fuel in Brazil]].]]
The inclusion of ILUC in the proposed ruling provoked complaints from ethanol<ref name="LAT0609"/><ref name="Guardian0609"/><ref name=WP0506>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/05/AR2009050503731.html?hpid%3Dmoreheadlines&sub=AR|title=EPA Proposes Changes To Biofuel Regulations |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |author1=Steven Mufson |author2=Juliet Eilperin |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref><ref name="Jennifer Kho"/><ref name="UNICA Press Release"/> and biodiesel producers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/07/biodiesel-group-lashes-out-at-epa-rule/?scp=1&sq=EPA%20RFS%20&st=cse |title=Biodiesel Makers Lash Out at E.P.A. Rule |publisher=[[The New York Times]]|author=Kate Galbraith |date=2009-07-09 |accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref> Several environmental organizations welcomed the inclusion of ILUC but criticized the consideration of a 100-year payback scenario, arguing that it underestimated land conversion effects.<ref name=WP0506/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foe.org/epa-confirms-corn-ethanol-worsens-global-warming-pollution |title=EPA Confirms Most Corn Ethanol Worsens Global Warming Pollution |publisher=[[Friends of the Earth]] Give EPA an Earful on Renewable Fuel Standard|publisher=Environment News Service |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher=Biomass Magazine|date=2009-06-06 |accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/9049866CBE5DDBF9 |title= Public Hearing on EPA's Proposed RFS Rule|publisher=Renewable Fuels Association |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref> while the oil industry requested an implementation delay.<ref name=PHsummary/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ogj.com/index/article-display/2183526677/s-articles/s-oil-gas-journal/s-processing/s-refining/s-articles/s-api_-npra_ask_epa.html |title=API, NPRA ask EPA to consider delay of RFS-2 implementation |publisher=Oil & Gas Journal |author=Nick Snow |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref>
On June 26, 2009, the House of Representatives approved the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act]] 219 to 212, mandating EPA to exclude ILUC for a 5-year period, vis a vis RFS2. During this period, more research is to be conducted to develop more reliable models and methodologies for estimating ILUC, and [[U.S. Congress|Congress]] will review this issue before allowing EPA to rule on this matter.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2009/06/29/climate-change-bill-passes-with-five-year-punt-on-indirect-land-use-change/trackback/ |title=Climate change bill passes, with five-year punt on indirect land use change |publisher=Biofuels Digest |author=Jim Lane |date=2009-06-29 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://industry.bnet.com/energy/10001543/climate-change-bill-passes-on-razor-thin-margin-tougher-battle-awaits-in-senate/ |title=Climate Change Bill Passes on Razor-Thin Margin, Tougher Battle |title= House passes historic climate bill |publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2009-06-26 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author=John M. On February 3, 2010, EPA issued its final RFS2 rule for 2010 and beyond.<ref name=EPARuling>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/|title=Renewable Fuel Standard Program (RFS2): Final Rule|publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref> The rule incorporated direct and significant indirect emissions including ILUC. EPA incorporated comments and data from new studies.<ref name=EPA2010/> Using a 30-year time horizon and a 0% discount rate,<ref name=EPAFinal2010/> EPA concluded that multiple biofuels would meet this standard.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/business/energy-environment/12biofuel.html|title=Questions About Biofuels' Environmental Costs Could Alter Europe's Policies|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|author=James Kanter|date=2010-02-11|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
EPA's analysis accepted both [[Ethanol fuel in the United States|ethanol produced from corn starch]] and [[Butanol fuel|biobutanol]] from corn starch as "renewable fuels". [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|Ethanol produced from sugarcane]] became an "advanced fuel". Both [[Green diesel|diesel produced from algal oils]] and [[biodiesel]] from soy oil and diesel from waste oils, fats, and greases fell in the "biomass-based diesel" category. [[Cellulosic ethanol]] and cellulosic diesel met the "cellulosic biofuel" standard.<ref name=EPA2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/420f10007.htm#7|title=Greenhouse Gas Reduction Thresholds|publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref>
The table summarizes the mean GHG emissions estimated by EPA modelling and the range of variations considering that the main source of uncertainty in the life cycle analysis is the GHG emissions related to international land use change.<ref name=EPAFinal2010/>

=====Reactions===== UNICA welcomed the ruling, in particular, for the more precise lifecycle emissions estimate and hoped that classification the advanced biofuel designation would help eliminate the tariff.<ref name=UNICA022010>{{cite web|url=http://unica.com.br/noticias/show.asp?nwsCode={BF4E1F8C-A8C0-4E1A-A0F0-208D2513D8DE}|title=Agência ambiental dos EUA reconhece etanol de cana como biocombustível avançado |publisher=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]]|language=Portuguese|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://domesticfuel.com/2010/02/04/epa-deems-sugarcane-ethanol-an-advanced-biofuel/|title=EPA Deems Sugarcane Ethanol an Advanced Biofuel|publisher=DOMESTICFUEL.com|date=2010-02-04|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
The U.S. [[Renewable Fuels Association]] (RFA) also welcomed the ruling, as ethanol producers "require stable federal policy that provides them the market assurances they need to commercialize new technologies", restating their ILUC objection.<ref name=RFA012010>{{cite web|url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/78B3C6C380747C63|title=RFS Rules "Workable" - ILUC Inclusion Still Problematic|publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
RFA also complained that corn-based ethanol scored only a 21% reduction, noting that without ILUC, corn ethanol achieves a 52% GHG reduction.<ref name=RFA012010/><ref name=NYTEPA010>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2010/02/04/04greenwire-new-biofuels-regs-could-still-face-fight-from-80948.html?emc=eta1|title=New Biofuels Regs Could Still Face Fight From Capitol Hill|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|author=Allison Winter|date=2010-02-04|accessdate=2010-02-16}}</ref> RFA also objected that Brazilian sugarcane ethanol "benefited disproportionally"<!--disproportionATEly?--> because EPA's revisions lowered the initially equal ILUC estimates by half for corn and 93% for sugarcane.<ref name=RFA022010>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/2769/rfs2_rule_summary_brief.pdf |title=Issue Brief: Summary of RFS2 Final Rule |publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]] |date=2010-02-04 |accessdate=2010-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nYTK6ewp?url=http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/2769/rfs2_rule_summary_brief.pdf |archivedate= February 15, 2010 }}</ref>
Several [[Midwestern United States|Midwestern]] lawmakers commented that they continued to oppose EPA's consideration of the "dicey science" of indirect land use that "punishes domestic fuels".<ref name=NYTEPA010/> House Agriculture Chairman [[Collin Peterson]] said, "... to think that we can credibly measure the impact of international indirect land use is completely unrealistic, and I will continue to push for legislation that prevents unreliable methods and unfair standards from burdening the biofuels industry."<ref name=NYTEPA010/>
EPA Administrator [[Lisa P. Jackson]] commented that the agency "did not back down from considering land use in its final rules, but the agency took new information into account that led to a more favorable calculation for ethanol".<ref name=NYTEPA010/> She cited new science and better data on crop yield and productivity, more information on co-products that could be produced from advanced biofuels and expanded land-use data for 160 countries, instead of the 40 considered in the proposed rule.<ref name=NYTEPA010/>
===Europe=== As of 2010, European Union and United Kingdom regulators had recognized the need to take ILUC into account, but had not determined the most appropriate methodology.
====UK Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation==== {{see also|Renewable transport fuel obligation}}
The [[UK]] [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]] (RTFO) program requires fuel suppliers to report direct impacts, and asked the [[Renewable Fuels Agency]] (RFA) to report potential indirect impacts, including ILUC and commodity price changes.<ref name="UKRTFO"/> The RFA's July 2008 "Gallager Review", mentioned several risks regarding biofuels and required feedstock production to avoid agricultural land that would otherwise be used for food production, despite concluding that "quantification of GHG emissions from indirect land-use change requires subjective assumptions and contains considerable uncertainty".<ref name=Gallagher0708/> Some environmental groups argued that emissions from ILUC were not being taken into account and could be creating more emissions.<ref name=Guardian0409>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/apr/15/biofuels-carbon-emissions |title=UK biofuels target creating more emissions, environmentalists claim|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|author=Alok Jha|date=2009-04-15|accessdate=2009-06-16 | location=London}}</ref><ref name=Telegraph0409>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/greenertransport/5153781/Green-fuels-produce-twice-as-much-carbon-as-fossil-fuels.html |title=Green fuels produce twice as much carbon as fossil fuels |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2009-04-15|accessdate=2009-06-16 | location=London}}</ref><ref name=BBCNews0408>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7347142.stm |title=Petrol must now include biofuels|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2008-04-15|accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref> <!--Pending: criticism to the Gallagher report, there is from both sides of the issue<ref name=Guardian0409/>-->
====European Union==== {{see also|Directive on the Promotion of the use of biofuels and other renewable fuels for transport}}
On December 17, 2008, the [[European Parliament]] approved the Renewable Energy Sources Directive (COM(2008)19) and amendments to the Fuel Quality Directive (Directive 2009/30),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32009L0030:EN:NOT|title=Directive 2009/30/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009|publisher=EUR Lex|accessdate=2010-01-29}}</ref> which included sustainability criteria for biofuels and mandated consideration of ILUC. The Directive established a 10% biofuel target. A separate Fuel Quality Directive set the [[Low-carbon fuel standard#EU low-carbon fuel standard|EU's Low Carbon Fuel Standard]], requiring a 6% reduction in GHG intensity of EU transport fuels by 2020. The legislation ordered the [[European Commission]] to develop a methodology to factor in GHG emissions from ILUC by December 31, 2010, based on the best available scientific evidence.<ref name="EU08">{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+TA+20081217+ITEMS+DOC+XML+V0//EN&language=EN#BKMD-27| title=Texts adopted Wednesday, 17 December 2008: Monitoring and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels |author=[[European Parliament]]|date=2008-12-17 |accessdate=2009-06-09}} ''For ILUC see "Whereas" items 11 through 18''</ref><ref name="ARBproposal"/><ref name=ILUC_EU>{{cite web |url=http://biofuelsandclimate.wordpress.com/2008/12/31/europe-to-study-indirect-land-use/|title=Europe to Study Indirect Land Use |publisher=Biofuels and Climate Change |date=2008-12-31 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
In the meantime, the European Parliament defined lands that were ineligible for producing biofuel feedstocks for the purpose of the Directives. This category included [[wetland]]s and continuously [[forest]]ed areas with [[Canopy (biology)|canopy]] cover of more than 30 percent or cover between 10 and 30 percent given evidence that its existing carbon stock was low enough to justify conversion.<ref name="EU08"/>
The Commission subsequently published terms of reference for three ILUC modeling exercises: one using a General Equilibrium model;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/DG%20TRADE%20GEM.pdf|title=Annex A - Terms of Reference - The indirect land use change impact of biofuels|publisher=European Commission|date=2009-06-29|accessdate=2010-01-29}}</ref> one using a Partial Equilibrium model<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/DG%20AGRI%20PEM.pdf|title=Annex 1 - Terms of Reference|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=2010-01-29}}</ref> and one comparing other global modeling exercises.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/DG%20JRC%20model%20comparison.pdf|title=Terms of Reference - Administrative arrangement between JRC and DG ENV on Indirect Land Use Change emissions from biofuels|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=2010-01-29}}</ref> It also consulted on a limited range of high-level options for addressing ILUC<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/iluc_preparatory_consultation_doc.pdf|title= Indirect land use change – Possible elements of a policy approach – preparatory draft for stakeholder/expert comments |publisher=European Commission|accessdate=2010-01-29}}</ref> to which 17 countries<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/iluc_consultation_comments_by_country.zip|title=ILUC Consultation comments by country|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=2010-01-29}} ''Download zip file with comments from 17 countries in PDF format.''</ref> and 59 organizations responded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/iluc_consultation_comments_by_organisation.zip|title=ILUC Consultation comments by organisation|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=2010-01-29}}''Download zip file with comments from 59 organisations in PDF format.''</ref> The [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]] on the Right to Food and several environmental organizations complained that the 2008 safeguards were inadequate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/12/biofuels-and-land-grabs-in-poor-nations/ |title=Biofuels and 'Land Grabs' in Poor Nations |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |author=James Kanter |date=2009-06-12 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://assets.panda.org/downloads/eu_renewable_energy_directive_2008___summary.pdf|format=PDF |title=EU Renewable Energy Directive 2008 - Summary of WWF position |publisher=[[World Wide Fund for Nature]] |author=WWF European Policy Office |accessdate=2009-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wetlands.org/NewsandEvents/NewsPressreleases/tabid/60/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/1647/Default.aspx|title=Final Biofuel Directive limits impact on wetlands |publisher=[[Wetlands International]] |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birdlife.org/eu/EU_policy/Biofuels/eu_biofuels5.html |title=Inadequacy of the Renewable Energy Directive|publisher=[[BirdLife International]] |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> UNICA called for regulators to establish an empirical and "globally accepted methodology" to consider ILUC, with the participation of researchers and scientists from biofuel crop-producing countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.unica.com.br/noticias/show.asp?nwsCode={4236514C-4E5D-4F5F-86C6-44BE4D081B4D} |title=UNICA calls for globally harmonized methodologies to assess Indirect Land Use Change in IEA conference in Rotterdam |publisher=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]]|date=2009-05-28 |accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref>
In 2010 some [[NGO]]s accused the European Commission of lacking transparency given its reluctance to release documents relating to the ILUC work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportenvironment.org/News/2010/3/Green-groups-sue-Commission-over-withheld-biofuels-docs/ |title=Green groups sue Commission over withheld biofuels docs|publisher=Transport & Environment|date=2010-03-09|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> In March 2010 the Partial and General Equilibrium Modelling results were made available, with the disclaimer that the EC had not adopted the views contained in the materials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/energy/renewables/studies/land_use_change_en.htm|title=Renewable Energy: Studies - Land Use Change|publisher=European Energy Commission|date=2010-03-26 |accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> These indicate that a 1.25% increase in EU biofuel consumption would require around {{convert|5000000|ha}} of land globally.<ref name=EUiluc>{{cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=542|title= Biofuels and global trade study goes online|publisher=European Commission Chief Economist |date=March 2010|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
The scenarios for varied from 5.6-8.6% of road transport fuels. The study found that ILUC effects offset part of the emission benefits, and that above the 5.6% threshold, ILUC emissions increase rapidly increase.<ref name=EUilucPDF/><ref name=GCCEU/> For the expected scenario of 5.6% by 2020, the study estimated that biodiesel production increases would be mostly domestic, while bioethanol production would take place mainly in Brazil, regardless of EU duties.<ref name=EUilucPDF/> The analysis concluded that eliminating trade barriers would further reduce emissions, because the EU would import more from Brazil.<ref name=EUiluc/> Under this scenario, "''direct emission savings from biofuels are estimated at 18 Mt {{chem|CO|2}}, additional emissions from ILUC at 5.3 Mt {{chem|CO|2}} (mostly in Brazil), resulting in a global net balance of nearly 13 Mt {{chem|CO|2}} savings in a 20 years horizon.''<ref name=EUilucPDF>{{cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2010/march/tradoc_145954.pdf|title=Global Trade and Environmental Impact Study of the EU Biofuels Mandate|author=[[International Food Policy Research Institute]] (IFPRI)|publisher=Directorate General for Trade of the European Commission |date=2010-03-25|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> The study also found that ILUC emissions were much greater for biodiesel from [[vegetable oil]] and estimated that in 2020 even at the 5.6% level were over half the greenhouse gas emissions from diesel.<ref name=EUilucPDF/><ref name=GCCEU>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/03/ifpri-20100326.html|title= Analysis Finds That First-Generation Biofuel Use of Up to 5.6% in EU Road Transport Fuels Delivers Net GHG Emissions Benefits After Factoring in Indirect Land Use Change|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2010-03-26|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
As part of the announcement, the Commission stated that it would publish a report on ILUC by the end of 2010.<ref name=EC0610_2>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/10/247&format=HTML&aged=0&language=en&guiLanguage=en|title=Commission sets up system for certifying sustainable biofuels: MEMO/10/247|publisher=[[European Commission]]|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
=====Certification system===== On June 10, 2010, the EC announced its decision to set up certification schemes for biofuels, including imports as part of the Renewable Energy Directive. The Commission encouraged E.U. nations, industry and [[NGO]]s to set up voluntary certification schemes.<ref name=EC0610>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/10/711&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en|title=Commission sets up system for certifying sustainable biofuels|publisher=[[European Commission]]|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref><ref name=GCC0610>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/06/ecsust-20100610.html#more|title=European Commission Sets Up System for Certifying Sustainable Biofuels|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref> EC figures for 2007 showed that 26% of [[biodiesel]] and 31% of [[ethanol fuel|bioethanol]] used in the E.U. was imported, mainly from [[Brazil]] and the [[United States]].<ref name=BBC0610>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science_and_environment/10283258.stm|title=EU biofuels 'need to be certified for sustainability'EU biofuels 'need to be certified for sustainability'|publisher=[[BBC News]]|author=Mark Kinver|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
=====Reactions===== UNICA welcomed the EU efforts to "engage independent experts in its assessments" but requested that improvements because "... the report currently contains a certain number of inaccuracies, so once these are corrected, we anticipate even higher benefits resulting from the use of Brazilian sugarcane ethanol."<ref name=UNICAEU10>{{cite web|url=http://english.unica.com.br/releases/show.asp?rlsCode={0BBE41C2-2FD4-4D09-B088-8A112C031E43}|title=Report highlights benefits of Brazilian sugarcane ethanol, confirms highest emissions savings|publisher=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]]|date=2010-03-29|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> UNICA highlighted the fact that the report assumed land expansion that "does not take into consideration the agro-ecological zoning for sugarcane in Brazil, which prevents cane from expanding into any type of native vegetation."<ref name=UNICAEU10/>
Critics said the 10% figure was reduced to 5.6% of transport fuels partly by exaggerating the contribution of [[electric vehicle]]s (EV) in 2020, as the study assumed EVs would represent 20% of new car sales, two and six times the car industry's own estimate.<ref name=ReutersEU10/> They also claimed the study "exaggerates to around 45 percent the contribution of bioethanol—the greenest of all biofuels—and consequently downplays the worst impacts of biodiesel."<ref name=ReutersEU10>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE62O1UK.htm|title=EU report signals U-turn on biofuels target|author=[[Reuters]]|publisher=AlertNet|date=2010-0325-|accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
Environmental groups found that the measures "are too weak to halt a dramatic increase in deforestation".<ref name=BBC0610/><ref name=Greenpeace0610/> According to [[Greenpeace]], "indirect land-use change impacts of biofuel production still are not properly addressed", which for them was the most dangerous problem of biofuels<ref name=Greenpeace0610>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/eu-unit/press-centre/press-releases2/broken-biofuel-policies-still|title=Broken biofuel policies still driving rainforest destruction|publisher=[[Greenpeace]] European unit|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
Industry representatives welcomed the certification system and some dismissed concerns regarding the lack of land use criteria.<ref name=BBC0610/><ref name=NYT0610>{{cite news|url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/11/parsing-europes-new-biofuel-rules/?emc=eta1|title=Parsing Europe’s New Biofuel Rules|author=James Kanter|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=2010-06-11 |accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref><ref name=Unica0610/> UNICA and other industry groups wanted the gaps in the rules filled to provide a clear operating framework.<ref name=NYT0610/><ref name=Unica0610>{{cite web|url=http://unica.com.br/clipping/show.asp?cppCode=5C3F6D12-67A2-4614-8746-FBC406C74D38|title=Trade bodies welcome EU biofuels rules, but call for more guidance |publisher=[[UNICA, Brazil]]|author=Platts Commodity News|date=2010-06-11|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
The negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council of European Ministers continue. A deal is not foreseen before 2014<ref>http://www.vieuws.eu/energy/irish-ambassador-tom-hanney-on-ilucbiofuels/</ref>

{{Designation list | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Kizilirmak Delta | designation1_date = 15 April 1998 | designation1_number = 942<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kizilirmak Delta|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/942|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} The '''Kızılırmak Delta''' is the [[River delta|delta]] of the [[Kızılırmak River]]. It is the biggest wetland in the [[Black Sea Region]] <ref>{{cite web|title=38 Black Sea wetlands to visit|url=http://www.moew.government.bg/files/file/Nature/Natura%202000/RAMSAR/Black_Sea_Wet_Catalog-Final.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414071238/http://www.moew.government.bg/files/file/Nature/Natura%202000/RAMSAR/Black_Sea_Wet_Catalog-Final.pdf|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}}</ref> and is listed under the [[Ramsar Convention]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ramsar Sites Information Service |url=http://ramsar.wetlands.org/Database/SearchforRamsarsites/tabid/765/Default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325154909/http://ramsar.wetlands.org/Database/SearchforRamsarsites/tabid/765/Default.aspx |archivedate=2014-03-25 |df= }}</ref> as internationally important.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ramsar Sites of Turkey|url=http://www.ramsar.org/pdf/Ramsar_Sites_of_Turkey_publication_english.pdf#page=52}}</ref> All of the first and second delta plains and most of the third delta plain is dominated by agriculture.<ref>{{cite web|title=ECOSYSTEMS IN THE MIND: FUZZY COGNITIVE MAPS OF THE KIZILIRMAK DELTA WETLANDS IN TURKEY|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/q-bio/0603022v1.pdf|publisher=Erciyes University}}</ref> It is important for biodiversity of plants and birds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dogadernegi.net/our-work/wetlands/kizilirmak-delta/|title=Doğa|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414061632/http://www.dogadernegi.net/our-work/wetlands/kizilirmak-delta/|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}}</ref>. In 2016 it was inscribed in the [[List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)|Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Kızılırmak Delta Wetland and Bird Sanctuary |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6125/ |website=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Kızılırmak_Delta%2CBafra.Samsun.JPG|thumb|400px|Delta]]
==Lakes== In 2010 Liman Lake was found to be [[eutrophic]] possibly due to agricultural pollution via drainage channels.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Limnological {{Sic|Assesment|nolink=y}} on the Brakish Shallow Liman Lake from Kizilirmak Delta (Turkey)|url=http://www.medwelljournals.com/fulltext/?doi=javaa.2010.2132.2139|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415060717/http://www.medwelljournals.com/fulltext/?doi=javaa.2010.2132.2139|archivedate=2014-04-15|df=}}</ref>
==Biology==
===Birds=== [[White stork]] breed here.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Nesting habits and breeding success of the White Stork, Ciconia ciconia, in the Kızılırmak delta, Turkey|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09397140.2012.10648959#.U0wZ3I-e614 | doi=10.1080/09397140.2012.10648959}}</ref>
===Fish=== Small numbers of [[sturgeon]] have been observed in the estuary and may still attempt to migrate upstream.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.trjfas.org/pdf/issue_13_04/0420.pdf|title=Biological Data Derived from Sturgeon ( Acipenser stellatus , Acipenser gueldenstaedtii and Huso huso ) by-catch along the Coasts of the Southern Black Sea (Turkey)}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:USA National Forests Map.jpg|thumb|450px|right|alt=A map of the United States showing the locations of the National Forests and National Grasslands|Map of the National Forests and Grasslands of the United States]] The [[United States]] has 154 [[protected area]]s known as [[United States National Forest|National Forests]] covering 188,336,179 acres (762,169 km2/294,275 sq. mi). The National Forests are managed by the [[U.S. Forest Service]], an agency of the [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]].{{cite web |title=About Us – Meet the Forest Service |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/aboutus/meetfs.shtml |accessdate=October 22, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRKIXs3?url=http://www.fs.fed.us/aboutus/meetfs.shtml |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The first National Forest was established as the [[Yellowstone National Forest|Yellowstone Park Timber and Land Reserve]] on March 30, 1891, then in the [[Department of the Interior]]. In 1897, the [[Organic Act of 1897|Organic Act]] provided purposes for which forest reserves could be established, including to protect the forest, secure water supplies, and supply timber. With the [[Forest Reserve Act of 1891]], the [[President of the United States]] was given the power to set aside forest reserves in the public domain. With the [[Transfer Act of 1905]], forest reserves became part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture in the newly created U.S. Forest Service.{{Cite document |first1=Ross W. |last1=Gorte |first2=Betsy A. |last2=Cody |title=The Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management: History and Analysis of Merger Proposals |publisher=Congressional Research Service Reports for Congress |url=http://cnie.org/NLE/CRSreports/Forests/for-15.cfm |date=November 7, 1995 |accessdate=October 22, 2012 |postscript=. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRFZJS1?url=http://cnie.org/NLE/CRSreports/Forests/for-15.cfm |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} By 1907 President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] more than doubled the forest reserve acreage, and [[United States Congress|Congress]] responded by limiting the President's ability to proclaim new reserves. The National Forest System underwent a major reorganization in 1908, and in 1911 Congress authorized new additions to the system under the authority of the [[Weeks Act]]. The management goals provided by the Organic Act were expanded upon by the [[Multiple-Use Sustained-Yield Act of 1960]] to include "outdoor recreation, range, timber, watershed, and wildlife and fish purposes" as well as for the establishment of [[National Wilderness Preservation System#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. As of September 30, 2014, the Forest Service manages a total {{convert|192922127|acre|km2}}, {{convert|188336179|acre|km2}} of which are National Forests. The additional land areas include 20 [[United States National Grassland|National Grasslands]], 59 purchase units, 19 research and experimental areas, five land utilization projects and 37 other areas. The National Forest System has an extensive and complicated history of reorganization, so while there are currently 154 named National Forests, many of these are managed together as either a single forest or separate forests.{{ref label|Note1|A|A}}{{cite web |title=Find a Forest by State |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/recreation/map/state_list.shtml |accessdate=October 22, 2012}} There is at least one National Forest in all but ten states: Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Iowa, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, North Dakota, New Jersey, and Rhode Island (although Kansas and North Dakota have [[national grasslands]]). In addition, [[Puerto Rico]] contains [[El Yunque National Forest]]. Alaska has the most national forest land with 21.9 million acres (8.9 million ha), followed by California (20.8 million acres, 8.4 million ha) and Idaho (20.4 million acres, 8.3 million ha). Idaho also has the greatest percent of its land in national forests with 38.2%, followed by Oregon with 24.7% and Colorado with 20.9%. On maps, national forests in the west generally show the true extent of their area, but those in the east often only show purchase districts, within which usually only a minority of the land is owned by the Forest Service. == National Forests == {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width:98%" !scope="col" |Name{{note label|Note1|A|A}} !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Photo !scope="col" |Location{{cite web |title=U.S. Board on Geographic Names |publisher=[[U.S. Geological Survey]] |url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}}{{note label|Note1|B|B}} !scope="col" |Date formed{{Cite document |title=The National Forests of the United States |publisher=The Forest History Society |url=http://www.foresthistory.org/ASPNET/places/National%20Forests%20of%20the%20U.S.pdf |accessdate=October 14, 2012 |postscript=. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRGckIT?url=http://www.foresthistory.org/ASPNET/places/National%20Forests%20of%20the%20U.S.pdf |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{note label|Note1|C|C}} !scope="col" |Area{{Cite document |title=Land Areas of the National Forest System |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |date=November 2015 |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/LAR2015/FY2015%20LAR%20Book.pdf |accessdate=January 16, 2016 |postscript=. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6eaVJBE90?url=http://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/LAR2015/FY2015%20LAR%20Book.pdf |archivedate=January 16, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description{{note label|Note1|D|D}} |- !scope="row" | [[Allegheny National Forest|Allegheny]] |[[File:Fall at Allegheny Reservoir.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of Allegheny Reservoir in fall.]] |[[Pennsylvania]]
{{coord|41|39|N|79|01|W|name=Allegeny|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 24, 1923}} |{{convert|513655|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Pennsylvania's only National Forest includes [[Kinzua Dam]] and [[Allegheny Reservoir]] on the [[Allegheny Plateau]] in the northwestern part of the state. The forest contains the largest tract of remaining [[old-growth forest]] in Pennsylvania at [[Tionesta Scenic and Research Natural Areas]] and {{convert|10|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the [[North Country Trail]].{{cite web |title=Allegheny National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/allegheny/home |accessdate=October 14, 2012}}{{rp|255–263}} |- !scope="row" | [[Angeles National Forest|Angeles]] |[[File:Angelesnationalforest.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of the San Gabriel Mountains.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|34|24|N|118|10|W|name=Angeles|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 20, 1892}}{{cite web |title=Angeles National Forest – History & Culture |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/angeles/learning/history-culture |accessdate=September 25, 2016}} |{{convert|661565|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] at the edge of the [[Los Angeles]] metro area, this National Forest includes five [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]. While much of the forest is dense [[chaparral]], elevations in the forest range from {{convert|1200|ft|m}} to {{convert|10064|ft|m}} at the summit of [[Mount San Antonio]].{{cite web |title=Angeles National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/angeles/home |accessdate=October 14, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Angelina National Forest|Angelina]] |[[File:Angelina National Forest sign.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of a ranger station in Angelina National Forest.]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|31|13|N|94|17|W|name=Angelina|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 13, 1936}} |{{convert|154140|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Primarily [[longleaf pine|longleaf]], [[loblolly pine|loblolly]], and [[shortleaf pine|shortleaf]] pine, the forest includes two [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] and borders the [[Sam Rayburn Reservoir]]. The forest provides habitat for the endangered [[red-cockaded woodpecker]] and wintering habitat for [[bald eagle]]s.{{cite web |title=Angelina National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/texas/about-forest/districts/?cid=fswdev3_008439 |accessdate=October 14, 2012}}{{rp|303–305}} |- !scope="row" | [[Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest|Apache-Sitgreaves]] |[[File:Apache Abbas.JPG|150px|alt=A photo of the highlands from route 191 in Arizona in Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest.]] |[[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|33|44|N|109|05|W|name=Apache-Sitgreaves|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 17, 1898}} |{{convert|2626306|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Encompassing the [[Mogollon Rim]] and [[White Mountains (Arizona)|White Mountains]], this forest includes 34 lakes and over {{convert|680|mi|km}} of rivers and streams, more than any other National Forest in the arid [[Southwestern United States|Southwest]].{{cite web |title=Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/asnf |accessdate=October 14, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Apalachicola National Forest|Apalachicola]] |[[File:Apalachicola pond.JPG|150px|alt=A photo of an artificial pond off of FH-111 in Apalachicola National Forest.]] |[[Florida]]
{{coord|30|11|N|84|41|W|name=Apalachicola|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 13, 1936}} |{{convert|576119|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |As the largest National Forest in Florida, Apalachicola includes over {{convert|2700|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of water and {{convert|67|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the [[Florida Trail]]. There are caverns and sinkholes at the [[Leon Sinks Geological Area]], while [[Fort Gadsden]] is along the [[Apalachicola River]].{{cite web |title=Apalachicola National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/apalachicola |accessdate=October 14, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Arapaho National Forest|Arapaho]] |[[File:Arapaho National Forest 2010 USDAgov.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of aspens in fall along the Crooked Creek Road.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|39|41|N|105|56|W|name=Arapaho|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 24, 1903}} |{{convert|720418|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Arapaho National Forest is in the high [[Rocky Mountains|Rockies]] and includes six [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]. It is currently managed jointly with [[Roosevelt National Forest]] and [[Pawnee National Grassland]]. The highest paved road in North America ascends [[Mount Evans]] at an elevation of {{convert|14265|ft|m|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |title=Arapaho and Roosevelt National Forests and Pawnee National Grassland |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/arp/home |accessdate=October 14, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ashley National Forest|Ashley]] |[[File:Kings Peak with Henry's Fork Basin.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of King's Peak and Henry's Fork Basin.]] |[[Utah]], [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|40|38|N|110|06|W|name=Ashley|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1378424|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Ashley National Forest manages the [[Flaming Gorge National Recreation Area]] and the [[High Uintas Wilderness]]. [[Kings Peak (Utah)|Kings Peak]] at {{convert|13528|ft|m|abbr=on}} is the highest point in Utah and is located in the [[Uinta Mountains]].{{cite web |title=Ashley National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley |accessdate=October 14, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest|Beaverhead-Deerlodge]] |[[File:Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of a stream and mountains in Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|45|30|N|113|00|W|name=Beaverhead-Deerlodge|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|3362638|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The largest National Forest in Montana, it encompasses several mountain ranges of the [[Rocky Mountains]]. The forest includes the [[Anaconda-Pintler Wilderness|Anaconda-Pintler]] and [[Lee Metcalf Wilderness|Lee Metcalf]] [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] and sections of the [[Continental Divide Trail]] and [[Nez Perce National Historic Trail]].{{cite web |title=Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/bdnf |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bienville National Forest|Bienville]] |[[File:Bienville National Forest.jpeg|150px|alt=A photo of a forest sign in Bienville National Forest.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|32|16|N|89|30|W|name=Bienville|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 15, 1936}} |{{convert|180251|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in central Mississippi, this forest includes several lakes and reservoirs and [[Harrell Prairie Botanical Area|Harrell Prairie]], the largest and least disturbed prairie in the state. Bienville Pines Scenic Area includes {{convert|189|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]]. It is managed collectively with Mississippi's five other National Forests.{{rp|162–166}}{{cite web |title=National Forests in Mississippi |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mississippi/ |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bighorn National Forest|Bighorn]] |[[File:Bighorn National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=A mountain meadow in Bighorn National Forest.]] |[[Wyoming]]
{{coord|44|32|N|107|21|W|name=Bighorn|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|1105311|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Big Horn Mountains]] of north-central Wyoming, Bighorn National Forest has eight lodges, several reservoirs, and {{convert|1500|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails. Elevation reach {{convert|13167|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Cloud Peak]] in the [[Cloud Peak Wilderness]], which is also the location of the [[Cloud Peak Glacier]].{{cite web |title=Bighorn National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/bighorn |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bitterroot National Forest|Bitterroot]] |[[File:Lake Como view from Woods Cabin.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of Lake Como and mountains.]] |[[Montana]], [[Idaho]]
{{coord|45|46|N|114|17|W|name=Bitterroot|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|1594579|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Bitterroot National Forest is located in the [[Bitterroot Mountains|Bitterroot]] and [[Sapphire Mountains|Sapphire]] mountains, reaching its highest point at {{convert|10157|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Trapper Peak (Montana)|Trapper Peak]]. The forest is named for the [[bitterroot]] plant.{{rp|192–199}}{{cite web |title=Bitterroot National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/bitterroot |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Black Hills National Forest|Black Hills]] |[[File:Black Elk Wilderness South Dakota 5.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of the Black Hills in the Black Elk Wilderness with Horsethief Lake.]] |[[South Dakota]], [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|44|00|N|103|47|W|name=Black Hills|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|1250866|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Consisting predominately of [[Ponderosa pine]], this forest is located in the namesake [[Black Hills]]. There are 11 reservoirs, {{convert|353|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, and {{convert|1300|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams in this forest. [[Black Elk Peak]] is the highest point in South Dakota and the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains at {{convert|7244|ft|m|abbr=on}}.{{rp|293–301}}{{cite web |title=Black Hills National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/blackhills |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Boise National Forest|Boise]] |[[File:River Rocks (440298432).jpg|150px|alt=A photo of rocks along a river in Boise National Forest.]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|44|07|N|115|34|W|name=Boise|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|2648273|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Portions of the [[Boise River|Boise]], [[Payette River|Payette]], and South and Middle Forks of the [[Salmon River (Idaho)|Salmon River]] drainages make up the forest. There are over {{convert|7600|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams and more than 250 lakes and reservoirs in the forest.{{cite web |title=Boise National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/boise |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bridger-Teton National Forest|Bridger-Teton]] |[[File:Approaching Lozier Lakes.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of the Wind River Range approaching the Lozier Lakes.]] |[[Wyoming]]
{{coord|42|45|N|110|45|W|name=Bridger-Teton|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|3383302|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |As part of the [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem]], Bridger-Teton National Forest has 27 [[glacier]]s in its portion of the [[Wind River Range]]. The [[Gros Ventre landslide]] formed a dam on the [[Gros Ventre River]] in 1925 before failing in 1927.{{cite web |title=Bridger-Teton National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/btnf |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Caribou-Targhee National Forest|Caribou-Targhee]] |[[File:Mesa Falls 4.JPG|150px|alt=A photo of Upper Mesa Falls.]] |[[Idaho]], [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|41|57|N|112|08|W|name=Caribou-Targhee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 23, 1905}} |{{convert|2624739|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The forest's [[Jedediah Smith Wilderness]] has many caves and the [[Winegar Hole Wilderness]] protects [[grizzly bear]] habitat in the [[Greater Yellowstone ecosystem]]. The [[Upper Mesa Falls|Upper]] and [[Lower Mesa Falls]] are on [[Henrys Fork (Snake River)|Henrys Fork]] of the [[Snake River]] and tours of [[Minnetonka Cave]] are available.{{cite web |title=Caribou-Targhee National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/ctnf |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Carson National Forest|Carson]] |[[File:Wheeler from Walter.JPG|150px|alt=A photo of Wheeler Peak from Mount Walter.]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|36|30|N|106|04|W|name=Carson|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 7, 1906}} |{{convert|1390885|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Sangre de Cristo Mountains]], this forest has over {{convert|330|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and [[Taos Ski Valley, New Mexico|Taos Ski Valley]]. The highest point in the forest is [[Wheeler Peak (New Mexico)|Wheeler Peak]], also New Mexico's highest point, at {{convert|13161|ft|m|abbr=on}}.{{rp|246–253}}{{cite web |title=Carson National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/carson |accessdate=October 16, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest|Chattahoochee-Oconee]] |[[File:Raven Cliffs Trail.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of a waterfall along the Raven Cliffs Trail.]] |[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
{{coord|34|45|N|84|07|W|name=Chattahoochee-Oconee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 9, 1936}} |{{convert|866763|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |With {{convert|430|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, this forest contains the southern terminius of the [[Appalachian Trail]]. Georgia's highest point, [[Brasstown Bald]] at {{convert|4784|ft|m|abbr=on}} is in the forest, and several [[American Civil War|Civil War]] battles were fought in the area.{{rp|56–70}}{{cite web |title=Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/conf |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forest|Chequamegon-Nicolet]] |[[File:BlackjackSpringsWilderness.jpg|150px|alt=A photo of a lake and coniferous forests.]] |[[Wisconsin]]
{{coord|46|02|N|90|48|W|name=Chequamegon-Nicolet|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1933}} |{{convert|1523704|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are 2,020 lakes, 440 spring ponds, and {{convert|347000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of wetlands in this National Forest. There are also {{convert|493|mi|km|abbr=on}} of non-motorized trails, {{convert|292|mi|km|abbr=on}} of motorized trails, and {{convert|9000|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads alongside five [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]].{{cite web |title=Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/cnnf |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Cherokee National Forest|Cherokee]] |[[File:South Fork Citico Creek.jpg|150px|alt=South Fork of Citico Creek in the Citico Creek Wilderness.]] |[[Tennessee]], [[North Carolina]]
{{coord|35|52|N|83|03|W|name=Cherokee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 14, 1920}} |{{convert|656394|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Cherokee National Forest has eleven [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], three large lakes, and over {{convert|600|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, including {{convert|150|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the [[Appalachian Trail]] in the [[Great Smoky Mountains]]. There are 43 mammal species, 154 fish species, 55 amphibian species, and 262 bird species in the forest.{{cite web |title=Cherokee National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/cherokee |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chippewa National Forest|Chippewa]] |[[File:Chippewa National Forest - Social - 2.jpg|150px|alt=A trail]] |[[Minnesota]]
{{coord|47|24|N|94|08|W|name=Chippewa|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 23, 1908}} |{{convert|671952|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |With 1,300 lakes and ponds, {{convert|925|mi|km|abbr=on}} of rivers, and {{convert|440000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of wetlands, there are many opportunities for boating and fishing in this forest. There are over 180 nesting pairs of [[bald eagle]]s as well as [[Canada lynx]], and [[sandhill crane]]s here.{{rp|144–150}}{{cite web |title=Chippewa National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/chippewa |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chugach National Forest|Chugach]] |[[File:Lost Lake, Seward, Alaska.jpg|150px|alt=Lost Lake and mountains.]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|60|28|N|149|07|W|name=Chugach|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 23, 1907}} |{{convert|5419095|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |As the third largest National Forest, Chugach covers three unique landscapes: the [[Copper River (Alaska)|Copper River Delta]], [[Kenai Peninsula|Eastern Kenai Peninsula]], and [[Prince William Sound]]. Many of the streams contain [[salmon]] and [[trout]], and glaciers still carve the land here. Over half of the forest is [[tundra]] and [[glacier]]s.{{cite web |title=Chugach National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/chugach/ |accessdate=October 17, 2012}}{{rp|2–9}} |- !scope="row" | [[Cibola National Forest|Cibola]] |[[File:Ridge from the Sandia Crest Trail.jpg|150px|alt=View of a ridge from the Sandia Crest Trail.]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|34|20|N|107|35|W|name=Cibola|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 6, 1906}} |{{convert|1616435|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Part of this National Forest are four [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], including the [[Sandia Mountain Wilderness]] east of [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]]. Elevations range from {{convert|5000|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|11301|ft|m|abbr=on}} at the summit of [[Mount Taylor (New Mexico)|Mount Taylor]], a [[stratovolcano]] in the [[San Mateo Mountains (Cibola County, New Mexico)|San Mateo Mountains]].{{rp|253–265}}{{cite web |title=Cibola National Forest and National Grasslands |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/cibola |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Clearwater National Forest|Clearwater]] |[[File:Lochsa River in Clearwater NF.jpg|150px|alt=The Lochsa River.]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|46|33|N|115|09|W|name=Clearwater|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1682068|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The forest covers the [[Bitterroot Mountains]] and [[Palouse|Palouse Prairie]] as well as the [[Clearwater River (Idaho)|Clearwater]] and [[Lochsa River|Lochsa]] rivers. The [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] followed the Lolo Trail through the forest in 1805, and gold miners came to the forest in the 1860s.{{rp|168–173}}{{cite web |title=Clearwater National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r1/clearwater/ |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Cleveland National Forest|Cleveland]] |[[File:Mountlagunasmall.jpg|150px|alt=Cleveland National Forest near Mount Laguna.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|32|45|N|116|36|W|name=Cleveland|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 25, 1893}} |{{convert|425580|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In southern California, Cleveland National Forest has a [[Mediterranean climate]] and four [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]. There are 22 endangered plant and animal species found in the forest. With its highest point at {{convert|6271|ft|m|abbr=on}} on Monument Peak, elevations are not as high here as in most of California's other National Forests.{{rp|81–84}}{{cite web |title=Cleveland National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/cleveland |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Coconino National Forest|Coconino]] |[[File:Sycamore Canyon from Barney Pasture.jpg|150px|alt=Sycamore Canyon viewed from Barney Pasture.]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|34|45|N|111|33|W|name=Coconino|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 17, 1898}} |{{convert|1852201|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The [[San Francisco Peaks]], [[Mogollon Rim]], and [[Oak Creek Canyon]] can be found in Coconino National Forest. The forest's [[Sycamore Canyon]] is the second largest canyon in Arizona's redrock country. The forest also contains [[Humphreys Peak]], which at {{convert|12637|ft|m|abbr=on}} is the highest point in Arizona.{{rp|28–37}}{{cite web |title=Coconino National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/coconino |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Colville National Forest|Colville]] |[[File:Colville National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Colville National Forest with a lake and mountains.]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48|32|N|117|54|W|name=Colville|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 1, 1907}} |{{convert|954668|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |With {{convert|486|mi|km|abbr=on}} of hiking trails, Colville National Forest has elevations that range up to {{convert|7300|ft|m|abbr=on}} in the [[Kettle River Range|Kettle River]] and [[Selkirk Mountains|Selkirk]] mountains. Part of the [[Salmo-Priest Wilderness]] is in the forest along with part of the [[Pacific Northwest National Scenic Trail]].{{cite web |title=Colville National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/colville |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Conecuh National Forest|Conecuh]] |[[File:Open pond, conecuh national forest, alabama.jpg|150px|alt=Open Pond and pine trees.]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|31|05|N|86|38|W|name=Conecuh|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 17, 1936}} |{{convert|83983|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Managed together with Alabama's other National Forests, Conecuh has two areas designated for recreation: Blue Lake and Open Pond. The dry, sandy uplands support [[longleaf pine]] forest, while bottomlands have [[sinkhole]] ponds, springs, and swamps.{{rp|2–8}}{{cite web |title=National Forests of Alabama |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/alabama |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Coronado National Forest|Coronado]] |[[File:Coronado Natl Forest Nima1.JPG|150px|alt=Mountains and forest west of Paradise, Arizona.]] |[[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|32|30|N|110|40|W|name=Coronado|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 11, 1902}} |{{convert|1718945|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Covering the [[sky island]]s of the [[Southwestern United States|Southwest]], Coronado National Forest also includes [[Mount Wrightson]] and the birding destination of [[Madera Canyon]]. There are eight [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] in the forest as well as observatories on [[Mount Hopkins (Arizona)|Mount Hopkins]] and [[Mount Lemmon]]{{cite web |title=Coronado National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/coronado |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Croatan National Forest|Croatan]] |[[File:Lake Croatan Natl Forest 3970.jpg|150px|alt=Swamp along the Patsy Pond Nature Trail.]] |[[North Carolina]]
{{coord|34|52|N|77|00|W|name=Croatan|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 29, 1936}} |{{convert|161325|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The only coastal National Forest on the east coast, Croatan includes [[Estuary|estuaries]] and [[pocosin]]s. The forest is home to carnivorous plants such as the [[Venus flytrap]] and [[pitcher plant]]. Cedar Point is a recreation area at the mouth of the [[White Oak River]].{{rp|214–222}}{{cite web |title=National Forests in North Carolina |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/nfsnc |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Custer National Forest|Custer]] |[[File:Granite Peak Montana.jpg|150px|alt=A mountain goat below Granite Peak.]] |[[Montana]], [[South Dakota]]
{{coord|45|30|N|106|00|W|name=Custer|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1907}} |{{convert|1189465|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Custer National Forest includes the [[Beartooth Highway]] and the Capitol Rock and the Castles National Natural Landmarks. The forest's [[Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness]] includes [[Granite Peak (Montana)|Granite Peak]], the highest point in Montana at {{convert|12807|ft|m|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |title=Custer National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/custer |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Daniel Boone National Forest|Daniel Boone]] |[[File:Daniel Boone National Forest Tater Knob.jpg|150px|alt=The forest viewed from Tater Knob.]] |[[Kentucky]]
{{coord|37|17|N|83|52|W|name=Daniel Boone|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 23, 1937}} |{{convert|564168|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Encompassing part of the [[Cumberland Plateau]] and [[Appalachian Mountains]], Daniel Boone National Forest has two wilderness areas and several reservoirs. Scenic areas include [[Cumberland Falls]], [[Red River Gorge]], [[Yahoo Arch]] and many caves.{{cite web |title=Daniel Boone National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/dbnf |accessdate=October 18, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Davy Crockett National Forest|Davy Crockett]] |[[File:Ratcliff Lake, Ratcliff, TX IMG 0985.JPG|150px|alt=Ratcliff Lake.]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|31|18|N|95|06|W|name=Davy Crockett|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 13, 1936}} |{{convert|161140|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located where the southeastern pine forests meet the blackland prairies of central Texas, Davy Crockett National Forest's Big Slough Wilderness consists primarily hardwood forest. A recreation area surrounds Ratcliff Lake, which covers {{convert|45|acre|ha|abbr=on}}.{{rp|310–312}}{{cite web |title=National Forests of Texas |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/texas |accessdate=October 18, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Delta National Forest|Delta]] |[[File:Delta NF Sunflower WMA.jpg|150px|alt=A sign for Sunflower Wildlife Management Area in Delta National Forest.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|32|45|N|90|46|W|name=Delta|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 12, 1961}} |{{convert|62109|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Delta National Forest contains the only [[bottomland hardwood forest]] in the National Forest System, located in the floodplain of the [[Mississippi River]]. The forest includes the Green Ash-Overcup Oak-Sweetgum Research Natural Areas, which is a [[National Natural Landmark]] because it contains remnant bottomland [[old-growth forest]].{{rp|167–172}}{{cite web |title=Green Ash-Overcup Oak-Sweetgum Research Natural Areas |publisher=National Park Service |url=http://nature.nps.gov/nnl/site.cfm?Site=GRAS-MS |accessdate=October 19, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRS9wVn?url=http://nature.nps.gov/nnl/site.cfm?Site=GRAS-MS |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Deschutes National Forest|Deschutes]] |[[File:Lava Lake (Oregon).jpg|150px|alt=View to the northeast across Lava Lake with three volcanic mountains in the background: South Sister, Broken Top, and Mount Bachelor.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|43|50|N|121|32|W|name=Deschutes|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1612218|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |On the east side of the [[Cascade Range]], Deschutes National Forest includes [[Newberry National Volcanic Monument]] and five [[Deschutes National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. [[Lava River Cave]], at {{convert|5211|ft|m|abbr=on}} long, is Oregon's longest [[lava tube]].{{cite web |title=Deschutes & Ochoco National Forests & Crooked River National Grassland |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/centraloregon |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[De Soto National Forest|De Soto]] |[[File:DeSotoNationalForest.jpg|150px|alt=Pine forest in De Soto.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|31|02|N|88|59|W|name=De Soto|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 17, 1936}} |{{convert|532100|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |De Soto National Forest contains Mississippi's only wilderness areas: [[Black Creek Wilderness|Black Creek]] and Leaf River. The Black Creek and Tuxachanie [[National Recreation Trail]]s provide {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on}} of hiking opportunities.
