Black Creek has been designated a [[National Wild and Scenic Rivers System|National Wild and Scenic River]] for {{convert|21|mi|km|abbr=on}}.{{rp|173–178}} |- !scope="row" | [[Dixie National Forest|Dixie]] |[[File:RedRockUtah.jpg|150px|alt=Scenic Byway 12 in Red Canyon.]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|38|15|N|111|30|W|name=Dixie|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 25, 1905}} |{{convert|1885655|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Straddling the divide between the [[Great Basin]] and [[Colorado River]], Dixie National Forest has elevations ranging from {{convert|2800|ft|m|abbr=on}} near [[St. George, Utah|St. George]] to {{convert|11322|ft|m|abbr=on}} on [[Boulder Mountain (Utah)|Boulder Mountain]]. [[Ashdown Gorge Wilderness|Ashdown Gorge]], [[Box-Death Hollow Wilderness|Box-Death Hollow]], [[Cottonwood Forest Wilderness|Cottonwood Forest]], and [[Pine Valley Mountain Wilderness|Pine Valley Mountain]] wilderness areas are in the forest.{{cite web |title=Dixie National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/dixie |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Eldorado National Forest|Eldorado]] |[[File:Eldorado NF - trail to Winnemucca Lake.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains and forest along the trail to Winnemucca Lake.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|38|47|N|120|19|W|name=Eldorado|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 28, 1910}} |{{convert|695098|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], Eldorado National Forest has {{convert|611|mi|km|abbr=on}} of fishable streams and 297 lakes and reservoirs. There are {{convert|349|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and {{convert|2367|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads in the forest. The forest's [[Desolation Wilderness]] is the most visited [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]] per acre in the country.{{rp|84–88}}{{cite web |title=Eldorado National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/eldorado |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[El Yunque National Forest|El Yunque]] |[[File:El Yunque National Forest, Puerto Rico by Geoff Gallice - 001.jpg|150px|alt=Forested mountainsides in El Yunque.]] |[[Puerto Rico]]
{{coord|18|17|N|65|48|W|name=El Yunque|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 17, 1903}} |{{convert|28683|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The only [[tropical rainforest]] in the National Forest System, higher elevations of El Yunque National Forest receive nearly {{convert|200|in|cm|abbr=on}} of rainfall per year. There are 240 tree species in the forest, 23 of which are [[Endemism|endemic]] to the forest, being found nowhere else in the world.{{cite web |title=El Yunque National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/elyunque/about-forest |accessdate=October 19, 2012}}{{cite document |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |title=El Yunque National Forest |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/fsbdev3_042861.pdf |accessdate=August 17, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IxBoRERu?url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/fsbdev3_042861.pdf |archivedate=August 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Finger Lakes National Forest|Finger Lakes]] |[[File:Finger Lakes National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Overlooking the hills, forest, and surrounding area in Finger Lakes National Forest.]] |[[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|42|31|N|76|47|W|name=Finger Lakes|type:landmark}} |{{dts|1983}} |{{convert|16352|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located between [[Seneca Lake (New York)|Seneca]] and [[Cayuga Lake|Cayuga]] lakes, Finger Lakes National Forest is one of the smallest National Forests. The Gorge Trail enters a small gorge in the forest, and the [[North Country Trail]] crosses part of the forest.{{rp|209–212}}{{cite web |title=Finger Lakes National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/fingerlakes |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Fishlake National Forest|Fishlake]] |[[File:AspenOverview0172.JPG|150px|alt=Aspens during fall in the mountains of the Richfield Ranger District.]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|38|42|N|111|57|W|name=Fishlake|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 10, 1899}} |{{convert|1452969|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in south central Utah, Fishlake National Forest is named for [[Fish Lake (Utah)|Fish Lake]], the state's largest natural mountain lake. The forest's [[Tushar Mountains]] reach their highest point at {{convert|12174|ft|m|abbr=on}} on [[Delano Peak]].{{rp|284–288}}{{cite web |title=Fishlake National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Flathead National Forest|Flathead]] |[[File:Big Salmon Lake.jpg|150px|alt=Big Salmon Lake and the Bob Marshall Wilderness.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|48|01|N|113|48|W|name=Flathead|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|2413573|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Bordering [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]], Flathead is home to [[grizzly bear]]s, [[bull trout]], and [[Canada lynx]]. The forest manages four [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], including the [[Bob Marshall Wilderness|Bob Marshall]] and [[Great Bear Wilderness|Great Bear]] wildernesses.{{rp|203–208}}{{cite web |title=Flathead National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/flathead/ |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Francis Marion National Forest|Francis Marion]] |[[File:Francis Marion NF1.jpg|150px|alt=A trail through pine forest.]] |[[South Carolina]]
{{coord|33|10|N|79|42|W|name=Francis Marion|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 10, 1936}} |{{convert|258673|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Francis Marion National Forest is home to {{convert|150|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams and a variety of wildlife, including the endangered [[red-cockaded woodpecker]]. There are four [[Francis Marion National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] in the forest, and it is managed together with [[Sumter National Forest]].{{rp|282–289}}{{cite web |title=Francis Marion and Sumter National Forests |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/scnfs |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Fremont-Winema National Forest|Fremont-Winema]] |[[File:Mount Thielsen aerial.jpg|150px|alt=An aerial view of Mount Thielson.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|42|34|N|120|52|W|name=Fremont-Winema|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 17, 1906}} |{{convert|2253796|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Encompassing the [[Warner Mountains]] and bordering [[Crater Lake National Park]], Fremont-Winema National Forest also includes the semi-arid areas of the [[Oregon Outback]]. The [[Gearhart Mountain Wilderness]] is near the center of the forest.{{rp|217–220}}{{cite web |title=Fremont-Winema National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/fremont-winema |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Gallatin National Forest|Gallatin]] |[[File:Daisy Pass Gallatin National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains around Daisy Pass.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|45|15|N|111|00|W|name=Gallatin|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 10, 1899}} |{{convert|1849701|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Bordering the north side of [[Yellowstone National Park]], Gallatin National Forest contains parts of both the [[Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness|Absaroka-Beartooth]] and [[Lee Metcalf Wilderness|Lee Metcalf]] wilderness areas. [[Quake Lake]] was formed on the [[Madison River]] when an earthquake launched a landslide across the river in 1959.{{cite web |title=Gallatin National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/gallatin |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[George Washington and Jefferson National Forests|George Washington & Jefferson]] |[[File:White Rocks Little Sluice Mountain GWNF.jpg|150px|alt=Forested mountains viewed from the White Rocks on Little Sluice Mountain.]] |[[Virginia]], [[West Virginia]], [[Kentucky]]
{{coord|38|12|N|79|21|W|name=George Washington & Jefferson|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 16, 1918}} |{{convert|1792209|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Appalachian Mountains]], the highest point of the forest is [[Mount Rogers]], also the highest point in Virginia at {{convert|5729|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Mount Rogers National Recreation Area]]. There are {{convert|230000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]] here, and the [[Blue Ridge Parkway]] and [[Appalachian Trail]] both run through the forest.{{cite web |title=George Washington and Jefferson National Forests |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/gwj |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Gifford Pinchot National Forest|Gifford Pinchot]] |[[File:OldSnowy 15A.JPG|150px|alt=Partially snow-covered Old Snowy Mountain.]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|46|10|N|121|48|W|name=Gifford Pinchot|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1312274|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Gifford Pinchot National Forest includes [[Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument]] and parts of seven [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]. There are {{convert|1475|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and {{convert|4104|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads in the forest.{{cite web |title=Gifford Pinchot National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/giffordpinchot |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Gila National Forest|Gila]] |[[File:Gila National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains and valleys in Gila National Forest.]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|33|17|N|108|20|W|name=Gila|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1899}} |{{convert|2658321|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The forest's [[Gila Wilderness]] was the world's first [[wilderness area]] and was proclaimed on June 3, 1924. The Catwalk National Recreation Trail travels up a narrow canyon for {{convert|1.1|mi|km|abbr=on}} while following Whitewater Creek.{{cite web |title=Gila National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/gila/ |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Grand Mesa National Forest|Grand Mesa]] |[[File:West edge of Grand Mesa, Colorado.jpg|150px|alt=The northwestern edge of Grand Mesa from the south.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|39|05|N|107|54|W|name=Grand Mesa|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|345939|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In western Colorado, Grand Mesa National Forest covers part of [[Battlement Mesa]] and most of [[Grand Mesa]], the largest flattop mountain in the world with an average elevation of {{convert|10500|ft|m|abbr=on}}. There are over 300 lakes in the forest. It is managed together with [[Gunnison National Forest]] and [[Uncompahgre National Forest]].{{rp|49–56}}{{cite web |title=Grand Mesa Uncompahgre and Gunnison National Forests |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/gmug |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Green Mountain National Forest|Green Mountain]] |[[File:Hapgood Pond - Flickr - USDAgov.jpg|150px|alt=Trees in fall along a road near the Hapgood Pond Recreation Area.]] |[[Vermont]]
{{coord|43|18|N|73|00|W|name=Green Mountain|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 25, 1932}} |{{convert|408419|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In Vermont's [[Green Mountains]], this forest includes eight [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]. Among the {{convert|900|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest are the [[Appalachian Trail]] and two [[National Recreation Trail]]s: [[Long Trail|Long]] and Robert Frost.{{cite web |title=Green Mountain National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/greenmountain |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Gunnison National Forest|Gunnison]] |[[File:Copper Lake Trail, Crested Butte.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains in spring along the Copper Lake Trail near Crested Butte.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|38|41|N|106|41|W|name=Gunnison|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 12, 1905}} |{{convert|1666514|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Gunnison National Forest is located in the [[Rocky Mountains]] near [[Gunnison, Colorado]]. Among the seven [[Gunnison National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] in the forest are the [[Maroon Bells-Snowmass Wilderness]]. The Slumgullion Slide is a giant landslide due to the mineral [[montmorillonite]].{{rp|56–67}} |- !scope="row" | [[Helena National Forest|Helena]] |[[File:York-Trout Creek Bridge on the Missouri River in Helena National Forrest-750px.JPG|150px|alt=The York-Trout Creek Bridge over the Missouri River below mountains in Helena National Forest.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|46|33|N|112|12|W|name=Helena|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 12, 1906}} |{{convert|982385|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The [[Continental Divide Trail]] travels almost {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} through the forest, which surrounds Montana's capital city. The [[Elkhorn Mountains]] are the only Wildlife Management unit in the National Forest System.{{cite web |title=Helena National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/helena/ |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Hiawatha National Forest|Hiawatha]] |[[File:Hiawatha National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=A forest sign along road M-28 in Hiawatha National Forest.]] |[[Michigan]]
{{coord|46|10|N|86|40|W|name=Hiawatha|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 16, 1931}} |{{convert|898475|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in Michigan's [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan|Upper Peninsula]], Hiawatha National Forest borders [[Lake Superior]], [[Lake Michigan]], and [[Lake Huron]]. The forest is home to [[Grand Island National Recreation Area]] and five [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]].{{cite web |title=Hiawatha National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/hiawatha |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Holly Springs National Forest|Holly Springs]] |[[File:Provisional Head of Navigation of Wolf River.jpg|150px|alt=A cypress swamp in Holly Springs National Forest.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|34|34|N|89|18|W|name=Holly Springs|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 15, 1936}} |{{convert|156243|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In north-central Mississippi, Holly Springs National Forest has small lakes in upland forests and unique bottomlands. Chewalla and Puskus recreation areas surround the namesake lakes and have boat launches.{{rp|178–180}} |- !scope="row" | [[Homochitto National Forest|Homochitto]] |[[File:Homochitto National Forest sign.jpeg|150px|alt=A sign for Homochitto National Forest.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|31|26|N|90|56|W|name=Homochitto|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 20, 1936}} |{{convert|192237|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in southern Mississippi, this forest is named for the [[Homochitto River]], meaning "Big Red River." Most of the forest is densely forested hills, but there are recreation facilities at Pipes Lake, Clear Springs, and Mount Nebo.{{rp|180–186}} |- !scope="row" | [[Hoosier National Forest|Hoosier]] |[[File:Hoosier National Forest.png|150px|alt=A hazy fall day over the hills in Hoosier National Forest.]] |[[Indiana]]
{{coord|38|31|N|86|31|W|name=Hoosier|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 1, 1961}} |{{convert|203627|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The Pioneer Mothers Memorial Forest is {{convert|88|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]] in Hoosier National Forest. The forest's [[Charles C. Deam Wilderness Area|Charles C. Deam Wilderness]] is Indiana's only [[wilderness area]].{{cite web |title=Hoosier National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url= http://www.fs.usda.gov/hoosier |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest|Humboldt-Toiyabe]] |[[File:20111018-FS- SE-0009 - Flickr - USDAgov.jpg|150px|alt=Aspen in Lamoille Canyon surrounded by mountains.]] |[[Nevada]], [[California]]
{{coord|40|23|N|115|33|W|name=Humboldt-Toiyabe|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 3, 1906}} |{{convert|6290945|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |As the largest National Forest outside of Alaska, Humboldt-Toiyabe occupies many of the mountains of Nevada's [[Basin and Range Province]]. [[Spring Mountains National Recreation Area]] is located near [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] and is part of the forest.{{cite web |title=Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url= http://www.fs.usda.gov/htnf | accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Huron-Manistee National Forests|Huron-Manistee]] |[[File:Benton Lake Manistee Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Benton Lake and surrounding forests.]] |[[Michigan]]
{{coord|44|33|N|83|52|W|name=Huron-Manistee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 30, 1928}} |{{convert|975130|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Loda Lake National Wildflower Sanctuary is located around a small spring-fed lake in the forest. The [[Nordhouse Dunes Wilderness]] has sand dunes up to {{convert|140|ft|m|abbr=on}} high along [[Lake Michigan]].{{cite web |title=Huron-Manistee National Forests |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url= http://www.fs.usda.gov/hmnf |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Idaho Panhandle National Forest|Idaho Panhandle]]
[[Coeur d'Alene National Forest|Coeur d'Alene]], [[St. Joe National Forest|St. Joe]], [[Kaniksu National Forest|Kaniksu]] |[[File:RevettLake.jpg|150px|alt=Revett Lake and surrounding mountains and forests from above.]] |[[Idaho]], [[Montana]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|47|43|N|116|13|W|name=Idaho Panhandle|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 6, 1906}} |{{convert|3074438|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are two [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], [[Cabinet Mountains Wilderness|Cabinet Mountains]] and [[Salmo-Priest Wilderness|Salmo-Priest]], and numerous recreation opportunities in Idaho Panhandle National Forest. This forest ranges from the Canada–US border to the [[Saint Joe River]], which is the highest navigable river in the world.{{rp|173–179}}{{cite web |title=Idaho Panhandle National Forests |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/ipnf/ |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Inyo National Forest|Inyo]] |[[File:Mount Whitney September 2009.JPG|150px|alt=Mount Whitney from the Whitney Portal Trailhead.]] |[[California]], [[Nevada]]
{{coord|37|30|N|118|39|W|name=Inyo|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 25, 1907}} |{{convert|1957264|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], Inyo includes [[Mono Lake]], [[bristlecone pine]]s, the [[Long Valley Caldera]], nine [[Inyo National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]], and [[Mount Whitney]], which at {{convert|14505|ft|m|abbr=on}} is the highest point in the United States outside of Alaska.{{cite web |title=Inyo National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/inyo/ |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kaibab National Forest|Kaibab]] |[[File:NKRD Aspen.jpg|150px|alt=Aspens and a meadow in fall.]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|35|56|N|112|09|W|name=Kaibab|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1561060|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located on the [[Colorado Plateau]] to both the north and south of [[Grand Canyon National Park]], elevations in Kaibab National Forest reach {{convert|10418|ft|m|abbr=on}} on Kendrick Mountain in the [[Kendrick Mountain Wilderness]]. There are over {{convert|300|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest, including through the [[Kanab Creek Wilderness]].{{cite web |title=Kaibab National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/kaibab |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kisatchie National Forest|Kisatchie]] |[[File:Kisatchie Bayou.jpg|150px|alt=The Kisatchie Bayou.]] |[[Louisiana]]
{{coord|31|00|N|92|37|W|name=Kisatchie|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 10, 1930}} |{{convert|607540|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Kisatchie is Louisiana's only National Forest, covering [[old-growth forest|old-growth]] pine forest and [[bald cypress]] groves in the bayous. There are 48 mammal species, 56 reptiles, 30 amphibians, and 155 breeding or overwintering birds in this forest.{{cite web |title=Kisatchie National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/kisatchie |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Klamath National Forest|Klamath]] |[[File:Klamath National Forest-16N05 March 05.jpg|150px|alt=A road through the forest.]] |[[California]], [[Oregon]]
{{coord|41|30|N|123|08|W|name=Klamath|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 6, 1905}} |{{convert|1672442|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Straddling the California-Oregon border, this forest has part of five [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], {{convert|152|mi|km|abbr=on}} of [[National Wild and Scenic Rivers System|wild and scenic rivers]], and {{convert|200|mi|km|abbr=on}} of rivers for rafting, including on the [[Klamath River]].The [[Calochortus persistens|Siskiyou mariposa lily]] is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the forest, being found nowhere else in the world.{{cite web |title=Klamath National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/klamath |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kootenai National Forest|Kootenai]] |[[File:Kootenai National Forest.JPG|150px|alt=Snow-capped mountains in Kootenai National Forest.]] |[[Montana]], [[Idaho]]
{{coord|48|32|N|115|26|W|name=Kootenai|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 13, 1906}} |{{convert|1810361|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Kootenai includes the [[Cabinet Mountains]] and the [[Kootenai River|Kootenai]] and [[Clark Fork (river)|Clark Fork]] rivers. The [[Noxon Rapids Dam|Noxon]] and [[Cabinet Gorge Dam|Cabinet Gorge]] reservoirs are on the Clark Fork within the forest. The Northwest Peak Scenic Area is in the [[Selkirk Mountains]].{{rp|222–226}}{{cite web |title=Kootenai National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/kootenai/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit]] |[[File:Lake_Tahoe_NV.jpg|150px|alt=Lake Tahoe.]] |[[California]], [[Nevada]]
{{coord|38|55|N|119|58|W|name=Lake Tahoe Basin|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 1973}} |{{convert|152008|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The Forest Service lands surrounding [[Lake Tahoe]] are managed by the Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit, which was created in April 1973 in order to protect the lake's unique ecological and recreational values.{{cite web |title=Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ltbmu/about-forest |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb5371192.pdf |title=Land and Resource Management Plan: Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit |publisher=United States Forest Service |accessdate=October 2, 2013}}{{note label|Note1|E|E}} |- |[[Land Between the Lakes National Recreation Area|Land Between The Lakes]] |[[File:Scenic lake2.jpg|150px|Scenic lake2]] |[[Kentucky]], [[Tennessee]]
{{coord|36|46|39|N|88|3|47|W|name=Land Between The Lakes|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 1963}} |{{convert|171251|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Land Between The Lakes National Recreation area is located in Western [[Kentucky]] and [[Tennessee]], and encompasses over 170,000 acres of forests, wetlands, and open lands on the largest inland peninsula in the United States. It is located between [[Kentucky Lake]] and [[Lake Barkley]].{{Cite web|title = Overview - Land Between The Lakes National Recreation Area|url = http://www.landbetweenthelakes.us/about/overview/|accessdate = 2015-09-02}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lassen National Forest|Lassen]] |[[File:Echo Lake.jpg|150px|alt=Echo Lake.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|40|05|N|121|14|W|name=Lassen|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 2, 1905}} |{{convert|1066027|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Surrounding [[Lassen Volcanic National Park]], this forest has three [[Lassen National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] and {{convert|92000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest|old-growth]] [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mixed conifer forests. Subway Cave is a [[lava tube]] that is {{convert|0.3|mi|km|abbr=on}} long and open to the public.{{cite web |title=Lassen National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/lassen |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lewis and Clark National Forest|Lewis and Clark]] |[[File:Riding in Lewis and Clark National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=A riding ranger with mules near the Chinese Wall.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|46|55|N|110|38|W|name=Lewis and Clark|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|1871490|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in north-central Montana, this forest includes seven mountain ranges and large portions of the [[Bob Marshall Wilderness|Bob Marshall]] and [[Scapegoat Wilderness|Scapegoat]] wilderness areas. The forest operates the Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center in [[Great Falls, Montana|Great Falls]].{{cite web |title=Lewis and Clark National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/lcnf |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lincoln National Forest|Lincoln]] |[[File:Terrain.JPG|150px|alt=Partially forested mountains in Lincoln National Forest.]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|32|57|N|105|26|W|name=Lincoln|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 26, 1902}} |{{convert|1095470|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |With portions of four mountain ranges, the [[Capitan Mountains|Capitan]], [[Guadalupe Mountains|Guadalupe]], [[Sacramento Mountains|Sacramento]], and [[Sierra Blanca (New Mexico)|Sierra Blanca]] mountains, elevations range from {{convert|4000|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|11500|ft|m|abbr=on}} in Lincoln National Forest. The forest was the birthplace of [[Smokey Bear]].{{cite web |title=Lincoln National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/lincoln |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lolo National Forest|Lolo]] |[[File:Rainy Lake in Lolo National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Rainy Lake and mountains.]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|47|09|N|114|26|W|name=Lolo|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 20, 1906}} |{{convert|2237961|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located west of the [[Continental Divide]] and containing parts of four [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], this forest has {{convert|700|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and over 100 named lakes. There are at least 20 fish species, 60 mammals, 300 birds, and 1,500 plants in the forest.{{cite web |title=Lolo National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/lolo |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Los Padres National Forest|Los Padres]] |[[File:Chaparral1.jpg|150px|alt=Montane chaparral and mountains.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|34|32|N|119|46|W|name=Los Padres|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1898}} |{{convert|1772237|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Encompassing portions of the [[California Coast Ranges|California Coast]] and [[Transverse Ranges|Transverse]] ranges of central California, Los Padres has ten [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] covering about 48% of the forest. There are {{convert|1257|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and part of the Jacinto Reyes National Scenic Byway.{{cite web |title=Los Padres National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/lpnf/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Malheur National Forest|Malheur]] |[[File:Strawberry Lake Wilderness.jpg|150px|alt=Strawberry Lake and mountains in fall.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|44|15|N|118|51|W|name=Malheur|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1480818|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Blue Mountains (Oregon)|Blue Mountains]] of eastern Oregon, Malheur National Forest's highest point is [[Strawberry Mountain (Oregon)|Strawberry Mountain]] at {{convert|9038|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The Cedar Grove Botanical Area contains the only stand of [[Cupressus nootkatensis|Alaska yellow cedar]] east of the [[Cascade Range]] in the United States.{{cite web |title=Malheur National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/malheur |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Manti-La Sal National Forest|Manti-La Sal]] |[[File:Mount Peale north face.jpg|150px|alt=Mount Peale viewed from Mount Mellenthin.]] |[[Utah]], [[Colorado]]
{{coord|38|23|N|109|01|W|name=Manti-La Sal|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 29, 1903}} |{{convert|1269984|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Including the [[La Sal Range|La Sal]] and [[Abajo Mountains|Abajo]] mountains of eastern Utah, elevations in this forest reach {{convert|12721|ft|m|abbr=on}} on [[Mount Peale]]. The [[Dark Canyon Wilderness]] is the only [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]] in the forest.{{rp|288–298}}{{cite web |title=Manti-La Sal National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mark Twain National Forest|Mark Twain]] |[[File:St. Francis River at Silver Mines Recreation Area 2.jpg|150px|alt=A kayaker on the St. Francis River.]] |[[Missouri]]
{{coord|37|00|N|91|30|W|name=Mark Twain|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 11, 1939}} |{{convert|1504881|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Missouri's only National Forest, Mark Twain contains seven [[Mark Twain National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] and the [[Eleven Point National Wild and Scenic River]]. There are 19 natural areas in the forest that are managed by the [[Missouri Department of Conservation]].{{cite web |title=Mark Twain National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mtnf |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Medicine Bow – Routt National Forest|Medicine Bow – Routt]] |[[File:Esterbrook Medicine Bow NF.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains and grasslands surrounding a work center.]] |[[Colorado]], [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|41|14|N|106|15|W|name=Medicine Bow — Routt|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 22, 1902}} |{{convert|2210327|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This forest contains many ranges of the [[Rocky Mountains]] with elevations ranging from {{convert|5500|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|12940|ft|m|abbr=on}}. There are ten [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] and Rob Roy Reservoir, which covers {{convert|500|acre|ha|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |title=Medicine Bow-Routt National Forest & Thunder Basin National Grassland |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mbr |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mendocino National Forest|Mendocino]] |[[File:Howard Lake and Anthony Peak.jpg|150px|alt=Howard Lake and forested mountains.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|39|38|N|122|51|W|name=Mendocino|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|915532|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Mendocino is the only National Forest in California not crossed by a paved highway. The forest's Genetic Resource and Conservation Center produces plants for reforestation, watershed restoration, wildlife recovery, and other projects.{{cite web |title=Mendocino National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mendocino/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Modoc National Forest|Modoc]] |[[File:Modoc National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=The summit trail and surrounding mountains.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|41|34|N|120|53|W|name=Modoc|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 29, 1904}} |{{convert|1680405|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Modoc National Forest contains the [[Medicine Lake Volcano]], which has an elevation of {{convert|7921|ft|m|abbr=on}} and is the largest [[shield volcano]] in North America. There are {{convert|43400|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]] here along with Mill Creek Falls in the [[South Warner Wilderness]].{{cite web |title=Modoc National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/modoc |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Monongahela National Forest|Monongahela]] |[[File:Senecarock - West Virginia - ForestWander.jpg|150px|alt=Seneca Rock.]] |[[West Virginia]]
{{coord|38|33|N|79|54|W|name=Monongahela|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 28, 1920}} |{{convert|920583|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Monongahela National Forest includes [[Spruce Knob-Seneca Rocks National Recreation Area]] and eight [[Monongahela National Forest#U.S. Wilderness Areas|wilderness areas]]. [[Spruce Knob]] is the highest point in West Virginia at {{convert|4863|ft|m|abbr=on}}, and [[Seneca Rocks]] is a {{convert|900|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[quartzite]] [[cliff|crag]].{{cite web |title=Monongahela National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mnf |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest|Mount Baker-Snoqualmie]] |[[File:Sunrise Lake Washington.jpg|150px|alt=Table Mountain and its reflection in a lake.]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48|28|N|121|25|W|name=Mount Baker-Snoqualmie|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|2562955|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In the [[Cascade Range]], this forest includes [[Mount Baker]], at an elevation of {{convert|10781|ft|m|abbr=on}}, a glaciated [[stratovolcano]]. [[Mount Baker National Recreation Area]], the [[Pacific Crest Trail]], [[Pacific Northwest National Scenic Trail]], and portions of ten [[Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest#Conservation|wilderness areas]] are in the forest.{{cite web |title=Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mbs |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mount Hood National Forest|Mount Hood]] |[[File:Mount Hood reflected in Mirror Lake, Oregon.jpg|150px|alt=Mount Hood and its reflection in Mirror Lake.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|45|16|N|121|49|W|name=Mount Hood|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 17, 1892}} |{{convert|1069427|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This forest is named for and contains [[Mount Hood]], the highest point in Oregon at {{convert|11249|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The forest stretches from the [[Columbia River Gorge]] and includes [[Mount Hood National Recreation Area]] and nine [[Mount Hood National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness areas]].{{cite web |title=Mt. Hood National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/mthood |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Nantahala National Forest|Nantahala]] |[[File:Dry Falls Nantahala NF.jpg|150px|alt=Dry Falls.]] |[[North Carolina]]
{{coord|35|12|N|83|33|W|name=Nantahala|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 6, 1907}} |{{convert|532300|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In southwestern North Carolina, this forest includes the Nantahala Gorge and [[Nantahala River]]. There are {{convert|600|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest with elevations ranging from {{convert|1200|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|5800|ft|m|abbr=on}} on Lone Bald. |- !scope="row" | [[Nebraska National Forest|Nebraska]] |[[File:Nebraska National Forest, Bessey Ranger District, no. 5.jpg|150px|alt=Forest and grasslands in the Bessey Ranger District.]] |[[Nebraska]]
{{coord|41|42|N|100|22|W|name=Nebraska|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 16, 1902}} |{{convert|140813|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This forest was created in 1902 by [[Charles E. Bessey]] as an experiment to see if a forest could be created in treeless areas of the [[Great Plains]] for use as a national timber reserve. The Bessey Nursery is located in the northwest corner of the forest's Bessey Ranger District.{{rp|240–242}}{{cite web |title=Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/nebraska |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Nez Perce National Forest|Nez Perce]] |[[File:Crooked Creek in Gospel Hump Wilderness.jpg|150px|alt=Crooked Creek in fall.]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|45|27|N|115|55|W|name=Nez Perce|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|2223586|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Nez Perce National Forest includes parts of four wilderness areas: [[Frank Church—River of No Return Wilderness|Frank Church-River of No Return]], [[Gospel Hump Wilderness|Gospel Hump]], [[Hells Canyon Wilderness (Oregon and Idaho)|Hells Canyon]], and [[Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness|Selway-Bietterroot]]. This forest is managed together with [[Clearwater National Forest]].{{cite web |title=Nez Perce National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/nezperceclearwater |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ocala National Forest|Ocala]] |[[File:Farles Prairie.jpg|150px|alt=A pond in Farles Prairie.]] |[[Florida]]
{{coord|29|12|N|81|44|W|name=Ocala|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 24, 1908}} |{{convert|384693|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Ocala protects the world's largest [[Pinus clausa|sand pine]] scrub forest. There are more than 600 lakes, rivers, and springs in the forest along with four [[Ocala National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. There are over 600 lakes and part of the [[Florida Trail]] in the forest.{{rp|34–37}}{{cite web |title=Ocala National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/ocala |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ochoco National Forest|Ochoco]] |[[File:Steins Pillar.jpg|150px|alt=Steins Pillar.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|44|22|N|120|07|W|name=Ochoco|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1911}} |{{convert|854817|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Ochoco National Forest contains a variety of odd geological formations, {{convert|95000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]], the headwaters of the [[Crooked River (Oregon)|Crooked River]], and three [[Ochoco National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness areas]]. Stein's Pillar is a {{convert|350|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall rock column in the [[Ochoco Mountains]].{{rp|227–229}} |- !scope="row" | [[Okanogan National Forest|Okanogan]]-[[Wenatchee National Forest|Wenatchee]] |[[File:View from Maple Pass.jpg|150px|alt=A lake and the surrounding mountains and forest viewed from Maple Pass.]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48|38|N|119|35|W|name=Okanogan-Wenatchee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1911}} |{{convert|1501826|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located on the eastern side of the [[Cascade Range]], this forest stretches from the Canada–US border to the [[Columbia River|Columbia]] and [[Okanogan River|Okanogan]] rivers. There are {{convert|1285|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest, including part of the [[Pacific Crest Trail]].{{rp|329–332}}{{cite web |title=Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest | publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/okawen |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Olympic National Forest|Olympic]] |[[File:Olympic NF from Hurricane Ridge.jpg|150px|alt=Forests and the Olympic Mountains from Hurricane Ridge.]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48|07|N|124|15|W|name=Olympic|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|631808|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Olympic National Forest surrounds [[Olympic National Park]] on the [[Olympic Peninsula]] of Washington. There are five [[Olympic National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]], occupying about 14% of the forest. This part of Washington receives more rainfall annually than anywhere else in the United States.{{rp|332–338}}{{cite web |title=Olympic National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/olympic/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Osceola National Forest|Osceola]] |[[File:Pinus palustris forest, Osceola National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Pine forest with palmetto understory.]] |[[Florida]]
{{coord|30|19|N|82|27|W|name=Osceola|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 10, 1931}} |{{convert|160192|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The [[Big Gum Swamp Wilderness]] is the forest's only [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]], and the Osceola Research Natural Area was designated a National Natural Landmark in 1974. The [[American Civil War|Civil War]] [[Battle of Olustee]] occurred in what is now the forest, and {{convert|23|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the [[Florida National Scenic Trail]] pass through the forest.{{cite web |title=Osceola National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/osceola |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ottawa National Forest|Ottawa]] |[[File:Pinus strobus Syvania.jpg|150px|alt=Pines along Kathryn Lake.]] |[[Michigan]]
{{coord|46|27|N|89|15|W|name=Ottawa|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 27, 1931}} |{{convert|990961|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan]], Ottawa National Forest stretches from [[Lake Superior]] to the [[Wisconsin]] border. There are 500 named lakes, nearly {{convert|2000|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams, and three [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] in the forest.{{cite web |title=Ottawa National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/ottawa |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ouachita National Forest|Ouachita]] |[[File:Ouachitanationalforestpicture.jpg|150px|alt=The view across Ouachita National Forest from atop the Standing Stairs Mountains.]] |[[Arkansas]], [[Oklahoma]]
{{coord|34|38|N|94|04|W|name=Ouachita|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 18, 1907}} |{{convert|1785468|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Including the namesake [[Ouachita Mountains]], this forest has nearly {{convert|800000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]]. The forest has two [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]]: [[Black Fork Mountain Wilderness|Black Fork Mountain]] and [[Upper Kiamichi River Wilderness|Upper Kiamichi River]].{{cite web |title=Ouachita National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/ouachita |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ozark-St. Francis National Forest|Ozark-St. Francis]] |[[File:Scenic Lookout on White Rock Mountain.jpg|150px|alt=View of the Ozarks from atop White Rock Mountain.]] |[[Arkansas]]
{{coord|35|42|N|93|21|W|name=Ozark-St. Francis|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 5, 1908}} |{{convert|1153374|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Ozark-St. Francis National Forest has more than {{convert|400|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, including the [[Ozark Highlands Trail]]. [[Blanchard Springs Caverns]] is a three level cave system that is open for public tours.{{cite web |title=Ozark-St. Francis National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/osfnf/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Payette National Forest|Payette]] |[[File:Seven Devils.jpg|150px|alt=The Seven Devils Mountains in winter.]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|45|05|N|115|48|W|name=Payette|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 3, 1905}} |{{convert|2326779|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Payette National Forest includes the [[Seven Devils Mountains]] and part of the [[Frank Church—River of No Return Wilderness]]. It also borders [[Hells Canyon]] to the west and contains the [[Brundage Mountain]] ski area.{{rp|183–187}}{{cite web |title=Payette National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/payette/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pike National Forest|Pike]] |[[File:Pike National Forest (1).jpg|150px|alt=A lake and mountains in Pike National Forest.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|39|10|N|105|27|W|name=Pike|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 11, 1892}} |{{convert|1096146|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Pike National Forest includes [[Pikes Peak]] at an elevation of {{convert|14115|ft|m|abbr=on}} and three [[Pike National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. Since 1975 the forest has been managed together with [[San Isabel National Forest]].{{cite web |title=Pike and San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Comanche National Grasslands |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/psicc |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pisgah National Forest|Pisgah]] |[[File:Upper Creek-27527-4.jpg|150px|alt=Upper Creek Falls.]] |[[North Carolina]]
{{coord|35|48|N|82|20|W|name=Pisgah|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 17, 1916}} |{{convert|509283|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Elevations in Pisgah National Forest reach over {{convert|6000|ft|m|abbr=on}}, and there are {{convert|46600|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]]s, including {{convert|10000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} in [[Linville Gorge]]. There are three [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] in the forest: [[Linville Gorge Wilderness|Linville Gorge]], [[Middle Prong Wilderness|Middle Prong]], and [[Shining Rock Wilderness|Shining Rock]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Plumas National Forest|Plumas]] |[[File:Bucks Lake.jpg|150px|alt=Bucks Lake.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|39|56|N|120|49|W|name=Plumas|type:landmark_region:US-CA}} |{{dts|March 27, 1905}} |{{convert|1189554|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are {{convert|127000|acre|ha|abbr=on}} of [[old-growth forest]] in Plumas National Forest.{{Cite document |last1=Warbington |first1=Ralph |last2=Beardsley |first2=Debby |year=2002 |title=2002 Estimates of Old Growth Forests on the 18 National Forests of the Pacific Southwest Region |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r5/rsl/publications/oldgrowth/oldgrowth2002.html |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |accessdate=October 20, 2012 |postscript=. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRTgVkv?url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r5/rsl/publications/oldgrowth/oldgrowth2002.html |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The Little Grass Valley Recreation Area surrounds [[Little Grass Valley Reservoir]] and includes a campground and boat launch, among other facilities and services.{{cite web |title=Plumas National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/plumas/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Prescott National Forest|Prescott]] |[[File:Prescott Natl Forest Nima5.JPG|150px|alt=A lake near Mingus Mountain.]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|34|35|N|112|36|W|name=Prescott|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 10, 1898}} |{{convert|1257005|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Vegetation in Prescott National Forest ranges from that characteristic of the [[Sonoran Desert]] at lower elevations to [[Ponderosa pine]] at higher elevations. There are eight [[Prescott National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness areas]] and {{convert|450|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest{{cite web |title=Prescott National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/prescott/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Rio Grande National Forest|Rio Grande]] |[[File:Stony Pass road (better), Colo.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains along the Stony Pass Road.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|37|43|N|106|37|W|name=Rio Grande|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1837661|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The headwaters of the [[Rio Grande]] are in the [[San Juan Mountains]] in the western part of the forest, while the [[Sangre de Cristo Mountains]] form the eastern boundary. Elevations reach {{convert|14345|ft|m|abbr=on}} at the summit of [[Blanca Peak]], overlooking the [[San Luis Valley]] and [[Great Sand Dunes National Park]].{{cite web |title=Rio Grande National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/riogrande |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Rogue River – Siskiyou National Forest|Rogue River-Siskiyou]] |[[File:Preston southface.jpg|150px|alt=Preston Peak in winter.]] |[[Oregon]], [[California]]
{{coord|41|58|N|123|08|W|name=Rogue River-Siskiyou|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 28, 1893}} |{{convert|1718893|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This forest ranges from the [[Cascade Range]] to the [[Siskiyou Mountains]], and the [[Rogue River (Oregon)|Rogue River]] drains over 75% of the forest's area. There are parts of eight [[Rogue River – Siskiyou National Forest#Protected areas|wilderness areas]] in the forest as well as what may be the world's tallest pine tree, a [[ponderosa pine]] that is {{convert|268.35|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall.{{cite web |title=Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/rogue-siskiyou |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110123/NEWS/101230353/ |title=Tallest of the tall |date=January 23, 2011 |first=Paul |last=Fattig |newspaper=Mail Tribune |location=Medford, Oregon |accessdate=October 20, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EaRW5c8c?url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20110123%2FNEWS%2F101230353%2F |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Roosevelt National Forest|Roosevelt]] |[[File:Lake Isabelle, Roosevelt National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains surrounding Lake Isabelle.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|40|32|N|105|35|W|name=Roosevelt|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 22, 1902}} |{{convert|814090|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Rocky Mountains]] of northern Colorado, Roosevelt National Forest has part of six [[Roosevelt National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. It is managed together with [[Arapaho National Forest]] and [[Pawnee National Grassland]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Sabine National Forest|Sabine]] |[[File:Sabine National Forest sign.jpg|150px|alt=A sign for Sabine National Forest.]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|31|30|N|93|52|W|name=Sabine|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 13, 1936}} |{{convert|161088|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sabine National Forest borders the western side of [[Toledo Bend Reservoir]] and has {{convert|28|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails. The forest's only [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]] is the Indian Mounds Wilderness. [[Old-growth forest]] can be found in the wilderness and at Mill Creek Cove along the reservoir's shores.{{rp|312–316}} |- !scope="row" | [[Salmon-Challis National Forest|Salmon-Challis]] |[[File:Borah Peak winter.jpg|150px|alt=Borah Peak and the Lost River Range in winter.]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|45|07|N|114|09|W|name=Salmon-Challis|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|4226973|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Salmon-Challis National Forest includes parts of both the [[Salmon River (Idaho)|Salmon River]] and the [[Frank Church—River of No Return Wilderness]]. Idaho's highest point, [[Borah Peak]] at {{convert|12662|ft|m|abbr=on}}, is located in the [[Lost River Range]] in the forest.{{cite web |title=Salmon-Challis National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/scnf/ |accessdate=October 20, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sam Houston National Forest|Sam Houston]] |[[File:Swamp in Sam Houston NF.jpg|150px|alt=A hardwood swamp.]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|30|32|N|95|21|W|name=Sam Houston|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 13, 1936}} |{{convert|163264|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Part of the Lone Star Trail travels through Sam Houston National Forest, which borders parts of [[Lake Conroe]] and [[Lake Livingston]]. The Little Lake Creek Wilderness is the only [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]] in the forest. |- !scope="row" | [[Samuel R. McKelvie National Forest|Samuel R. McKelvie]] |[[File:McKelvieScene lg.jpg|150px|alt=Grassland approaching the forest edge.]] |[[Nebraska]]
{{coord|42|43|N|101|02|W|name=Sameul R. McKelvie|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 15, 1971}} |{{convert|115847|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Sandhills (Nebraska)|Sandhills]] of Nebraska, Samuel R. McKelvie National Forest is a combination of prairie and trees planted since 1903, of which [[ponderosa pine]] has been most successful.{{rp|243–244}} |- !scope="row" | [[San Bernardino National Forest|San Bernardino]] |[[File:Mount Baldy from Silverwood lake.jpg|150px|alt=Mount Baldy viewed from Silverwood Lake.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|34|03|N|116|57|W|name=San Bernardino|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 25, 1893}} |{{convert|678980|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |San Bernardino National Forest includes part of the [[Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument]]. The forest surrounds [[Lake Arrowhead Reservoir|Lake Arrowhead]] and other reservoirs.{{cite web |title=San Bernardino National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/sbnf/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[San Isabel National Forest|San Isabel]] |[[File:San Isabel Natl Forest Nima.JPG|150px|alt=A valley in the mountains of San Isabel National Forest.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|38|24|N|105|56|W|name=San Isabel|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 11, 1902}} |{{convert|1108639|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are 19 of Colorado's 54 [[fourteeners]] in San Isabel National Forest, including the highest point, [[Mount Elbert]] at {{convert|14440|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The forest includes the [[Sawatch Range]], [[Collegiate Peaks]], and [[Sangre de Cristo Range]] and is managed together with [[Pike National Forest]]. |- !scope="row" | [[San Juan National Forest|San Juan]] |[[File:San Juan National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains in San Juan National Forest.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|37|30|N|107|39|W|name=San Juan|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 3, 1905}} |{{convert|1864595|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |San Juan National Forest includes [[Chimney Rock National Monument]] and elevations that range from {{convert|5000|ft|m|abbr=on}} to over {{convert|14000|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The forest's [[Weminuche Wilderness]] is the largest in Colorado at {{convert|499771|acre|ha|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |title=San Juan National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/sanjuan |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Santa Fe National Forest|Santa Fe]] |[[File:Santa Fe NF Fall.jpg|150px|alt=Aspens and snow-capped mountains in late fall.]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35|54|N|106|13|W|name=Santa Fe|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 11, 1892}} |{{convert|1544748|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Santa Fe National Forest's highest point is [[Truchas Peak]] at {{convert|13103|ft|m|abbr=on}} in the [[Pecos Wilderness]]. There are {{convert|1002|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest, which includes the [[Valles Caldera National Preserve]].{{cite web |title=Santa Fe National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/santafe/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sawtooth National Forest|Sawtooth]] |[[File:Stanley Lake.JPG|150px|alt=Stanley Lake and McGown Peak.]] |[[Idaho]], [[Utah]]
{{coord|41|54|N|113|29|W|name=Sawtooth|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 29, 1905}} |{{convert|1802133|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sawtooth National Forest includes over 1,100 lakes, {{convert|1000|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and roads, and ten mountain ranges, with the highest point at {{convert|12009|ft|m|abbr=on}} on [[Hyndman Peak]]. The forest includes [[Sawtooth National Recreation Area]], the [[Sawtooth Range (Idaho)|Sawtooth Range]], [[Sawtooth Wilderness]], four ski areas, and four [[Endemism|endemic]] species, being found nowhere else in the world.{{cite web |title=Sawtooth National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/sawtooth |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sequoia National Forest|Sequoia]] |[[File:Alder creek CA giant Sequoias.jpg|150px|alt=Giant sequoias.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|36|03|N|118|31|W|name=Sequoia|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1139240|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sequoia National Forest includes [[Giant Sequoia National Monument]], both named for the [[Sequoiadendron giganteum|giant sequoia]], the largest tree species in the world. There are {{convert|2500|mi|km|abbr=on}} of maintained and abandoned roads and {{convert|850|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails in the forest, including the [[Pacific Crest Trail]].{{cite web |title=Sequoia National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r5/sequoia/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Shasta-Trinity National Forest|Shasta-Trinity]] |[[File:Trinity Alps near Granite Lake.jpg|150px|alt=The Trinity Alps near Granite Lake.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|41|08|N|122|12|W|name=Shasta-Trinity|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 26, 1905}} |{{convert|2229286|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are {{convert|6278|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams in the forest, and elevations range from {{convert|1000|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|14179|ft|m|abbr=on}} on [[Mount Shasta]]. Five [[Shasta-Trinity National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] and {{convert|460|mi|abbr=on}} of trails can be found in the forest.{{cite web |title=Shasta-Trinity National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/stnf/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Shawnee National Forest|Shawnee]] |[[File:Garden of the Gods Sunset.jpg|150px|alt=The Garden of the Gods at sunset.]] |[[Illinois]]
{{coord|37|30|N|88|48|W|name=Shawnee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 6, 1939}} |{{convert|273482|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |As Illinois's only National Forest, Shawnee is located in the southern part of the state and contains seven [[Shawnee National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]], including the [[Garden of the Gods Wilderness|Garden of the Gods]]. Among the many miles of hiking trails in the forest is the [[River to River Trail]], which is {{convert|160|mi|km|abbr=on}} long.{{cite web |title=Shawnee National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/shawnee/home |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Shoshone National Forest|Shoshone]] |[[File:Pingora Peak and Lonesome Lake.jpg|150px|alt=Pingora Peak and Lonesome Lake.]] |[[Wyoming]]
{{coord|44|02|N|109|32|W|name=Shoshone|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 30, 1891}} |{{convert|2439093|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem]], this forest includes part of the [[Absaroka Range|Absaroka]], [[Beartooth Mountains|Beartooth]], and [[Wind River Range|Wind River]] mountain ranges. Five [[Shoshone National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness areas]] make up 56% of the forest, and elevations reach {{convert|13804|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Gannett Peak]], the highest point in Wyoming.{{cite web |title=Shoshone National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/shoshone |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sierra National Forest|Sierra]] |[[File:Lake of the Lone Indian JMW.jpg|150px|alt=Lake of the Lone Indian and surrounding mountains.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|37|16|N|119|12|W|name=Sierra|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 14, 1893}} |{{convert|1311231|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sierra National Forest is located on the western slope of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] and elevations reach {{convert|13986|ft|m|abbr=on}}. There are {{convert|1800|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams, 480 lakes, 11 reservoirs, and 63 campgrounds in the forest.{{rp|137–143}}{{cite web |title=Sierra National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/sierra/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Siuslaw National Forest|Siuslaw]] |[[File:USA Oregon Dunes.jpg|150px|alt=Sand dunes at Oregon Dune National Recreation Area.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|44|32|N|123|53|W|name=Siuslaw|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|630291|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Siuslaw National Forest includes [[Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area]], three [[Siuslaw National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]], and Cascade Head Scenic Research Area among the [[Central Oregon Coast Range]]. Marys Peak Scenic Botanical Area includes [[Marys Peak]], which at {{convert|4097|ft|m|abbr=on}} is the forest's highest point.{{cite web |title=Siuslaw National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/siuslaw |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Six Rivers National Forest|Six Rivers]] |[[File:Spring Snowmelt on the Salmon River.jpg|150px|alt=The Salmon River during spring.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|40|21|N|123|36|W|name=Six Rivers|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1947}} |{{convert|977090|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Six Rivers National Forest was named for the [[Smith River (California)|Smith]], [[Klamath River|Klamath]], [[Trinity River (California)|Trinity]], [[Mad River (California)|Mad]], [[Van Duzen River|Van Duzen]], and [[Eel River (California)|Eel]] rivers. The forest includes the [[Salmon River (California)|Salmon River]] system, all of which has been designated a [[National Wild and Scenic Rivers System|National Wild and Scenic River]].{{cite web |title=Six Rivers National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/srnf/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Stanislaus National Forest|Stanislaus]] |[[File:Cherry Lake Stanislaus National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=Cherry Lake and the surrounding forest.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|38|10|N|120|01|W|name=Stanislaus|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|899427|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Stanislaus National Forest has over {{convert|800|mi|km|abbr=on}} of streams and four [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]], including the [[Carson-Iceberg Wilderness]]. The [[Emigrant Wilderness]] borders the northwest corner of [[Yosemite National Park]].{{rp|147–150}}{{cite web |title=Stanislaus National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url= http://www.fs.usda.gov/stanislaus/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sumter National Forest|Sumter]] |[[File:Ellicott Rock Wilderness July 2007.jpg|150px|alt=A sign at the border of the Ellicott Rock Wilderness.]] |[[South Carolina]]
{{coord|34|00|N|82|15|W|name=Sumter|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 13, 1936}} |{{convert|372778|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sumter National Forest contains 22 waterfalls with drops ranging from {{convert|12|ft|m|abbr=on}} to {{convert|150|ft|m|abbr=on}} and part of the [[Ellicott Rock Wilderness]], the only wilderness located in three states. |- !scope="row" | [[Superior National Forest|Superior]] |[[File:View from Eagle Mountain Minnesota.jpg|150px|alt=The view over the forest from Eagle Mountain.]] |[[Minnesota]]
{{coord|47|50|N|91|31|W|name=Superior|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 13, 1909}} |{{convert|2092767|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Superior National Forest includes the [[Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness]], which has over {{convert|1500|mi|km|abbr=on}} of canoe routes, 1,000 lakes, and 2,200 designated campsites. [[Eagle Mountain (Minnesota)|Eagle Mountain]], the highest point in Minnesota at {{convert|2301|ft|m|abbr=on}}, is also in the forest.{{cite web |title=Superior National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url= http://www.fs.usda.gov/superior |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tahoe National Forest|Tahoe]] |[[File:Tahoe NF Meadow.jpg|150px|alt=A meadow with wildflowers.]] |[[California]]
{{coord|39|23|N|120|32|W|name=Tahoe|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 13, 1899}} |{{convert|872981|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Tahoe National Forest is in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] northwest of [[Lake Tahoe]]. Part of the [[Granite Chief Wilderness]] is within the forest. The Middle Fork of the [[American River|American]], [[Yuba River|Yuba]], and [[North Yuba River|North Yuba]] rivers cross or border the forest.{{rp|151–156}}{{cite web |title=Tahoe National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/tahoe/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Talladega National Forest|Talladega]] |[[File:Cheaha Lake in the Fall.jpg|150px|alt=Cheaha Lake at the base of Mount Cheaha from above.]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|33|26|N|85|51|W|name=Talladega|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 17, 1936}} |{{convert|393006|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Talladega National Forest includes the [[Cheaha Wilderness|Cheaha]] and [[Dugger Mountain Wilderness|Dugger Mountain]] wilderness areas. The Talladega Scenic Byway and Pinhoti National Recreation Trail cross the forest. Talladega is managed together with Alabama's other National Forests.{{rp|8–11}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tombigbee National Forest|Tombigbee]] |[[File:Lakeside trail lg.jpg|150px|alt=The Lakeside Trail winding around Choctaw Lake.]] |[[Mississippi]]
{{coord|33|56|N|88|56|W|name=Tombigbee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 27, 1959}} |{{convert|67468|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in northeastern Mississippi, Tombigbee National Forest covers rolling hills that were abandoned farmland before the forest was established. It is managed together with Mississippi's other National Forests. |- !scope="row" | [[Tongass National Forest|Tongass]] |[[File:Tongass National Forest 4.jpg|150px|alt=Mountains and water in Tongass National Forest.]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|56|48|N|133|54|W|name=Tongass|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 10, 1907}} |{{convert|16748360|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The largest National Forest, Tongass spans {{convert|500|mi|km|abbr=on}} in southeast Alaska from the Canada–US border to the [[Pacific Ocean]]. Nearly one-third of the forest is covered by 19 [[Tongass National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. The forest includes [[Misty Fiords National Monument|Misty Fiords]] and [[Admiralty Island National Monument|Admiralty Island]] National Monuments.{{cite web |title=Tongass National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/tongass/ |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tonto National Forest|Tonto]] |[[File:Desert Foliage And Canyon In Arizona.jpg|150px|alt=Tonto National Forest canyons from above.]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|33|52|N|111|17|W|name=Tonto|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 3, 1905}} |{{convert|2866663|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Tonto National Forest stretches from the [[Sonoran Desert]] to the pine forests at the [[Mogollon Rim]]. There are eight [[Tonto National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]] and several [[Tonto National Forest#Lakes, rivers and streams|lakes and reservoirs]] in the forest{{cite web |title=Tonto National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/tonto |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tuskegee National Forest|Tuskegee]] |[[File:Tuskegee NF Trail.jpg|150px|alt=A bike along a trail in Tuskegee National Forest.]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|32|28|N|85|36|W|name=Tuskegee|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 27, 1959}} |{{convert|11349|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Tuskegee National Forest's Bartram National Recreation Trail was Alabama's first [[National Recreation Trail]]. Tuskegee is one of the smallest National Forests and is managed together with Alabama's other National Forests. |- !scope="row" | [[Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest|Uinta-Wasatch-Cache]] |[[File:Uinta-national-forest-banner02.jpg|150px|alt=Aspens below mountains in fall.]] |[[Utah]], [[Wyoming]], [[Idaho]]
{{coord|41|15|N|111|26|W|name=Uinta-Wasatch-Cache|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 1897}} |{{convert|2492404|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are nine [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness areas]] in the forest, which occupies part of the [[Wasatch Range|Wasatch]] and [[Uinta Mountains|Uinta]] mountains. [[Mount Nebo (Utah)|Mount Nebo]] and [[Mount Timpanogos]] are located in wilderness areas at the edge of the Wasatch Front.{{rp|302–309}}{{cite web |title=Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Umatilla National Forest|Umatilla]] |[[File:Oregon Butte.jpg|150px|alt=A trail atop Oregon Butte.]] |[[Oregon]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|45|38|N|118|11|W|name=Umatilla|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1908}} |{{convert|1405898|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located in the [[Blue Mountains (Oregon)|Blue Mountains]] of northeastern Oregon, Umatilla National Forest includes three [[Umatilla National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness areas]], occupying over 20% of the forest. The forest has over {{convert|715|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, {{convert|2000|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads, and one of the largest [[elk]] herds of any National Forest.{{cite web |title=Umatilla National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/umatilla |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Umpqua National Forest|Umpqua]] |[[File:Calapooya Mountains, Umpqua National Forest, Oregon.jpg|150px|alt=The Calapooya Mountains from Fairview Peak Lookout.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|43|13|N|122|35|W|name=Umpqua|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1907}} |{{convert|986120|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Umpqua National Forest is in the [[Cascade Range]] of southwestern Oregon and includes three [[Umpqua National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. [[Watson Falls]] is a waterfall that is {{convert|272|ft|m|abbr=on}} high on Watson Creek, a tributary of the [[Clearwater River (Oregon)|Clearwater River]].{{cite web |title=Umpqua National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/umpqua |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Uncompahgre National Forest|Uncompahgre]] |[[File:Wetterhorn peak.jpg|150px|alt=Wetterhorn Peak.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|38|16|N|108|07|W|name=Uncompahgre|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 14, 1905}} |{{convert|951767|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The northern portion of the [[San Juan Mountains]] and the [[Uncompahgre Plateau]] are located in this National Forest. The forest also contains [[Uncompahgre Gorge]] and three [[Uncompahgre National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Uwharrie National Forest|Uwharrie]] |[[File:Uwharrie National Forest.jpg|150px|alt=A pond in Uwharrie National Forest.]] |[[North Carolina]]
{{coord|35|24|N|79|56|W|name=Uwharrie|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 12, 1961}} |{{convert|51218|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Uwharrie National Forest borders the eastern side of [[Badin Lake]] and has one wilderness area: the [[Birkhead Mountains Wilderness]]. The forest is managed together with North Carolina's other National Forests. |- !scope="row" | [[Wallowa-Whitman National Forest|Wallowa-Whitman]] |[[File:Wallowa Mountains.jpg|150px|alt=The Wallowa Mountains.]] |[[Oregon]], [[Idaho]]
{{coord|45|13|N|117|31|W|name=Wallowa-Whitman|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 6, 1905}} |{{convert|2261480|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Wallowa-Whitman National Forest stretches from the [[Blue Mountains (Oregon)|Blue Mountains]] to the [[Snake River]]. Elevations range from {{convert|875|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Hells Canyon]], the deepest gorge in North America, to {{convert|9845|ft|m|abbr=on}} at the summit of [[Sacajawea Peak]] in the [[Eagle Cap Wilderness Area]].{{cite web |title=Wallowa-Whitman National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/wallowa-whitman |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Wayne National Forest|Wayne]] |[[File:WNF CIMG0448.JPG|150px|alt=A sign for Wayne National Forest.]] |[[Ohio]]
{{coord|39|10|N|82|25|W|name=Wayne|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 1, 1951}} |{{convert|243180|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Ohio's only National Forest, Wayne is located in the [[Appalachian Ohio|Appalachian foothills]] and has over {{convert|300|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails. The [[North Country Trail]] passes through several sections of the forest.{{cite web |title=Wayne National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/wayne |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[White Mountain National Forest|White Mountain]] |[[File:Sandwich Range.jpg|150px|alt=The Sandwich Range in winter.]] |[[New Hampshire]], [[Maine]]
{{coord|44|09|N|71|25|W|name=White Mountain|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 16, 1918}} |{{convert|761687|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This National Forest is located in the [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)|White Mountains]], which the [[Appalachian Trail]] and White Mountain Scenic Byway pass through. The forest includes [[Mount Washington (New Hampshire)|Mount Washington]], which at {{convert|6288|ft|m|abbr=on}} is the highest point in the Northeast and the location of the fastest wind speed recorded on earth, although the summit is located in a [[Mount Washington State Park|state park]].{{cite web |title=White Mountain National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/whitemountain |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[White River National Forest|White River]] |[[File:20111025-FS-SM-0002 - Flickr - USDAgov.jpg|150px|alt=The Maroon Bells and Maroon Lake in fall.]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|39|34|N|106|53|W|name=White River|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 16, 1891}} |{{convert|2287495|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |White River National Forest has eight [[White River National Forest#Wilderness areas|wilderness areas]], twelve ski resorts, four large reservoirs, {{convert|2500|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails, {{convert|1900|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads, and ten peaks higher than {{convert|14000|ft|m|abbr=on}} in elevation.{{cite web |title=White River National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/whiteriver |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[Willamette National Forest|Willamette]] |[[File:Breitenbush River in western Oregon, north of Detroit.jpg|150px|alt=The Breitenbush River.]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|44|07|N|122|11|W|name=Willamette|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1933}} |{{convert|1681674|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Willamette National Forest is in the [[Cascade Range]], stretching from [[Mount Jefferson (Oregon)|Mount Jefferson]] to [[Mount Washington (Oregon)|Mount Washington]]. About 20% of the forest is designated [[Willamette National Forest#Wilderness|wilderness]], but there are also {{convert|6000|mi|km|abbr=on}} of roads in the forest.{{cite web |title=Willamette National Forest |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/willamette |accessdate=October 21, 2012}} |- !scope="row" | [[William B. Bankhead National Forest|William B. Bankhead]] |[[File:Clear Creek Bankhead NF.jpg|150px|alt=Clear Creek.]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|34|14|N|87|20|W|name=William B. Bankhead|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 15, 1918}} |{{convert|181988|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |This forest contains {{convert|153|mi|km|abbr=on}} of trails and the [[Sipsey Wilderness]], which at {{convert|24922|acre|ha|abbr=on}} is the largest [[National Wilderness Preservation System|wilderness area]] east of the [[Mississippi River]]. It is managed together with Alabama's other National Forests. |- |} == See also == * [[List of former U.S. National Forests]] * [[United States National Grassland]] == Notes == * {{note label|Note1|A|A}}The listed National Forest names represent the current management divisions of the National Forest System. Forests that are managed separately, such as Allegheny National Forest and Monongahela National Forest, are listed as separate forests. But forests that are managed together may or may not be listed separately. Forests managed together and with hyphenated names, such as Salmon-Challis National Forest, are considered to be a single National Forest. Forests that are managed together under titles such as Grand Mesa, Uncompahgre, and Gunnison National Forests, are considered to be separate forests. National Forests listed in this column in small text are constituent National Forests managed by, but not included in the name of, the named National Forest in normal text. If you are counting to reach 154 National Forests, count hyphenated names as two forests, with the exception of Manti-La Sal, which is the official name of one forest. Uinta-Wasatch-Cache is counted as three and George Washington and Jefferson is counted as two. * {{note label|Note1|B|B}}In the case of National Forests in multiple states, the states are listed in descending order by land area of that forest contained in each state. States with the most area of that forest are listed first, while states with the least are listed last. Coordinates are those by the U.S. Board on Geographic Names, and may not be representative of the entire forest. * {{note label|Note1|C|C}}The history of the National Forest System is very complicated. Forests have been transferred between agencies, renamed, divided, consolidated, discontinued, established from parts of existing forests, had portions ceded to other forests, expanded from other lands, among various other actions. The date given represents the day: that forest was established as is, a predecessor forest with the same boundaries was established under a different name, or the earliest date of establishment of a forest that was combined in whole with another forest. *{{note label|Note1|D|D}}Forests with citations to the three books in the ''This Land '' series by Robert H. Mohlenbrock can be found in the section of the cited book that corresponds to that forest. Additional information about a particular forest can be found in this series and at each forest's website.{{cite book |first=Robert H. |last=Mohlenbrock |title=This Land: A Guide to Eastern National Forests |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley, California, USA |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-520-23984-5 |url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520239845 |accessdate=December 12, 2012}}{{cite book |first=Robert H. |last=Mohlenbrock |title=This Land: A Guide to Central National Forests |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley, California, USA |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-520-23982-1 |url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520239821|accessdate=December 12, 2012}}{{cite book |first=Robert H. |last=Mohlenbrock |title=This Land: A Guide to Western National Forests |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley, California, USA |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-520-23967-8 |url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520239678 |accessdate=December 12, 2012}} *{{note label|Note1|E|E}}The Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit (LTBMU) consists of {{convert|154830|acre|ha}} of U.S. Forest Service land in the Lake Tahoe watershed. The LTBMU was formed from existing Forest Service land that was managed by [[Eldorado National Forest|Eldorado]], [[Tahoe National Forest|Tahoe]], and [[Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest|Humboldt-Toiyabe]] national forests. Only {{convert|767|acre|ha}} of land in LTBMU is officially designated as LTBMU, and the remainder of the land is still officially designated as the three sources national forests. However, all of this land is managed separately as LTBMU, essentially making it a separate national forest. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|National Forests of the United States}} {{kml}} * [http://www.fs.fed.us/ Official '''United States Forest Service''' website] {{featured list}} [[Category:National Forests of the United States|*]] [[Category:Lists of forests in the United States|*National Forests]] [[Category:Lists of protected areas of the United States|National Forests]] [[Category:United States nature-related lists|Forests, National]] [[Category:United States geography-related lists|National Forests]]

The '''list of extinct cetaceans''' features the [[Extinction|extinct]] [[genera]] and [[species]] of the order [[Cetacea]]. The cetaceans ([[whale]]s, [[dolphin]]s and [[porpoise]]s) are descendants of land-living mammals, the [[even-toed ungulate]]s. The earliest cetaceans were still hoofed mammals. These early cetaceans became gradually better adapted for swimming than for walking on land, finally [[Evolution of cetaceans|evolving]] into fully marine cetaceans.
This list currently includes only [[fossil]] genera and species. However, the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] population of [[gray whale]]s (''Eschrichtius robustus'') became extinct in the 18th century, and the [[baiji]] (or Chinese river dolphin, ''Lipotes vexillifer'') was declared "[[functionally extinct]]" after an expedition in late 2006 failed to find any in the [[Yangtze River]].
