revision.text:
A '''solvated electron''' is a [[particle|free]] [[electron]] in (solvated in) a [[solution]], and is the smallest possible [[anion]]. Solvated electrons occur widely, although it is difficult to observe them directly since their lifetimes are so short.<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/anie.196801901|title=Formation and Properties of Solvated Electrons|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition in English|volume=7|issue=3|pages=190–203|year=1968|last1=Schindewolf|first1=U.}}</ref> The deep color of solutions of alkali metals in [[ammonia]] arises from the presence of solvated electrons: blue when dilute and copper-colored when more concentrated (> 3 molar).<ref name="c&w">{{cite book |last=Cotton |first=F.A |authorlink= |author2=G. Wilkinson |title=Advanced Inorganic Chemistry |year=1972 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons Inc |location= |isbn=978-0-471-17560-5 }}</ref> Classically, discussions of solvated electrons focus on their solutions in ammonia, which are stable for days, but solvated electrons also occur in water and other solvents -- in fact, in any solvent that mediates [[outer-sphere electron transfer]]. The real hydration energy of the solvated electron can be estimated by using the hydration energy of proton in water combined with kinetic data from pulse radiolysis experiments. The solvated electron forms an acid-base pair with [[atomic hydrogen]].
The solvated electron is responsible for a great deal of [[radiation chemistry]].
Alkali metals dissolve in liquid ammonia giving deep blue solutions which are conducting in nature. The blue colour of the solution is due to ammoniated electrons which absorb energy in the visible region of light. Alkali metals also dissolve in [[hexamethylphosphoramide]], forming blue solutions.
== Properties == Focusing on ammonia solutions, all of the alkali metals, as well as [[calcium|Ca]],<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Calcium–Ammonia|author=Edwin M. Kaiser|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Reagents for Organic Synthesis|year=2001|doi=10.1002/047084289X.rc003|chapter=Calcium-Ammonia|isbn=978-0471936237}}</ref> [[strontium|Sr]], [[barium|Ba]], [[europium|Eu]], and [[ytterbium|Yb]] (also [[magnesium|Mg]] using an electrolytic process<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0022-0728(00)00504-0|title=Solutions of solvated electrons in liquid ammonia|journal=Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry|volume=499|pages=144–151|year=2001|last1=Combellas|first1=C|last2=Kanoufi|first2=F|last3=Thiébault|first3=A}}</ref>), dissolve to give the characteristic blue solutions. Other amines, such as [[methylamine]] and [[ethylamine]], are also suitable solvents.<ref>{{Greenwood&Earnshaw2nd}}</ref>
A lithium ammonia solution at −60 °C is saturated at about 15 mol% metal (MPM). When the concentration is increased in this range [[electrical conductivity]] increases from 10<sup>−2</sup> to 10<sup>4</sup> [[ohm]]<sup>−1</sup>[[Centimetre|cm]]<sup>−1</sup> (larger than liquid [[mercury (element)|mercury]]). At around 8 MPM, a "transition to the metallic state" (TMS) takes place (also called a "metal to nonmetal transition" (MNMT)). At 4 MPM a liquid-liquid phase separation takes place: the less dense gold-color phase becomes immiscible from a more dense blue phase. Above 8 MPM the solution is bronze/gold-colored. In the same concentration range the overall [[density]] decreases by 30%.
Dilute solutions are [[paramagnetic]] and at around 0.5 MPM all electrons are [[Electron pair|paired up]] and the solution becomes [[diamagnetic]]. Several models exist to describe the spin-paired species: as an ion trimer; as an ion-triple—a cluster of two single-electron solvated-electron species in association with a cation; or as a cluster of two solvated electrons and two solvated cations.
Solvated electrons produced by dissolution of reducing metals in ammonia and amines are the anions of salts called [[electride]]s. Such salts can be isolated by the addition of [[macrocyclic]] [[ligand]]s such as [[crown ether]] and [[cryptand]]s. These ligands bind strongly the cations and prevent their re-reduction by the electron.
Its [[standard electrode potential]] value is -2.77 V.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/3583572?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Baxendale, J. H. (1964) , Radiation Res. Suppl., 114 and 139]</ref> Equivalent conductivity 177 Mho cm<sup>2</sup> is similar to that of [[hydroxide ion]]. This value of equivalent conductivity corresponds to a diffusivity of 4,75*10<sup>−5</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>Survey of Progress in Chemistry p 148</ref>
Some thermodynamic properties of the solvated electron have been investigated by Jortner and Noyes (1966)<ref>J. Phys. Chem., 1966, 70 (3), pp 770–774 doi: 10.1021/j100875a026 [https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/j100875a026]</ref>
Alkaline aqueous solutions above pH = 9.6 regenerate the hydrated electron through the reaction of hydrated atomic hydrogen with [[hydroxide]] ion giving water beside hydrated electrons.
Below pH = 9.6 the hydrated electron reacts with [[hydronium ion]] giving atomic hydrogen, which in turn can react with the hydrated electron giving hydroxide ion and usual molecular hydrogen H<sub>2</sub>.
The properties of solvated electron can be investigated using the [[rotating ring-disk electrode]].
== Reactivity and applications == The solvated electron reacts with [[oxygen]] to form a [[superoxide]] [[radical (chemistry)|radical]] (O<sub>2</sub><sup>.−</sup>).<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Hayyan, M.; Hashim M. A.; AlNashef I. M.|title=Superoxide Ion: Generation and Chemical Implications|journal=Chem. Rev.|year=2016|volume=116|issue=5|pages=3029–3085|doi=10.1021/acs.chemrev.5b00407|pmid=26875845}}</ref> With [[nitrous oxide]], solvated electrons react to form [[hydroxyl]] radicals (HO<sup>.</sup>).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Janata|first=E.|author2=Schuler, Robert H. |title=Rate constant for scavenging eaq- in nitrous oxide-saturated solutions|journal=J. Phys. Chem.|year=1982|volume=86|issue=11|pages=2078–84|doi=10.1021/j100208a035}}</ref> The solvated electrons can be scavenged from both aqueous and organic systems with [[nitrobenzene]] or [[sulfur hexafluoride]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}.
A common use of sodium dissolved in liquid ammonia is the [[Birch reduction]]. Other reactions where sodium is used as a reducing agent also are assumed to involve solvated electrons, e.g. the use of sodium in ethanol as in the [[Bouveault–Blanc reduction]].
== Diffusion == The diffusivity of the solvated electron in liquid ammonia can be determined using potential-step [[chronoamperometry]].<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/271082773 | title=The diffusion coefficient of solvated electrons in liquid ammonia}}</ref>
== History == The first recorded observation of the color of metal-electride solutions is generally attributed to [[Sir Humphry Davy]]. In 1807–1809, he examined the addition of grains of potassium to gaseous ammonia (liquefaction of ammonia was invented in 1823). [[James Ballantyne Hannay]] and J. Hogarth repeated the experiments with sodium in 1879–1880. W. Weyl in 1844 and C.A. Seely in 1871 were the first to use liquid ammonia. [[Hamilton Cady]] in 1897 was the first to relate the ionizing properties of ammonia to that of water. [[Charles A. Kraus]] measured the [[electrical conductance]] of metal ammonia solutions and in 1907 was the first to attribute it the electrons liberated from the metal.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kraus | first1 = Charles A. | year = 1907 | title = Solutions of Metals in Non-Metallic Solvents; I. General Properties of Solutions of Metals in Liquid Ammonia | url = | journal = [[J. Am. Chem. Soc.]] | volume = 29 | issue = 11| pages = 1557–1571 | doi = 10.1021/ja01965a003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Zurek | first1 = Eva | year = 2009 | title = A Molecular Perspective on Lithium–Ammonia Solutions | url = | journal = [[Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.]] | volume = 48 | issue = 44| pages = 8198–8232 | doi = 10.1002/anie.200900373 | pmid = 19821473 }}</ref> In 1918, G. E. Gibson and W. L. Argo introduced the solvated electron concept.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gibson | first1 = G. E. | last2 = Argo | first2 = W. L. | year = 1918 | title = The Absorption Spectra of the Blue Solutions of Certain Alkali and Alkaline Earth Metals in Liquid Ammonia and Methylamine | url = | journal = [[J. Am. Chem. Soc.]] | volume = 40 | issue = 9| pages = 1327–1361 | doi = 10.1021/ja02242a003 }}</ref> They noted based on [[Absorption spectrum|absorption spectra]] that different metals and different solvents ([[methylamine]], [[ethylamine]]) produce the same blue color, attributed to a common species, the solvated electron. In the 1970s, solid salts containing [[electride|electrons as the anion]] were characterized.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Dye, J. L. | title = Electrons as Anions | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | year = 2003 | volume = 301 | pages = 607–608 | doi = 10.1126/science.1088103 | pmid = 12893933 | issue = 5633}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
* {{cite journal | last1 = Sagar | first1 = D. M. | last2 = Colin | last3 = Bain | first3 = D. | last4 = Verlet | first4 = Jan R. R. | year = 2010 | title = Hydrated Electrons at the Water/Air Interface | url = | journal = J. Am. Chem. Soc. | volume = 132 | issue = 20| pages = 6917–6919 | doi = 10.1021/ja101176r | pmid = 20433171 }} * {{cite journal|last1=Martyna|first1=Glenn|title=Electronic states in metal-ammonia solutions|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=71|issue=2|pages=267–270|doi=10.1103/physrevlett.71.267 |pmid=10054906|bibcode = 1993PhRvL..71..267D |year=1993}} * {{cite journal|last1=Martyna|first1=Glenn|title=Quantum simulation studies of singlet and triplet bipolarons in liquid ammonia|journal=Journal of Chemical Physics|volume=98|issue=1|pages=555–563|doi=10.1063/1.464650|bibcode = 1993JChPh..98..555M |year=1993}} * {{cite journal|last1=Martyna|first1=Glenn|title=Quantum simulation studies of metal–ammonia solutions|journal=Journal of Chemical Physics|volume=100|issue=10|pages=7590–7601|doi=10.1063/1.466852 |bibcode = 1994JChPh.100.7590D |year=1994}} *{{cite book|url=http://pubs.acs.org/isbn/9780841200517|doi=10.1021/ba-1965-0050|isbn=978-0-8412-0051-7|title=Solvated Electron|volume=50|series=Advances in Chemistry|year=1965}} *{{cite book|doi=10.1021/ba-1965-0050.ch006|chapter=Reactions of the Hydrated Electron|title=Solvated Electron|volume=50|pages=55–81|series=Advances in Chemistry|year=1965|last1=Anbar|first1=Michael|isbn=978-0-8412-0051-7}} *{{cite journal|doi= 10.1039/C1CP21803D |pmid= 22075842 |title= On the nature and signatures of the solvated electron in water |journal= Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. |volume= 14 |issue= 1 |pages= 22–34 |year= 2012 |last1= Abel |first1= B. |last2= Buck |first2= U. |last3= Sobolewski |first3= A. L. |last4= Domcke |first4= W. |bibcode= 2012PCCP...14...22A }} *{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022072881800277|title=Determination of the Chemical Solvation Energy of the Solvated Electron|journal=Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry and Interfacial Electrochemistry|volume=129|issue=1–2|pages=349–352|series=Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry|year=1981|doi=10.1016/S0022-0728(81)80027-7|last1=Harima|first1=Y.|last2=Aoyagui|first2=S.}} *Survey of Progress in Chemistry, chapter 5, 129, 1969 [first page https://www.sciencedirect.com/sdfe/pdf/download/eid/1-s2.0-B9780123957061500108/first-page-pdf] and content preview [https://books.google.ro/books?id=43upH7_tovwC&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=sodium+reaction+with+water+Walker+1966&source=bl&ots=AocXNWQlTV&sig=tG0qSOMEsIvAYnknZF6JIbX6oTo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQrruBqvHbAhWiJZoKHUtuC0YQ6AEIYzAM#v=onepage&q=sodium%20reaction%20with%20water%20Walker%201966&f=false] *The electrochemistry of the solvated electron Technische Universiteit Eindhoven https://pure.tue.nl/ws/files/2089318/388448.pdf *IAEA On the Elextrolytic Generation of Hydrated Electron [http://www.iaea.org/inis/collection/NCLCollectionStore/_Public/07/254/7254831.pdf] *Fundamentals of Radiation Chemistry, chapter 6, p 145-198, Academic Press, 1999 [https://books.google.ro/books?id=TudUOdz8SIwC&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=sodium+reaction+with+water+Walker+1966&source=bl&ots=bJwdX3CYOB&sig=e2BYlVGwFglgScUmWRg-svocQ0E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3zr6ZnvHbAhWJFJoKHSceBCoQ6AEIbzAO#v=onepage&q=sodium%20reaction%20with%20water%20Walker%201966&f=false]
[[Category:Solutions]] [[Category:Radiation]] [[Category:Nuclear chemistry]] [[Category:Organic chemistry]]

page.title: Southern Anatolian montane conifer and deciduous forests

revision.text:
The '''Southern Anatolian montane conifer and deciduous forests''' [[terrestrial ecoregion|ecoregion]], in the [[Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub]] [[biome]], is of the eastern [[Mediterranean Basin]].
== Setting ==
The ecoregion covers an area of {{convert|29,500|sqmi|km2|sp=us}}, and covers portions of [[Israel]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Syria]], the [[Palestinian territories]] and [[Turkey]].
== External links ==
* {{WWF ecoregion|name=Southern Anatolian montane conifer and deciduous forests|id=PA1220}}
[[Category:Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Turkey]] [[Category:Anatolia]] [[Category:Flora of Turkey|*]] [[Category:Forests of Turkey]] [[Category:Eastern Mediterranean]] [[Category:Environment of the Mediterranean]] [[Category:Flora of the Mediterranean|.]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Asia]] [[Category:Palearctic ecoregions]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{italictitle}} [[Image:John Gould Emu.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The [[Emu]] from ''The Birds of Australia''.]] '''''The Birds of Australia''''' was a book written by [[John Gould]] and published in seven volumes between 1840 and 1848. It was the first comprehensive survey of the [[birds of Australia]] and included descriptions of 681 species, 328 of which were new to science and were first described by Gould.
Gould and his wife [[Elizabeth Gould (illustrator)|Elizabeth]] travelled to Australia from England in 1838 to prepare the book. They spent a little under two years collecting specimens for the book. John travelled widely and made extensive collections of Australian birds and other fauna. Elizabeth, who had illustrated several of his earlier works, made hundreds of drawings from specimens for publication in ''The Birds of Australia''<ref>Linda Hall Library. [http://www.lindahall.org/events_exhib/exhibit/exhibits/womenswork/gould3.shtml Portraits of 12 Scientific Illustrators from the 17th to the 21st Century] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060928115328/http://www.lindahall.org/events_exhib/exhibit/exhibits/womenswork/gould3.shtml |date=2006-09-28 }}</ref>
The plates of the book were produced by [[lithography]], Elizabeth produced 84 plates before she died in 1841, [[Edward Lear]] produced one, [[Waterhouse Hawkins]] contributed one and the remaining 595 plates were produced by [[Henry Constantine Richter|H. C. Richter]] from Elizabeth's drawings and were published under his name.<ref name = "NLA">Hetherington, M. [http://www.nla.gov.au/collect/treasures/apr_treasure.html John Gould's Birds of Australia] in Peter Cochrane ed. Remarkable Occurrences: The National Library of Australia’s First 100 Years, 1901–2001. National Library of Australia</ref><ref>Kenneth Spencer Research Library. John Gould, his birds and beasts - [http://spencer.lib.ku.edu/exhibits/gould/collections/gould.htm John and Elizabeth Gould]</ref>
250 sets of the seven-volume work were printed.<ref name = "NLA"/> Complete sets of original volumes recently sold at auction for more than [[A$]]350,000.<ref>Kells, F and Kells, S. 2000. [http://libres.curtin.edu.au/libres10n2/kells.htm The Australian Book Auction Records]. Library and Information Science Research {{ISSN|1058-6768}}</ref>
In 1865 Gould published a revised and updated version of the text of ''The Birds of Australia'' in the two-volume ''[[Handbook to the Birds of Australia]]''.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|The Birds of Australia (John Gould)}} *[http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn365487 ''The Birds of Australia: in seven volumes''] / John Gould - National Library of Australia collection copy of the 1848 edition - digitised
{{DEFAULTSORT:Birds of Australia (Gould)}} [[Category:Books about Australian natural history]] [[Category:Fine illustrated books]] [[Category:1840s books]] [[Category:Ornithological handbooks]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 3 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{main|Energy law}} '''United States energy law''' is a function of the federal government, states, and local governments. At the federal level, it is regulated extensively through the [[United States Department of Energy]]. Every state, the Federal government, and the [[District of Columbia]] collect some [[motor vehicle]] [[excise tax]]es.<ref name="MVET Rates">[http://www.taxadmin.org/fta/rate/motor_fl.html Motor Fuel Excise Tax Rates as of January 1, 2008 from the Federation of Tax Administrators website]. Retrieved February 24, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100224115922/http://www.taxadmin.org/fta/rate/motor_fl.html |date=February 24, 2010 }}</ref> Specifically, these are excise taxes on [[gasoline]], [[diesel fuel]], and [[gasohol]].<ref name="MVET Rates" /> While many western states rely a great deal on [[severance tax]]es on oil, gas, and mineral production for revenue, most states get a relatively small amount of their revenue from such sources.<ref name="taxdis">[http://www.taxadmin.org/fta/rate/07taxdis.html 2007 State Tax Collection by Source from the Federation of Tax Administrators website]. Retrieved February 24, 2009.</ref>
The practice of energy law has been the domain of [[law firm]]s working on behalf of [[utility]] companies, rather than [[legal scholar]]s or other legal actors (such as private [[lawyer]]s and [[paralegal]]s), especially in [[Texas]], but this is changing. Some officials from energy agencies may take jobs in the utilities or other companies they regulate, such as the former [[FERC]] chairman did in 2008.<ref>"Former FERC Chairman Joins [[Husch Blackwell Sanders]]", August 4, 2008, found at [http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/former-ferc-chairman-joins-husch/story.aspx?guid=%7B1C27F35B-C132-4AC9-81EC-2CEED947C3FE%7D&dist=hppr Marketwatch story]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref>
The [[American Bar Association]] (ABA) has a ''Section of Environment, Energy, and Resources'', which is a "forum for lawyers working in areas related to environmental law, natural resources law, and energy law."<ref>[http://www.abanet.org/environ/ Section of Environment, Energy, and Resources of the American Bar Association website]. Retrieved August 22, 2008.</ref> The Section houses several substantive committees on environmental and energy law that release current information on topics of interest to practitioners and news of committee activities.<ref>http://www.americanbar.org/groups/environment_energy_resources/committees.html</ref> The ABA recognized 'environmental and energy law' as one of the practice areas where legal work may be found in 2009.<ref>Deborah L. Cohen and Julie Kay, "Where the Work IS," ''ABA Journal'', August 2009, pp. 58-61, at 59.</ref>
==Common law== Under the [[common law]], persons who owned [[real property]] owned "[[Cuius est solum eius est usque ad coelum et ad inferos|from the depths to the heavens]]".<ref name=Merrill>Thomas Merrill, ''Establishing Ownership: First Possession versus Accession,'' p. 14, fn. 22-23, Law and Economics Workshop (University of California, Berkeley 2007 Paper 3), found at [http://repositories.cdlib.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1174&context=berkeley_law_econ CDLib website]. Retrieved September 17, 2008.</ref><ref>Written as ''cjus est solum, ejus est usque ad coelum et ad inferos.'' This has been translated as "To whomever the soil belongs, he owns also to the sky and the depths." Black's Law Dictionary (6th ed. 1990). From Merrill, fn. 22, ''[[q.v.]]''.</ref> Therefore, [[real estate]] traditionally has included all rights to water, oil, gas, and other minerals underground.<ref name=Merrill /> The [[United States Supreme Court]] has held that as far as [[air rights]], "this doctrine has no place in the modern world,"<ref>''[[United States v. Causby]],'' 328 U.S. 256, 261 (1942), see {{ussc|328|256|1946}}. From Merrill, fn. 23, ''[[q.v.]]''.</ref> but it remains as a source of law to this day, or "fundamental to property rights in land."<ref name=Merrill />
An [[easement]] or [[license]] to drill for oil, gas, or minerals generally runs with the [[Real property|land]], and thus is an [[appurtenant easement]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} However, a utility easement generally runs with the owner of the [[easement]], rather than running with the land, and as such, is an example of an [[Easement#Easement in gross|easement in gross]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}
The West digest system, used in [[WestLaw]], has allocated several topics in energy law: * 114 – Customs duties * 145 – Electricity * 190 – Gas * 371 – Taxation.
There are many library research resources available about American oil and gas law.<ref name=Cooley>"OIL AND GAS LAW: A Selective Research Guide," from the [http://www.cooley.edu/library/research_guides/Oil_Gas_Law.pdf Cooley Law School website]. Retrieved July 28, 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527121141/http://www.cooley.edu/library/research_guides/Oil_Gas_Law.pdf |date=May 27, 2010 }}</ref>
==Federal laws== {{Main|United States Department of Energy#Related legislation}} {{See also|List of United States federal legislation|Energy Information Administration}}
Previous to the 1920s, the role of the Federal government in energy was restricted to the disposition of oil, gas, and coal on Federal lands. The [[Mineral Leasing Act of 1920]] {{USC|30|181}} et seq. is the major Federal law that authorizes and governs [[lease|leasing]] of [[public land]]s for developing deposits of [[hydrocarbons]] and other minerals. Previous to the act, these materials were subject to mining claims under the [[General Mining Act of 1872]]. In ''[[BP America Production Co. v. Burton]]'', [[Case citation|549 U.S. 84]] (2006), the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] held that a [[statute of limitations]] does not apply to government [[lawsuit|actions]] for [[contract]] claims for an agency to recover royalties on such leases.
Concerned that a predicted immanent shortage of petroleum would not leave enough fuel for naval vessels, President William Howard Taft established the first Naval Petroleum Reserve by withdrawing Federal land over the [[Elk Hills Oil Field]] in California from being claimed and drilled by private companies. A number of additional Naval Petroleum Reserves and Naval Oil Shale Reserves were established by Taft and his successor, Woodrow Wilson.
Until the 1920s, "the federal government did not play an active role in the energy industries," sometimes explained as due to "the widespread belief in the unlimited supply of energy."<ref name=cornell>[http://topics.law.cornell.edu/wex/energy Cornell Law School website]. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> The first US law was the [[Federal Power Act|Federal Power Act of 1920]] (later amended in 1935 and 1986).<ref name=cornell /><ref>[http://www.kannerandassoc.com/ Federal Energy Law Summaries online].</ref><ref>[http://www.fws.gov/laws/lawsdigest/fedpowr.html Federal Power laws online].</ref><ref>[http://www.theorator.com/bills108/s716.html Federal Power Act Amendments Act of 2003 at The Orator website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204041630/http://www.theorator.com/bills108/s716.html |date=February 4, 2012 }}.</ref> The [[Manhattan Project]] of the 1940s "initiated the era of nuclear regulation."<ref name=cornell /> In 1946, the [[United States Atomic Energy Act of 1946|Atomic Energy Act]] was passed.<ref>Pub.L. 1946, ch. 724, 60 Stat. 755, {{USPL|60|755}}.</ref>
The [[Price-Anderson Nuclear Industries Indemnity Act]] was first enacted in 1957, and has been renewed periodically, which governs a [[no-fault insurance]] regime for [[nuclear accident]]s.<ref>Pub.L. 1957, 85 Stat. 257, {{USPL|85|257}}, codified at 42 U.S. ch. 23.</ref> The statute was upheld as constitutional in ''[[Duke Power Co. v. Carolina Environmental Study Group]]'', 438 U.S. 59 (1978).<ref>''Duke Power Co. v. Carolina Environmental Study Group'', 438 U.S. 59 (1978).</ref>
The Department of Energy and its constituent [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] (FERC) were created in 1977,<ref name=cornell /> through the [[Department of Energy Organization Act]].<ref>Pub.L. 95-238, 92 Stat. 47, {{USPL|95|238}}.</ref> The stated purposes of these "federal energy laws and regulations is to provide affordable energy by sustaining competitive markets, while protecting the economic, environmental, and security interests of the United States."<ref name=cornell /> The U.S. [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] (NRC) regulates the use of [[nuclear power]] and its uses as a [[Atom bomb|defense weaponry]].<ref name=cornell />
Other statutes are the [[Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act]],<ref>PURPA, at {{USPL|95|617}}</ref> the [[Energy Security Act]],<ref>{{USPL|96|294}}.</ref> the [[Price-Anderson Nuclear Industries Indemnity Act]], and the [[Energy Policy Act of 1992]]<ref>{{USPL|102|486}}</ref> Most of these laws are codified at [[U.S. Code]], Title 16, Chapter 12 – Federal regulation and development of power. The [[Commodity Futures Modernization Act of 2000]] also affects energy trading companies. The [[Oil Pollution Act of 1973]] and [[Oil Pollution Act of 1990]] affect the transportation of oil on the [[high seas]].
As of January 1, 2008, the Federal excise tax is 18.3 [[cent (currency)|cents]] per [[gallon]] on gasoline, 24.3 cents per gallon on diesel, and 13 cents per gallon on [[gasohol]].<ref name="MVET Rates" />
===Energy Policy Act of 2005=== {{Main|Energy Policy Act of 2005}} The most recent major law is the [[Energy Policy Act of 2005]], which was an attempt to combat growing energy problems, changed the [[energy policy of the United States]] by providing tax incentives and loan guarantees for energy production of various types. <ref>({{USPL|109|58}}).</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/oust/fedlaws/publ_109-058.pdf|title=PUBLIC LAW 109–58—AUG. 8, 2005 ENERGY POLICY ACT OF 2005|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|accessdate=July 2, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303163112/http://www.epa.gov/oust/fedlaws/publ_109-058.pdf|archivedate=March 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/F?c109:6:./temp/~c109fE8GRZ:e496969: |title=Sec. 388 |accessdate=2008-07-11 |publisher=U.S.LibraryofCongress |date=2005-08-08 }}</ref> There were various [[Energy Policy Act of 2005#Criticism|criticisms]] of the Act.<ref>Grunwald, Michael and Juliet Eilperin. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/29/AR2005072901128.html Energy Bill Raises Fears About Pollution, Fraud Critics Point to Perks for Industry]." ''Washington Post''. July 30, 2005.</ref><ref>"[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/8870039/ Bush signs $12.3 billion energy bill into law]." ''MSNBC''. Aug. 8, 2005.</ref> One of the most controversial [[Energy Policy Act of 2005#Change to daylight saving time|provisions of that Act]] was to change [[daylight saving time]] by four to five weeks, depending upon the year;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2005/07/26/dim_witted_proposal_for_daylight_time/|title=Dim-witted proposal for daylight time|work=Boston Globe|author=Alex Beam|date=2005-07-26}}</ref> some scholars have questioned whether daylight saving results in a net energy savings.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ryan Kellogg; Hendrik Wolff|title=Does extending daylight saving time save energy? Evidence from an Australian experiment|version=CSEM WP 163|publisher=University of California Energy Institute|date=January 2007|url=http://www.ucei.berkeley.edu/PDF/csemwp163.pdf}}</ref> It also directs a study for the development of [[oil shale]] and [[tar sands]] resources on public lands especially in [[Colorado]], [[Utah]], and [[Wyoming]].<ref name=anl>{{cite web | publisher= Oil Shale and Tar Sands Leasing Programmatic EIS Information Center | url= http://ostseis.anl.gov/eis/what/index.cfm | title = What's in the Oil Shale and Tar Sands Leasing Programmatic EIS | accessdate=2007-07-10}}</ref> The Act further sets Federal reliability standards regulating the electrical grid (done in response to the [[2003 North America blackout|Blackout of 2003]]).<ref>Ken Belsen and Matthew L. Wald, " '03 Blackout Is Recalled, Amid Lessons Learned", ''[[New York Times]]'', August 13, 2008, found at [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/14/nyregion/14blackout.html?_r=1&oref=slogin NY Times website]. Retrieved August 27, 2008.</ref><ref>David Freedlander, "It could happen again: On fifth anniversary of blackout, nation still vulnerable", ''A.M. N.Y.'', August 12, 2008. See response at [https://archive.is/20101206135212/http://www.amny.com/news/opinion/am-letters0815,0,1329107.story Letter to the Editor]. Retrieved August 27, 2008.</ref><ref>Report, Energy and Commerce Committee, "Blackout 2003: How Did It Happen and Why? Full Committee on Energy and Commerce, September 4, 2003, found at [http://energycommerce.house.gov/reparchives/108/Hearings/09042003hearing1062/print.htm Energy and Commerce Committee website]. Retrieved August 27, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081125144426/http://energycommerce.house.gov/reparchives/108/Hearings/09042003hearing1062/print.htm |date=November 25, 2008 }}</ref> There was also criticism of what was ''not'' included: the bill did not include provisions for drilling in the [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] (ANWR) even though some Republicans claim "access to the abundant [[oil reserves]] in ANWR would strengthen America's energy independence without harming the environment."<ref>Knight, Peyton. "[http://www.nationalcenter.org/TSR111005.html Small Group of House Republicans Derails ANWR Drilling] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140803110211/http://nationalcenter.org/TSR111005.html |date=2014-08-03 }}." Washington, DC: [http://www.nationalcenter.org/ The National Center for Public Policy Research]. November 10, 2005.</ref> There are a number of [[tax credit]]s in the Act, including the [[Nonbusiness Energy Property Tax Credit]].
===Developments 2007 to present=== [[File:Hubbert Upper-Bound Peak 1956.png|left|thumb|Hubbert's upper-bound prediction for US crude oil production (1956), and actual lower-48 states production through 2014]] Two Federal laws passed in 2007 were the [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]],<ref>Pub.L. 110-140, 121 Stat. 1492.</ref><ref>Summary of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, "New Energy Law Raises CAFE Standards," December 19, 2007, found at [http://enviro.blr.com/news.aspx?id=84183 Environment BLR website]. Retrieved February 17, 2009.</ref> and the [[Food and Energy Security Act of 2007]].<ref>("2007 Farm Bill"), Pub.L. 110-234, 122 Stat. 923 {{USPL|110|234}}.</ref>
{{quote|The [[auto industry]] said federal regulators are pushing too far, too fast in their effort to raise fuel-mileage rules. The complaints from the industry, which had previously voiced support for tougher standards, underscore how economic hardship is affecting a major policy debate.|''The Wall Street Journal''<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121789813230412201?mod=googlenews_wsj Wall Street Journal article from Google News]. Retrieved August 12, 2008.</ref>}}
The [[Biomass Research and Development Board]] was expected to release a report in late 2008 about [[biomass]] as fuel.
In August 2008, it was revealed that oil speculators had increased the [[Volatility (finance)|volatility]] of the price of oil; Congressman [[John Dingell]] criticized the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] for failing to scrutinize oil futures traders, in particular the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] company [[Vitol]].<ref>David Cho, "Sway of oil speculators revealed", ''[[Washington Post]]'', August 21, 2008, synidated at the ''[[Albany Times Union]]'', found at [http://timesunion.com/ASPStories/Story.asp?StoryID=713783&LinkFrom=RSS Albany Times Union website]. Retrieved August 27, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165653/http://timesunion.com/ASPStories/Story.asp?StoryID=713783&LinkFrom=RSS |date=October 14, 2008 }}</ref> On June 22, 2008, Obama proposed the repeal of the [[Enron loophole]] as a means to curb [[speculation]] on skyrocketing oil prices.<ref name="AP">{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/25318274/|title=Obama vows crackdown on energy speculators: McCain fires back after Democrat tries to tie rival to 'Enron loophole'|date=2008-06-22|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=2008-07-24}}</ref>
In October 2008, as the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] approached victory in the 2008 elections, they remained divided on [[energy policy]], thus a consensus was not expected in energy law.<ref>Sandler, Michael, "Dems get ready to rule," ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', found at [http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/dems-get-ready-to-rule-2008-10-28.html TheHill website]. Retrieved October 29, 2008.</ref> [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]]'s first [[Secretary of Energy]], [[Steven Chu]],<ref name="Office of the President-Elect">{{cite news| title=Chu to be Energy Secretary| url=http://change.gov/newsroom/entry/president_elect_barack_obama_announces_key_members_of_energy_and_environmen/| date=2008-12-15| accessdate=2008-12-16| publisher=[[change.gov]]| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813143325/http://change.gov/newsroom/entry/president_elect_barack_obama_announces_key_members_of_energy_and_environmen/| archive-date=2014-08-13| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/19/magazine/19wwln-q4-t.html?_r=3&ref=energy-environment ''New York Times'' interview with Steven Chu]. Retrieved April 20, 2009.</ref> had no prior expertise in law.
The [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] (DOE) will, by administrative measures, reduce the [[Hanford nuclear reservation]] (originally 586 square miles) to 10 square miles.<ref name=Hanford>AP, "Feds propose big cut in restricted area at Hanford," March 29, 2009, found at [http://www.seattlepi.com/local/6420ap_wa_hanford_shrinkage.html Seattle Post Intelligencer website]{{dead link|date=May 2011}}. Retrieved March 30, 2009.</ref> Much of the remaining area will go to the {{convert|300|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} [[Hanford Reach National Monument]].<ref name=Hanford />
In October 2009, Secretary Chu announced a new program, Arpa-e, which will fund grants authorized under the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007.<ref>Matthew L. Wald, "Energy Dept. Aid for Scientists on the Edge," ''New York Times'', October 25, 2009, found at [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/26/science/earth/26energy.html?_r=1&partner=rss&emc=rss NY Times article]. Retrieved October 26, 2009.</ref>
The "Energy Credit for Qualified Fuel Cell Property and Qualified Microturbine Property" was created in 2008,<ref>I.R.C. § 48; rules published at [https://www.irs.gov/irb/2008-34_IRB/ar10.html Internal Revenue Bulletin 2008-34]. Dated August 25, 2008. Accessed April 11, 2013.</ref> but it appears to have expired as of 2013.
Individual taxpayers may claim several energy credits to reduce their Federal [[Income taxes]], if they file the Long [[Form 1040]] along with Form 5695 attached. These include the "Resident energy efficient property tax credit", and starting in the 2012 tax year, a "nonbusiness energy property credit".<ref>[[Internal Revenue Service]], ''1040 Instructions'', Form 1040 line 52, instructions pages 5, 45, and Form 5695. Instruction for Form 1040 Found online at [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i1040.pdf], and for Form 5695 at [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f5695.pdf]. Both accessed April 11, 2013.</ref> Some of these provisions were extended by ARRA (see below) and by later bills.<ref>[[Internal Revenue Service]], ''Energy Incentives for Individuals in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act'', found at [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f5695.pdf]. Updated November 4, 2011. Accessed April 11, 2013.</ref>
===American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009=== [[File:Alternative Energies.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Loans and investments into green energy technology is a significant part of ARRA]] {{Main|American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009}} As part of the $787 Billion stimulus package or "ARRA" (technically the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]]),<ref name=ARRA>ARRA, the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]], {{USPL|111|5}}, see [http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=111_cong_public_laws&docid=f:publ005.111 GPO website]; {{USBill|111|H.R.|1}}, see [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:HR00001:@@@S H.R. 111-1 at the Library of Congress]. Retrieved March 23, 2009.</ref>
[[File:Barack Obama signs American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 on February 17.jpg|thumb|right|294px|U.S. President Barack Obama signs the ARRA into law on February 17, 2009 in [[Denver, Colorado]]. [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] stands behind him.]]
US law now allows rebates for energy efficient products and for weatherization.<ref name=Consumers>Traci Watson, "Consumers Could Foil Plans for Conservation: People buy energy efficient items, then use them more," ''[[USA Today]]'', March 23, 2009, found at [http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/3138427 iStockAnalyst website], original found at [https://www.usatoday.com/printedition/news/20090323/energysavings23_st.art.htm USA Today website]. Retrieved March 23, 2009.</ref> Energy law and policy are significantly affected by this new law.<ref>[http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/archive.cfm/pubDate=%7Bd%20%272009-02-18%27%7D Analysis of ARRA at the Department of Energy website]. Retrieved March 23, 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://appropriations.house.gov/pdf/PressSummary02-13-09.pdf |title=SUMMARY: AMERICAN RECOVERY AND REINVESTMENT |date=2009-02-13 |publisher=Committee on Appropriations |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216170759/http://appropriations.house.gov/pdf/PressSummary02-13-09.pdf |archivedate=February 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.recovery.gov/?q=content%2Finvestments |title=Recovery.gov website |access-date=2009-09-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917024227/http://www.recovery.gov/?q=content%2Finvestments |archive-date=2009-09-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wmtw.com/money/18706385/detail.html |title=WTMW website |access-date=2014-07-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217091518/http://www.wmtw.com/money/18706385/detail.html |archive-date=2012-02-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Official seal of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.svg|thumb|left|91px|Official seal of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.]]
==State laws== The states affect energy in numerous ways, including taxes, land use controls, regulation of energy utilities, and energy subsidies. States may establish environmental standards stricter than those set by the federal government. Regulation of oil and gas production, particularly on non-federal land, is largely left up to the states.
===Alaska law=== {{Main|Alaska#Energy}} [[File:Alaska Crude Oil Production.PNG|thumb|Alaska oil production peaked in 1988 and has declined 65% since]] [[Alaska]] has vast energy resources: * Major oil and gas reserves are found in the [[Prudhoe Bay]] area of the [[Alaska North Slope]] (ANS) and [[Cook Inlet]] basins. According to the [[Energy Information Administration]], Alaska ranks second in the [[United States|nation]] in [[crude oil production]], accounting for 1/5 (20%) of United States oil production, Prudhoe Bay alone accounting for 8% of the United States domestic oil production.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} * The [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline]] pumps up to {{convert|2.1|Moilbbl|m3}} of crude oil per day, more than any other crude oil pipeline in the United States. * Substantial coal deposits are found in Alaska's bituminous, sub-bituminous, and lignite coal basins. The United States Geological Survey estimates that there are {{convert|85.4|Tcuft|km3}} of undiscovered, technically recoverable gas from natural gas hydrates on the Alaskan North Slope.<ref>[http://www.usgs.gov/corecast/details.asp?ep=74 Gas Hydrates on Alaska's North Slope] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601170523/http://www.usgs.gov/corecast/details.asp?ep=74 |date=2010-06-01 }}.</ref> * Alaska also offers some of the highest [[hydroelectric power]] potential in the country from its numerous rivers, and large swaths of the Alaskan coastline offer wind and geothermal energy potential as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/state/state_energy_profiles.cfm?sid=AK |title= EIA State Energy Profiles: Alaska |date=2008-06-12 |accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref> As of 2001, the state's Energy Plan stated that, although [[wind power|wind]] and [[hydroelectric power]] are abundant, with [[single-wire earth return#Use in interties|low-cost electric interties]] they were judged uneconomical.<ref>[http://www.dced.state.ak.us/dca/AEIS/PDF_Files/AIDEA_Energy_Screening.pdf Screening Report for Alaska Rural Energy Plan], April 2001 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216014031/http://www.dced.state.ak.us/dca/AEIS/PDF_Files/AIDEA_Energy_Screening.pdf |date=February 16, 2008 }}</ref>
Likewise, Alaska receives a large proportion of its state revenues from its [[severance tax]] on oil: a full 68% of all revenue, much more than any state (only [[Wyoming]] coming close).<ref name="taxdis" /> Its dependence on [[petroleum]] revenues and federal subsidies allows it to have the lowest individual tax burden in the United States.<ref>CNN Money (2005). "How tax friendly is your state?" Retrieved from [http://money.cnn.com/pf/features/lists/taxesbystate2005/index.html CNN website].</ref><ref>[http://www.tax.state.ak.us/ Department of Revenue Tax Division website]</ref>
The state created the [[Alaska Permanent Fund]] from this "golden egg", which is owned and managed by the state, and "created by a constitutional amendment":<ref>[http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/permFund/aboutPermFund.cfm Alaska Permanent Fund website About the Fund page]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422031921/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/permFund/aboutPermFund.cfm |date=April 22, 2009 }}</ref>
{{quote|In November 1976, Alaskans voted to amend their state constitution to create the Permanent Fund. The state constitution and supporting statutes set out the Fund's purpose and how it works.|Alaska Permanent Fund<ref>[http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/lawIndex.cfm Alaska Permanent Fund website Fund Law page]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924010311/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/lawIndex.cfm |date=September 24, 2009 }}</ref>}}
The constitutional provisions are found at Alaska Constitution Article IX, Section 15.<ref>Alaska Constitution Article IX, Section 15, found at [http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/constAndLaw.cfm Alaska Permanent Fund website Alaska constitution and law pertaining to the Permanent Fund]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415083955/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/constAndLaw.cfm |date=April 15, 2009 }}</ref> Statutes regulate how the Fund is to be invested,<ref>Alaska Statutes § 37.13.120. "Investment responsibilities," found at [http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/investLaw.cfm Alaska Permanent Fund website Alaska state law concerning Fund investments]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924014935/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/investLaw.cfm |date=September 24, 2009 }}</ref> as well as how the [[income]] is to be disbursed.<ref>Alaska Statutes § 37.13.140. "Income." and § 37.13.145. "Disposition of income." found at [http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/incomeLaw.cfm Alaska state law concerning Fund income]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524000716/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/incomeLaw.cfm |date=May 24, 2009 }}</ref> Regulations state additional details regarding control of the Fund.<ref>"Alaska Administrative Code (AAC) pertaining to the Permanent Fund," 15 AAC Chapter 137. "Revenue Receipt, custody, investment and management of state funds," found at [http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/regulations.cfm Alaska Permanent Fund website]. Retrieved March 10, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524001755/http://www.apfc.org/home/Content/fundlaw/regulations.cfm |date=May 24, 2009 }}</ref>
The Federal government runs the [[Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects]], which are new pipelines, and its "Federal Coordinator" (director) is [[advice and consent|nominated with advice and consent of the Senate]] by the [[President of the United States]].<ref name="USA Alaska">"Across the USA: Alaska:Fairbanks," ''USA Today'', November 13, 2009, p. 13A.</ref><ref name="Drue Pearce">[http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/pearce-drue Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects government website biography of Drue Pearce] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808140901/http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/pearce-drue |date=2010-08-08 }}. Retrieved August 6, 2010.</ref> [[Drue Pearce]] was the first director; she was nominated by [[George W. Bush]] and served from December 13, 2006 through January 3, 2010.<ref name="USA Alaska" /><ref name="Drue Pearce" /> [[Larry Persilly]] is the current coordinator; he was nominated by [[Barack Obama]] on December 9, 2009, and was confirmed by the United States Senate on March 10, 2010.<ref name="Larry Persily">[http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/persily-larry Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects government website biography of Larry Persily] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620072941/http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/persily-larry |date=June 20, 2013 }}. Retrieved August 6, 2010.</ref>
===California law=== {{Main|California Energy Code}} The most populous state in the United States, [[California]] has gone through a series of [[California Energy crisis|energy crises]], and has reacted with several laws concerning energy. The [[California Energy Code]], or Title 24 of the [[California Code of Regulations]], also titled "The Energy Efficiency Standards for Residential and Nonresidential Buildings", were established in 1978 in response to a legislative mandate to reduce California's [[Domestic energy consumption|energy consumption]]. The standards are updated periodically to allow consideration and possible incorporation of new [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] technologies and methods, such as the [[Programmable Communicating Thermostat]].<ref>''See'' [http://www.energy.ca.gov/title24 Official code] and [http://www.bsc.ca.gov/title_24 BSC website].</ref>
California assesses an excise tax with the same basic rate of 18 cents per gallon on gasoline, diesel fuel, and gasohol.<ref name="MVET Rates" /> The state collects a relatively small 6.6 percent of its revenue from extraction and related taxes.<ref name="taxdis" />
===New Mexico law=== {{Main|New Mexico#Law & government}} As a major energy producer, [[New Mexico]] has government offices related to energy, including the Energy Conservation and Management Division,<ref>[http://www.emnrd.state.nm.us/ecmd/ Energy Conservation and Management Division website main page]. Retrieved February 19, 2009.</ref> which is part of the state's Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department.<ref>[http://www.emnrd.state.nm.us/main/index.htm Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department website]. Retrieved February 19, 2009.</ref> All of the major laws impacting energy are available from the Division's website.<ref name="NMLaws">[http://www.emnrd.state.nm.us/ECMD/LawsRegulationsExecutiveOrders/lawsregulationsexecutiveorders.htm Energy Conservation and Management Division website page on Laws, Regulations, Executive Orders]. Retrieved February 19, 2009.</ref> These include links to all of the state's [[statute]]s and related government websites, Federal and State [[regulation]]s, and [[Executive order (United States)|Executive orders]].<ref name="NMLaws" />
[[Uranium mining in New Mexico]] had been significant from about 1950 until 1998.<ref>See, ''e.g.'', Brookins, Douglas G. (1977) ''Uranium deposits of the Grants mineral belt: geochemical constraints on origin'', in ''Exploration Frontiers of the Central and Southern Rockies'', Denver: Rocky Mountain Association of Geologists, p. 337–52; Granger, H.C. ''et al.'', "Sandstone-type uranium deposits at Ambrosia Lake, New Mexico-an interim report," ''Economic Geology'', Nov. 1961, pp. 1179–1210.</ref> Several oil and gas companies developed [[uranium]] ore mines in New Mexico during that period.<ref name="time1957">{{cite journal| url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,891393,00.html| journal = Time | date = 1957-09-30 | title = Atomic Energy: Uranium Jackpot| accessdate=July 1, 2013}}(lists many companies)</ref> As of 2007, at least one company was evaluating development by [[in-situ leaching]]; there are potentially large deposits of [[coffinite]] and [[uranium oxide]] ores available in New Mexico.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://geoinfo.nmt.edu/staff/mclemore/documents/07-111_18.pdf |title=URANIUM RESOURCES IN NEW MEXICO |author=McLemore, V.|publisher=New Mexico |year=2007 |accessdate=July 1, 2013}}</ref>
New Mexico has enacted a number of new laws related to energy, including to create a New Mexico Renewable Energy Transmission Authority and to increase its renewable portfolio standards.<ref name="NMLaws" /><ref>[http://energylegalblog.com/archive/2007/03/12/322.aspx Energy Legal Blog], citing [http://www.nmlegis.gov/Sessions/07%20Regular/final/HB0188.pdf House bill 0188 session 2007 about New Mexico Renewable Energy Transmission Authority] and [http://www.nmlegis.gov/Sessions/07%20Regular/final/SB0418.pdf Senate bill 0418 session 2007 about renewable portfolio standards]. Retrieved February 17, 2009.</ref> According to one law firm's summary of President Obama's Economic Recovery Package, the state stands to gain much from the new administration, because "New Mexico leaders and laboratories are at the forefront of energy policy."<ref name=summary>Kelly de la Torre & Julia Jones, Memorandum of Law, "Update: President-elect Barack Obama's Renewable Energy Policy and New Mexico," (n.d., December 2008?), found at [http://www.bwenergylaw.com/News/documents/RENEWABLEENERGYPOLICYANDNEWMEXICO.pdf Beatty & Wozniak P.C. Law firm website]. Retrieved February 17, 2009.</ref> For example, former [[University of New Mexico Law School]] professor [[Suedeen G. Kelly]] was a member of the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]].<ref name=summary /><ref>"Energy team add UNM professor", ''[[Daily Lobo]]'', November 17, 2003, [http://media.www.dailylobo.com/media/storage/paper344/news/2003/11/17/News/Energy.Team.Adds.Unm.Professor-568001.shtml Daily Lobo archives]. Retrieved February 17, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604141219/http://media.www.dailylobo.com/media/storage/paper344/news/2003/11/17/News/Energy.Team.Adds.Unm.Professor-568001.shtml |date=June 4, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.ferc.gov/about/com-mem/kelly/kelly-bio.asp FERC government website Biography of Commissioner Kelly web page]. Retrieved February 17, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090825070830/http://www.ferc.gov/about/com-mem/kelly/kelly-bio.asp |date=August 25, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cleanskies.tv/articles/ferc-commissioner-kelly-wont-seek-3rd-term.html|work=Clean Skies|title=FERC Commissioner Kelly Won't Seek 3rd Term|first=Dipka|last=Bhambhani|date=September 22, 2009|accessdate=November 14, 2012}}</ref>
The state collects an effective rate of 18.875 cent per gallon tax on gasoline and gasohol, and 22.875 cents per gallon on diesel.<ref name="MVET Rates" /> Like many western states, it collects significant revenue from extraction taxes—20.9 percent of its overall sources.<ref name="taxdis" />
The City of [[Albuquerque]] passed an [[Local ordinance|ordinance]] to regulate "efficiency standards for heating and cooling equipment," which was struck down by the [[U.S. District Court]] as violating the [[Commerce Clause]] of the [[U.S. Constitution]].<ref>"District court puts brakes on N.M. energy law," ''Contractor Magazine'', December 1, 2008 (Penton Media), found at [http://contractormag.com/law/district_court_puts/ Contractor Magazine website]. Retrieved February 17, 2009.</ref>
The town board of [[Taos, New Mexico|Taos]] passed a "strict new new building code" in 2009 that mandated energy savings:
{{quote|The ordinance ... mandates that residential construction meet [[Home energy rating|Home Energy Rating System]] standards that gradually phase in starting this year, and commercial construction must meet [[Leadership In Energy and Environmental Design]] certified standards beginning this year.|''AP'' report, March 4, 2009.<ref>AP, "Taos passes strict new building code," March 2, 2009, found at [http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/environment/environment_ap_taos_building_code_200903021045 AP report on KRQE-TV website]. See also "Taos passes strict new building code," found at [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29470655/ MSNBC website]. Retrieved March 4, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405120431/http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/environment/environment_ap_taos_building_code_200903021045 |date=April 5, 2013 }}</ref>}}
The town debated the proposed Ordinance 08-16, High Performance Building Ordinance, starting in October 2008,<ref>"Town of Taos Updates," ''Taos Daily & Horse Faly'', October 31, 2008, found at [http://www.taosdaily.com/index.php?fuseaction=home.viewarticle&article_id=2624 Taos Daily website]. Retrieved March 4, 2009.</ref> postponed it for legal review,<ref>"Highlights from the Town of Taos special Council meeting of 10/28/08," found at [http://galleryrealtyoftaos.com/2008/10/28/town-of-taos-regular-council-meeting-highlights-102808/ galleryrealtyoftaos.com website]. Retrieved March 4, 2009.</ref> debated it in February 2009,<ref>"Highlights from the Town of Taos special Council meeting of 2/19/09," found at [http://galleryrealtyoftaos.com/2009/02/19/highlights-from-the-town-of-taos-special-council-meeting-21909/ galleryrealtyoftaos.com website]. Retrieved March 4, 2009.</ref> and passed it in March 2009.
The [[New Mexico Gas Company]] offers an Energy Star Home Rebate.<ref>Energy Star Home Rebate form, see [http://www.nmgco.com/pdf/NMGC_Energy_Star_Home_Rebate.pdf New Mexico Gas Company website Energy Star Home Rebate form]. Retrieved March 4, 2009.</ref>
In October 2009, Governor [[Bill Richardson]] announced 21 grants for energy projects that are being funded by $8 Million in [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|ARRA]] funds.<ref>"Across the USA News from every state," ''USA Today'', October 28, 2009, p. 7A, found at [https://www.usatoday.com/NEWS/usaedition/2009-10-28-states28_ST_U.htm?csp=34 USA Today archives]. Retrieved October 28, 2009.</ref><ref>"Richardson Announces $8.1 Million in Stimulus Funds," ''Gila Sustainable Community News, Calendar and Forum'', October 28, 2009, found at [http://gilacommunity.net/viewtopic.php?f=106&p=9255 Gila Community News website with complete list of all 21 projects]. Retrieved October 28, 2009.</ref>
===New York law=== {{Main|New York energy law}} [[New York (state)|New York]] has an Energy Law.<ref>N.Y. Energy Law § 1-101, found at [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/menugetf.cgi?COMMONQUERY=LAWS New York State Legislature official web site], go to "ENG", then "Article 1", finally "1-101 - Short title". Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> Under New York law, "energy" and "energy resources" are defined as:
{{quote|"Energy" means work or heat that is, or may be, produced from any fuel or source whatsoever. ... "Energy resources" shall mean any force or material which yields or has the potential to yield energy, including but not limited to electrical, fossil, geothermal, wind, hydro, solid waste, tidal, wood, solar and nuclear sources.|N.Y. Energy Law § 1-103 (5) and (6).<ref>N.Y. Energy Law § 1-103 (5) and (6), found at [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/menugetf.cgi?COMMONQUERY=LAWS New York State Legislature official website], go to "ENG", then "Article 1", finally "1-103 – Definitions". Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref>}}
The chief regulator is the "[[Commissioner]]" or "president" of the [[New York State Energy Research and Development Authority]] (also called NYSERDA).<ref>N.Y. Energy Law § 1-103 (4), found at [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/menugetf.cgi?COMMONQUERY=LAWS New York State Legislature official website], go to "ENG", then "Article 1", finally "1-103 - Definitions". Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref><ref name=nyserda>[http://www.nyserda.ny.gov/About/default.asp NYSERDA official website About webpage] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121214105437/http://www.nyserda.ny.gov/About/default.asp |date=2012-12-14 }}. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> The [[board of directors]] of NYSERDA includes—as a [[rule of law|matter of law]]—several utility insiders, as well as ''[[ex officio]]'' commissioners.<ref name=nyserda /><ref>[http://www.nyserda.ny.gov/about/board/default.asp NYSERDA official website Board of Directors webpage]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> Vincent DeIorio, a lawyer, is chairman of the board,<ref>[http://www.nyserda.ny.gov/About/Board/deiorio.asp NYSERDA official website Chairman's webpage]. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> and Francis J. Murray Jr. is President and [[CEO]]. NYSERDA was created as a [[public benefit corporation]] under NY law.<ref name=PBA>N.Y. Public Authorities Law §§ 1850 ''[[:et seq.]]'', found at [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/menugetf.cgi?COMMONQUERY=LAWS New York State Legislature official website], go to "PBA", then "Article 8", finally "Title 9 – (1850–1883) NEW YORK STATE ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY". Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref><ref name=pdf>[http://www.nyserda.ny.gov/About/TITLE_9_NYSERDA.pdf NYSERDA law from its official website]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (pdf document). Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> New York's other regulatory bodies and entities include the [[New York State Public Service Commission]], the [[New York State Department of Health]], the [[New York Power Authority]], and the [[Long Island Power Authority]].
In addition to Energy Law, the state has a variety of laws regulating and taxing energy, and its courts have issued significant case law concerning energy taxes. Two trial court cases in 2012 allowed local zoning law to pre-empt state law by effectively banning [[hydrofracking]], but this is being appealed.<ref>''Anschutz Exploration Corp. v. Town of Dryden'' __ N.Y.S.2d ___ (Index # 2012-0902) (N.Y. Supreme Ct. Tompkins Co. February 21, 2012), and ''Cooperstown Holstein Corp. v. Town of Middletown'', __ N.Y.S.2d ___ (Index # 2012-0930) (N.Y. Supreme Ct. Otsego Co. February 24, 2012). For discussion of these cases, see Charles Gottlieb, ''Hydrofracking, Local Zoning, and State Preemption'', paper presented at the [[Warren M. Anderson]] Legislative Breakfast Series, "Hydrofracking – Balancing the 3 E's: Energy, Environment, and Economic Development," February 28, 2012 ([[Albany Law School]]); Andrew Carden, "Judge rules local governments can ban fracking," ''[[Legislative Gazette]]'', February 28, 2012, page 13; Andrew Carden, "Another victory for anti-frackers," ''[[Legislative Gazette]]'', March 6, 2012, pp. 8, 19. Compare N.Y. Environmental Conservation Law § 23-0303 (2), found at [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/LAWSSEAF.cgi?QUERYTYPE=LAWS+&QUERYDATA=$$ENV23-0303$$@TXENV023-0303+&LIST=LAW+&BROWSER=EXPLORER+&TOKEN=24382709+&TARGET=VIEW N.Y. State assembly website]. Retrieved February 29, 2012.</ref>
Under New York law, both the [[New York Attorney General]] or a [[district attorney]] may prosecute alleged polluters who make [[oil spill]]s.<ref>Mark Fass, "Panel Finds D.A. Can Prosecute Polluter Under N.Y. Law", ''[[New York Law Journal]]'' (N.Y.L.J.), August 22, 2008, may be found at [http://www.bloglines.com/blog/PLL/2008_8_22 Bloglines website]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} or [http://www.law.com/jsp/nylj/PubArticleNY.jsp?hubtype=TopStories&id=1202423964488 N.Y.L.J. website] (Subscription Required). Citing ''People v. Quadrozzi'', No. 2006-065575 (2d dep't 2008), which cited N.Y. ECL §§ 71-0403 and 71-1933 (9), see [http://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/menugetf.cgi?COMMONQUERY=LAWS NY Laws at the Assembly official website], go to "ENV – Environmental Conservation", then "ARTICLE 71 – ENFORCEMENT". Links accessed August 27, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The state has enacted a number of recent laws to control [[carbon emission]]s.<ref>[http://assembly.state.ny.us/member_files/090/20070921/ website of Member of Assembly Sandy Galef] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201074847/http://assembly.state.ny.us/member_files/090/20070921/# |date=2012-12-01 }}. Retrieved August 27, 2008.</ref>
The state collects an effective rate of 24.4 cent per gallon tax on gasoline and gasohol, and 22.65 cents per gallon on diesel.<ref name="MVET Rates" /> New York collects one of the smallest amounts of revenue from extraction taxes of any state—only 5.8 percent of its overall sources.<ref name="taxdis" />
===Pennsylvania=== The Keystone state has been a major energy producer for over one hundred years. The state passed a [[Renewable energy law in Pennsylvania]].
===Texas law=== {{Main|Railroad Commission of Texas}} [[File:Texas Oil Production 1935-2012.png|thumb|right|150px|Texas oil production curve]] Oil, gas, and other energy resources are regulated by the powerful [[Railroad Commission of Texas|Texas Railroad Commission]].<ref>[http://www.rrc.state.tx.us/ Texas Railroad Commission official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref> It is the oldest regulatory agency in Texas, having been created in 1891.<ref name="about RRC">[https://web.archive.org/web/20130614210425/https://www.rrc.state.tx.us/about/history/index.php About the RRC Web page, on the Texas Railroad Commission official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080802162445/http://www.rrc.state.tx.us/about/index.html |date=August 2, 2008 }}</ref> It "oversee[s] the Texas oil and gas industry, gas utilities, pipeline safety, safety in the liquefied petroleum gas industry, and the surface mining of coal."<ref name="about RRC" />
According to ''Forbes'', the [[University of Houston]] has an "exceptional" energy policy and law program.<ref>{{cite web|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaelkrancer/2016/09/30/if-there-were-a-big-12-of-energy-the-university-of-houston-would-be-a-star/#72df0755541f|title=If there were a big 12 of energy the University of Houston would be a star|first=Michael|last=Krancer|date=September 30, 2016|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref>
===Vermont law=== {{Main|Act 250 (Vermont law)}} The state of [[Vermont]], like other states, has a comprehensive statutory scheme governing energy generation and transmission issues, colloquially referred to as "Section 248." The reference is to 30 V.S.A. Sec. 248, which is administered by Vermont's Public Service Board, a quasi-judicial board with three members. Section 248 is not to be confused with Vermont's comprehensive law governing land development and subdivision – Act 250.<ref>[http://www.nrb.state.vt.us/lup/publications/nrb1.pdf ACT 250: A Guide to Vermont's Land Use Law. State of Vermont Environmental Board, Montpelier, VT (USA), November 2000] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521092721/http://www.nrb.state.vt.us/lup/publications/nrb1.pdf# |date=2013-05-21 }}. Retrieved February 19, 2009.</ref> The state has an independent energy distributor, the [[Vermont Electric Cooperative]].
=== Wyoming law === [[Wyoming]] is the top [[coal]] producer of the 50 states in the [[United States]], has significant oil and gas reserves, and its government and laws reflect an interest in energy production, especially [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref name="UWyo">Press release, "UW Energy Research Diversifies", July 17, 2008, found at [http://www.uwyo.edu/news/showrelease.asp?id=24502 University of Wyoming official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref> The [[Wyoming]] Oil and Gas Conservation Commission regulates many aspects of oil, coal, and gas development in this resource-rich state.<ref>[http://wogcc.state.wy.us/ Wyoming Oil and Gas Conservation Commission official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref> There is an annual state Gas Fair.<ref>[https://www.wyogasfair.org/WNGFA.htm Wyoming Natural Gas Fair Association official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref> The [[University of Wyoming]] is well known for its research on energy development.<ref name="UWyo" /> The University sponsored a symposium on [[coal gasification]] in 2007.<ref>Press release, "School of Energy Resources Symposium Will Explore Coal Gasification in Wyoming", February 14, 2007, found at [http://www.uwyo.edu/news/showrelease.asp?id=13362 University of Wyoming official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref><ref>Symposium agenda, "Coal Gasification: What Does It Mean for Wyoming?" found at [http://www.westernresearch.org/SERSymposia/coalgas4wy/index_files/Page312.htm Western Research of the University of Wyoming official website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref>
Wyoming assesses an excise tax with the same rate of 14 cents per gallon on gasoline, diesel fuel, and gasohol.<ref name="MVET Rates" /> The state collects the largest percentage—46 percent of its revenue—from extraction and related taxes, the second highest of the states, surpassed only by Alaska.<ref name="taxdis" />
''[[Governing (magazine)|Governing]]'' has noted that starting in 2000, many observers have viewed the state's "overreliance on minerals taxes" to be "fiscally unhealthy", but it was rescued by the oil, gas, and coal boom; there remains a political wariness about imposing an [[income tax]], yet in 2012 the state imposed a tax on [[wind turbine]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.governing.com/topics/finance/politics-behind-not-levying-personal-state-income-taxes.html|work=Governing|title=The Politics Behind Not Levying Personal Income Taxes: In the nine states that don't levy a personal income tax, the politics of staying that course remains powerful|last=Walters|first=Jonathan|date=October 2013|accessdate=October 31, 2013}}</ref>
===Other state laws=== [[Florida]] and [[South Carolina]] have instituted utility fees to finance planned [[nuclear reactor]]s.<ref>Paul Davidson, "Nuclear power inches back into energy spotlight," ''USA Today'', March 30, 2009, at B1, found at [https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/energy/environment/2009-03-29-nuclear-power-energy-return_N.htm USA Today story of March 30, 2009]. Retrieved March 30, 2009.</ref>
[[Indiana]] passed in 2009 a law "that allows the state's finance authority to negotiate long-term contracts to buy and sell synthetic natural gas from a planned southern Indiana coal-[[gasification]] plant."<ref>Rick Callahan, "Governor signs coal-gasification bill," Associated Press (as published in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''), March 24, 2009, found at [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-ap-in-xgr-coalgasificat,0,1585737.story Chicago Tribune website]. Retrieved March 25, 2009.</ref>
[[Massachusetts]] Governor [[Deval Patrick]] successfully pushed for "clean energy initiatives" in the 2008 legislative session, calling it "one of the most productive in a long, long time."<ref>Matt Viser, "Patrick touts clean energy, economic initiatives, ''[[Boston Globe]]'', August 5, 2008 found at [http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2008/08/patrick_touts_c.html Boston Globe website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref>
[[New Hampshire]] passed in 2008 an energy law, signed by Governor [[John H. Lynch|John Lynch]], which "provides guidelines for residential wind energy systems ... such as height, noise, setbacks and aesthetics and outlines a process for input from neighbors." <ref name="UNH Student">AP, "UNH student research leads to new wind energy law", ''[[Boston Globe]]'', July 23, 2008, found at [http://www.boston.com/news/local/new_hampshire/articles/2008/07/23/unh_student_research_leads_to_new_wind_energy_law/ Boston Globe article on new New Hampshire energy law]. Retrieved August 21, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> This was found necessary because a [[University of New Hampshire]] student, Laura Carpenter, found that "most communities had no ordinances or zoning rules that specifically address small residential wind turbines."<ref name="UNH Student" />
[[Ohio]] requires utilities to meet regulatory goals for conservation.<ref>AEP Ohio Meets Goal of New Ohio Energy Law by Filing Electric Security Plan Below Market Rates; Continues Lowest Rates in the State; Balanced and progressive plan demonstrates "AEP's Commitment to Ohio's Future", found at [http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/aep-ohio-meets-goal-new/story.aspx?guid=%7B7BBCE3DC-CC50-4393-90BC-CED9965F862E%7D&dist=hppr Market Watch website]. Retrieved August 21, 2008.</ref>
